ancient-philosophy.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Ancient Philosophy

## Introduction
Ancient Philosophy encompasses foundational Western and Eastern thought from pre-Socratic Greece to Hellenistic periods and early Indian/Chinese schools. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: Ancient Greece, India, China.

## Key Ideas
Ethics vary (e.g., Stoic virtue, Confucian ren). Life meaning through wisdom or harmony. Afterlife: Diverse (Plato’s soul immortality, Buddhist reincarnation).

## Key Thinkers
Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Confucius, Laozi.

## Influence
Shaped Western ethics, Eastern traditions, modern philosophy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Plato Bust](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Plato_Silanion_Musei_Capitolini_MC1377.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, copy of 4th-century BCE original)

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/philosophies/platonism.md), [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ancient-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Ancient Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Western-philosophy/Ancient-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Greek Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/greekphi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Ancient Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_philosophy)
ancient-philosophy-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Ancient Philosophy

## Introduction
Ancient Philosophy spans foundational thought from pre-Socratic Greece (6th century BCE) to Hellenistic schools and early Indian/Chinese traditions. Branch: Historical. Historical context: Emerged in Greece (Thales), India (Upanishads), China (Confucius). Cultures: Mediterranean, South/East Asia.

## Branches
Pre-Socratic, Socratic, Platonic, Aristotelian, Hellenistic (Stoicism, Epicureanism), Vedic, Confucian, Daoist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ethics range from virtue (Aristotle) to detachment (Buddhism). Life meaning: Eudaimonia (Greek flourishing), moksha (Indian liberation). Afterlife: Soul immortality (Plato), reincarnation (Buddhism), or agnostic (Confucianism).

## Key Thinkers
Socrates (Socratic method), Plato (Forms), Aristotle (virtue ethics), Confucius (ren), Laozi (Dao).

## Influence
Western philosophy, Eastern ethics, global thought systems.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Plato Bust](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Plato_Silanion_Musei_Capitolini_MC1377.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, copy of 4th-century BCE original)

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/philosophies/platonism.md), [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ancient-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Ancient Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Western-philosophy/Ancient-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Greek Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/greekphi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Ancient Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Ancient Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2012102)
ancient-philosophy-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Ancient Philosophy

## Introduction
Ancient Philosophy laid the groundwork for Western and Eastern thought, from pre-Socratic Greece (6th century BCE) to Hellenistic schools and Indian/Chinese traditions (Upanishads, Confucius). Branch: Historical. Historical context: Rise of Greek city-states, Indian Vedic culture, Chinese Zhou dynasty. Cultures: Greece, India, China.

## Branches
Pre-Socratic (Thales, Heraclitus), Socratic, Platonic, Aristotelian, Hellenistic (Stoicism, Epicureanism, Skepticism), Vedic (Upanishads), Jain, Buddhist, Confucian, Daoist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ethics diverse—Greek virtue (Aristotle’s eudaimonia), Stoic resilience, Confucian harmony, Buddhist non-attachment. Life meaning: Flourishing (Greek), liberation (Indian), or balance (Chinese). Afterlife: Plato’s immortal soul, Buddhist reincarnation, Confucian ambiguity. Debates: Material vs. ideal (Democritus vs. Plato), free will vs. fate (Stoics).

## Key Thinkers
Socrates (questioning), Plato (Forms), Aristotle (logic), Confucius (social ethics), Laozi (natural way), Gautama Buddha (Four Noble Truths).

## Influence
Western logic/ethics, Eastern spiritual traditions; debated for universalism vs. cultural specificity.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Plato Bust](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Plato_Silanion_Musei_Capitolini_MC1377.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, copy of 4th-century BCE original)

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/philosophies/platonism.md), [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md), [stoicism.md](/philosophies/stoicism-roman.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ancient-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Ancient Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Western-philosophy/Ancient-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Greek Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/greekphi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Ancient Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Ancient Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2012102)
[^6]: IEP - Chinese Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/chinphil/)
animism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Animism

## Introduction
Animism attributes spirits to natural phenomena, viewing all things as alive. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Indigenous traditions globally, ancient roots.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Respect for spirits, nature. Life meaning: Interconnectedness with all beings. Afterlife: Spiritual continuity, often ancestral.

## Key Thinkers
E.B. Tylor (term coiner), Indigenous oral traditions.

## Influence
Shapes indigenous worldviews, eco-philosophy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Animist Ritual Illustration](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Animist_shrine.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2010)

## Related Religions

animism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Animism

## Introduction
Animism posits that all entities—animals, plants, objects—possess spirits or consciousness. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Foundational to indigenous cultures, formalized by Tylor in 1871. Cultures: Global indigenous (African, Native American, Oceanic).

## Branches
Traditional animism (tribal), neo-animism (modern eco-spirituality).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: All things imbued with spirit, requiring respect. Ethics: Harmony with nature, ritual offerings. Life meaning: Relational existence with spirits. Afterlife: Continuity in spirit world, often ancestral or ecological.

## Key Thinkers
E.B. Tylor (anthropological definition), Graham Harvey (new animism), Indigenous elders.

## Influence
Environmental ethics, anthropology, indigenous rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Animist Ritual Illustration](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Animist_shrine.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2010)

## Related Religions
See [shamanism.md](/religions/shamanic-philosophy.md), [yoruba-religion.md](/religions/yoruba-religion.md), [aboriginal-dreamtime.md](/religions/aboriginal-dreamtime.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Animism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/animism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Animism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/animism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Animism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Indigenous Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/indigphi/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Animism Studies[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260490)
animism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Animism

## Introduction
Animism attributes spiritual essence to all entities, foundational to indigenous worldviews. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient, documented by Tylor (1871). Cultures: African (Yoruba), Native American (Lakota), Oceanic (Maori).

## Branches
Traditional (tribal practices), neo-animism (modern ecological), animist materialism (philosophical).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Everything has spirit, interconnected. Ethics: Respect, reciprocity with nature. Life meaning: Living in balance with spirits. Afterlife: Spirit continuity, ancestral realms. Debates: Anthropomorphism vs. ecological ethics.

## Key Thinkers
E.B. Tylor, Graham Harvey, Nurit Bird-David (relational animism).

## Influence
Eco-philosophy, indigenous rights, new materialism; criticized for oversimplification.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Animist Ritual Illustration](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Animist_shrine.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2010)

## Related Religions
See [shamanism.md](/religions/shamanic-philosophy.md), [yoruba-religion.md](/religions/yoruba-religion.md), [aboriginal-dreamtime.md](/religions/aboriginal-dreamtime.md), [navajo-philosophy.md](/philosophies/navajo-philosophy.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Animism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/animism/)

[^3]: Wikipedia - Animism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animism)

[^6]: IEP - Environmental Ethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/enviro-e/)
anomalous-monism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Anomalous Monism

## Introduction
Anomalous Monism posits mental events are physical but not reducible to physical laws. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 20th-century philosophy of mind.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral responsibility despite physicalism. Life meaning: Mental-physical unity. Afterlife: Ambiguous, possibly none.

## Key Thinkers
Donald Davidson (founder).

## Influence
Philosophy of mind, cognitive science.

## Related Religions
See [materialism.md](/philosophies/materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Anomalous Monism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/anomalous-monism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Anomalous Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomalous_monism)
[^3]: Britannica - Philosophy of Mind[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-mind)
antinatalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Antinatalism

## Introduction
Antinatalism argues procreation is unethical due to inevitable suffering. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Modern ethical debates, pessimism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Prevent suffering by not creating life. Life meaning: Minimize harm. Afterlife: Irrelevant, focus on ending suffering.

## Key Thinkers
David Benatar (Better Never to Have Been), Arthur Schopenhauer (precursor).

## Influence
Bioethics, environmental ethics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View David Benatar Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:David_Benatar.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2018)

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources

[^2]: Britannica - Antinatalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/antinatalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Antinatalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antinatalism)
antinatalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Antinatalism

## Introduction
Antinatalism deems procreation morally wrong due to life’s inherent suffering. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Roots in Schopenhauer’s pessimism, modernized by Benatar (2006). Cultures: Western ethical philosophy, global bioethics.

## Branches
Philosophical (Benatar’s asymmetry), ecological (overpopulation concerns).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Suffering outweighs pleasure; non-existence preferable. Ethics: Moral duty to avoid birth. Life meaning: Harm reduction. Afterlife: Not addressed, secular focus. Debates: Ethical absolutism vs. personal choice.

## Key Thinkers
David Benatar, Arthur Schopenhauer, Emil Cioran.

## Influence
Bioethics, population ethics, veganism; criticized for nihilism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View David Benatar Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:David_Benatar.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2018)

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md), [schopenhauerian-pessimism.md](/philosophies/schopenhauerian-pessimism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Antinatalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/antinatalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Antinatalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/antinatalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Antinatalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antinatalism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Antinatalism Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/4415832)

text# Antinomianism

## Introduction
Antinomianism rejects moral laws, emphasizing grace or inner morality. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Christian theology, Reformation era.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Grace over legalism. Life meaning: Spiritual freedom. Afterlife: Salvation by faith.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Luther (critic), Anne Hutchinson.

## Influence
Protestant theology, ethical debates.

## Related Religions
See [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md).

antipositivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antipositivism

## Introduction
Antipositivism rejects strict scientific positivism, valuing interpretive methods. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 19th-20th-century social sciences.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Subjective understanding. Life meaning: Cultural interpretation. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Wilhelm Dilthey, Max Weber.

## Influence
Sociology, hermeneutics.

## Related Religions
See [hermeneutics.md](/philosophies/hermeneutics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Hermeneutics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hermeneutics/) [contextual]

text# Antirealism

## Introduction
Antirealism denies mind-independent reality, emphasizing perception. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Subjective moral frameworks. Life meaning: Constructed reality. Afterlife: Unknowable.

## Key Thinkers
Michael Dummett, Nelson Goodman.

## Influence
Philosophy of science, language.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/philosophies/idealism.md).

antireductionism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antireductionism

## Introduction
Antireductionism holds complex systems cannot be reduced to parts. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century science/philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Holistic moral systems. Life meaning: Emergent complexity. Afterlife: Not central.

## Key Thinkers
C.D. Broad, Hilary Putnam.

## Influence
Systems theory, philosophy of mind.

## Related Religions
See [emergentism.md](/philosophies/emergentism.md).

## Sources

text# Anti-Theism

## Introduction
Anti-Theism actively opposes belief in gods, viewing it as harmful. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern atheism debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Secular rationality. Life meaning: Freedom from divine. Afterlife: None presumed.

## Key Thinkers
Christopher Hitchens, Victor Stenger.

## Influence
New atheism, secular activism.

anthropocentrism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Anthropocentrism

## Introduction
Anthropocentrism prioritizes humans in ethical and metaphysical frameworks. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Western philosophy, Enlightenment.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Human welfare over nature. Life meaning: Human dominion. Afterlife: Varies, often secular.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant, Francis Bacon.

## Influence
Environmental ethics debates, humanism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

anthropocentrism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Anthropocentrism

## Introduction
Anthropocentrism centers humans as the primary ethical and metaphysical concern. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Rooted in Renaissance humanism, Enlightenment rationality. Cultures: Western philosophy, industrial societies.

## Branches
Strong (humans only matter), weak (humans prioritized).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Human needs/values shape morality. Ethics: Prioritize human flourishing, often over environment. Life meaning: Human progress, dominion. Afterlife: Secular or religious (e.g., Christian soul). Debates: Anthropocentrism vs. biocentrism in ecology.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant (human dignity), Francis Bacon (nature mastery), Peter Singer (critic).

## Influence
Shaped industrialization, bioethics; criticized for ecological harm.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [humanism.md](/religions/humanism.md), [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Environmental Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-environmental/)
[^2]: Britannica - Anthropocentrism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/anthropocentrism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Anthropocentrism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropocentrism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Environmental Ethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/enviro-e/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Anthropocentrism Debates[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/4415833)

antinatalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Antinatalism

## Introduction
Antinatalism is an ethical philosophy arguing that bringing new life into existence is morally wrong due to inevitable suffering. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Modern Western pessimism, 19th-21st century.

## Key Ideas
Ethics center on preventing harm, viewing birth as imposing unconsented suffering. Life meaning: Mitigate existing pain, not create more. Afterlife: Irrelevant or negative if suffering continues.

## Key Thinkers
David Benatar (asymmetry argument), Arthur Schopenhauer (pessimism precursor), Emil Cioran.

## Influence
Bioethics, population control debates, environmental ethics.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md), [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md) (suffering focus).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - The Nonidentity Problem[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nonidentity/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Antinatalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/antinatalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pessimism[](https://iep.utm.edu/pessimis/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Antinatalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antinatalism)
antinatalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Antinatalism

## Introduction
Antinatalism posits procreation as unethical, emphasizing life's inherent suffering. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Roots in ancient pessimism (e.g., Ecclesiastes), modernized by Schopenhauer (1819); Benatar's "Better Never to Have Been" (2006). Cultures: Western philosophy, growing in online communities, Asia (Buddhist influences).

## Branches
Philosophical (negative utility of existence), philanthropic (prevent suffering), misanthropic (human flaw), environmental (overpopulation).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Asymmetry—existence has harms without benefits for non-existent; consent impossible. Ethics: Moral duty to abstain from reproduction. Life meaning: Alleviate current suffering. Afterlife: Dismissed as wishful, or irrelevant. Debates: Individual choice vs. absolute duty, optimism counterarguments.

## Key Thinkers
David Benatar (asymmetry), Arthur Schopenhauer (will as suffering), Emil Cioran (birth defect), Philipp Mainländer.

## Influence
Bioethics (eugenics debates), veganism (harm prevention), climate activism; criticized for depression link.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md), [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [schopenhauerian-pessimism.md](/philosophies/schopenhauerian-pessimism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - The Nonidentity Problem[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nonidentity/)
[^2]: Britannica - Antinatalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/antinatalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pessimism[](https://iep.utm.edu/pessimis/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Antinatalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antinatalism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Antinatalism Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/4415832)
antinomianism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antinomianism

## Introduction
Antinomianism opposes moral laws, prioritizing grace or inner guidance. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Christian theology, Reformation.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Freedom from legalism. Life meaning: Spiritual liberation. Afterlife: Faith-based salvation.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Luther (critic), Johannes Agricola, Anne Hutchinson.

## Influence
Protestant debates, free grace theology.

## Related Religions
See [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md), [calvinism.md](/philosophies/calvinism.md).

antipositivity.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antipositivism

## Introduction
Antipositivism critiques strict scientific positivism, favoring interpretive social science. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 19th-century Germany, hermeneutics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Subjective understanding. Life meaning: Cultural context. Afterlife: Not focused.

## Key Thinkers
Wilhelm Dilthey, Max Weber, Heinrich Rickert.

## Influence
Sociology, qualitative research.

## Related Religions
See [hermeneutics.md](/philosophies/hermeneutics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Hermeneutics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hermeneutics/)

antirealism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antirealism

## Introduction
Antirealism denies mind-independent reality, stressing verification or construction. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Context-dependent morals. Life meaning: Constructed. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Michael Dummett (semantic antirealism), Bas van Fraassen.

## Influence
Philosophy of science, language.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/philosophies/idealism.md), [constructivism.md](/philosophies/constructivist-epistemology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/realism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Anti-Realism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-realism)
[^3]: Britannica - Realism and Antirealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/realism)
antireductionism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Antireductionism

## Introduction
Antireductionism argues higher-level phenomena can't be reduced to lower parts. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century science philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Holistic values. Life meaning: Emergent wholeness. Afterlife: Possible emergent.

## Key Thinkers
Philip Anderson, Nancy Cartwright.

## Influence
Complexity science, biology philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [emergentism.md](/philosophies/emergentism.md), [holism.md](/philosophies/holism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Reductionism in Biology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/reduction-biology/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Antireductionism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antireductionism)
[^3]: Britannica - Philosophy of Science[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-science)
anti-theism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Anti-Theism

## Introduction
Anti-Theism opposes theism as harmful, advocating against religious belief. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: New Atheism, 21st century.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rationality over faith. Life meaning: Human progress. Afterlife: Rejected.

## Key Thinkers
Christopher Hitchens (God Is Not Great), Michel Onfray.

## Influence
Atheist activism, secular policy.

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Atheism and Agnosticism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atheism-agnosticism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Antitheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antitheism)
[^3]: Britannica - Atheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atheism)
apatheism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Apatheism

## Introduction
Apatheism is indifference to gods' existence, focusing on practical life. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern secularism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Pragmatic morality. Life meaning: This-world focus. Afterlife: Irrelevant.

## Key Thinkers
Jonathan Rauch, Thomas Nagel (related).

## Influence
Secular culture, tolerance.

## Related Religions
See [agnosticism.md](/religions/agnosticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Atheism and Agnosticism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atheism-agnosticism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Apatheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apatheism)

applied-ethics.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Applied Ethics

## Introduction
Applied Ethics applies moral theories to practical issues like medicine, environment. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Contemporary Western philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Case-based morality. Life meaning: Moral decision-making. Afterlife: Varies by issue (e.g., end-of-life).

## Key Thinkers
Peter Singer, Tom Beauchamp, James Childress.

## Influence
Policy, bioethics, law.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Peter Singer Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Peter_Singer_02.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2009)

## Related Religions

applied-ethics-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Applied Ethics

## Introduction
Applied Ethics uses normative theories for real-world dilemmas. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Post-WWII, medical advances. Cultures: Global, Western dominance.

## Branches
Bioethics, environmental ethics, business ethics, military ethics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Principles like autonomy, justice. Life meaning: Ethical navigation of technology/society. Afterlife: Euthanasia debates, dignity in death.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Singer (animal rights), Tom Beauchamp/Childress (principles), Aldo Leopold (land ethic).

## Influence
Public policy, professional codes.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Peter Singer Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Peter_Singer_02.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2009)

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/philosophies/bioethics.md), [environmental-ethics.md](/philosophies/environmental-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Applied Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/ethics-applied/)
[^2]: Britannica - Applied Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/applied-ethics)

applied-ethics-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Applied Ethics

## Introduction
Applied Ethics bridges theory and practice for issues like abortion, war. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 1970s rise with bioethics. Cultures: Western, expanding global.

## Branches
Bioethics, animal ethics, AI ethics, sexual ethics, media ethics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Utilitarianism, deontology applied. Life meaning: Moral responsibility in decisions. Afterlife: End-of-life ethics, dignity. Debates: Cultural relativism vs. universalism.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Singer, Beauchamp/Childress (four principles), Martha Nussbaum (capabilities).

## Influence
Laws (e.g., HIPAA), corporate ethics, global rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Peter Singer Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Peter_Singer_02.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2009)

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/philosophies/bioethics.md), [environmental-ethics.md](/philosophies/environmental-ethics.md), [ai-ethics.md](/philosophies/ai-ethics.md).

## Sources

atomism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Atomism

## Introduction
Atomism posits reality as composed of indivisible atoms and void, denying continuous substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient Greece, India, revived in modern science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual atoms imply personal responsibility. Life meaning: Material interactions. Afterlife: None, as soul is atomic or mortal.

## Key Thinkers
Leucippus, Democritus, Epicurus (Hellenistic), Kanāda (Indian).

## Influence
Modern physics, materialism.

## Related Religions
See [materialism.md](/philosophies/materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Atomism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atomism-ancient/)
[^2]: Britannica - Atomism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atomism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Democritus[](https://iep.utm.edu/democritu/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Atomism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomism)
atomism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Atomism

## Introduction
Atomism theorizes universe as atoms in void, foundational to materialist metaphysics. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: 5th-century BCE Greece (Leucippus/Democritus), Indian Vaisheshika (Kanāda), Hellenistic Epicurus. Cultures: Greek, Indian, Roman.

## Branches
Ancient (Democritean), Epicurean (ethical atoms), Indian (Vaisheshika), modern (scientific).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Atoms eternal, motion random; no divine creation. Ethics: Epicurean pleasure from atomic harmony. Life meaning: Sensual enjoyment in material world. Afterlife: Soul atoms disperse, no immortality. Debates: Determinism vs. chance, soul immortality.

## Key Thinkers
Leucippus/Democritus (origins), Epicurus (ethics), Lucretius (De Rerum Natura), Kanāda.

## Influence
Chemistry, atheism, Epicurean hedonism.

## Related Religions
See [materialism.md](/philosophies/materialism.md), [epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md](/philosophies/epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ancient Atomism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atomism-ancient/)
[^2]: Britannica - Atomism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atomism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Democritus[](https://iep.utm.edu/democritu/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Atomism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Atomist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260491)
buddhist-atomism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Buddhist Atomism

## Introduction
Buddhist Atomism views reality as momentary atoms, denying permanent self. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient India, Abhidharma texts.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Impermanence guides compassion. Life meaning: No-self realization. Afterlife: Rebirth cycles via karma.

## Key Thinkers
Vasubandhu, Dharmakirti.

## Influence
Buddhist philosophy, quantum analogies.

## Related Religions
See [buddhist-philosophy.md](/religions/buddhism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Abhidharma[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/abhidharma/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Buddhist Atomism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_atomism)
[^3]: Britannica - Buddhism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Buddhism)
authoritarianism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Authoritarianism

## Introduction
Authoritarianism favors strong centralized authority, limiting individual freedoms. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century regimes, ancient empires.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Obedience for order. Life meaning: Hierarchical stability. Afterlife: Not central, secular.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Hobbes (Leviathan precursor), Carl Schmitt.

## Influence
Political science, regime studies.

## Related Religions
See [fascism.md](/philosophies/fascism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Authoritarianism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/authoritarianism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Authoritarianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/authoritarianism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Authoritarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarianism)
authoritarianism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Authoritarianism

## Introduction
Authoritarianism prioritizes authority over liberty. Branch: Political. Historical context: Ancient (Roman Empire), modern (totalitarianism). Cultures: Global, Asia/Europe dominant.

## Branches
Traditional (monarchic), totalitarian (ideological), competitive (hybrid).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Power concentration for efficiency. Ethics: Duty to leader/state. Life meaning: Collective security. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Stability vs. oppression.

## Key Thinkers
Hobbes (social contract), Machiavelli (prince), Hannah Arendt (critic).

## Influence
Regime types, democracy studies.

## Related Religions
See [fascism.md](/philosophies/fascism.md), [nazism.md](/philosophies/nazism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Authoritarianism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/authoritarianism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Authoritarianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/authoritarianism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Authoritarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarianism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Political Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/polphil/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Authoritarian Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/20009877)
bayesianism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Bayesianism

## Introduction
Bayesianism updates beliefs via probability and evidence. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 18th-century statistics, modern decision theory.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rational choice under uncertainty. Life meaning: Evidence-based decisions. Afterlife: Probabilistic, agnostic.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Bayes, Bruno de Finetti, Richard Jeffrey.

## Influence
AI, economics, philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [bayesian-epistemology.md](/philosophies/bayesian-epistemology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bayesian Epistemology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/epistemology-bayesian/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Bayesianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesianism)
[^3]: Britannica - Probability Theory[](https://www.britannica.com/science/probability-theory)
bayesianism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Bayesianism

## Introduction
Bayesianism treats belief as probability, updated by evidence. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Bayes' 1763 theorem, 20th-century revival. Cultures: Western mathematics, global science.

## Branches
Subjective Bayesianism, objective (Dutch book arguments).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Prior + likelihood = posterior. Ethics: Rational decision-making. Life meaning: Adaptive learning. Afterlife: Low probability. Debates: Subjectivity vs. objectivity.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Bayes, Leonard Savage, Frank Ramsey.

## Influence
Machine learning, law, medicine.

## Related Religions
See [bayesian-epistemology.md](/philosophies/bayesian-epistemology.md), [decision-theory.md](/philosophies/decision-theory.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bayesian Epistemology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/epistemology-bayesian/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Bayesianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesianism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Probability[](https://iep.utm.edu/probability/)
[^4]: Britannica - Probability Theory[](https://www.britannica.com/science/probability-theory)
[^5]: JSTOR - Bayesian Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/20009878)
behaviorism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Behaviorism

## Introduction
Behaviorism studies mind via observable behavior, rejecting introspection. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Early 20th-century US psychology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Conditioned responses. Life meaning: Environmental shaping. Afterlife: None, materialist.

## Key Thinkers
John B. Watson, B.F. Skinner, Ivan Pavlov.

## Influence
Psychology, education.

## View Illustrative Image
[View B.F. Skinner Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:B.F._Skinner_at_Harvard_circa_1950.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, 1950)

## Related Religions
See [materialism.md](/philosophies/materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Behaviorism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/behaviorism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Behaviorism[](https://www.britannica.com/science/behaviorism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Behaviorism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behaviorism)
behaviorism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Behaviorism

## Introduction
Behaviorism reduces mind to observable behavior, ignoring inner states. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Watson 1913 manifesto, Skinner’s operant conditioning. Cultures: American psychology, global behavioral therapy.

## Branches
Methodological (Watson), radical (Skinner), neo (cognitive integration).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Learning via stimulus-response. Ethics: Shaped behavior for good. Life meaning: Conditioned environment. Afterlife: Denied. Debates: Reductionism vs. mental states.

## Key Thinkers
Watson (founder), Skinner (operant), Pavlov (classical).

## Influence
Therapy (CBT), education, animal training.

## View Illustrative Image
[View B.F. Skinner Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:B.F._Skinner_at_Harvard_circa_1950.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, 1950)

## Related Religions
See [materialism.md](/philosophies/materialism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Behaviorism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/behaviorism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Behaviorism[](https://www.britannica.com/science/behaviorism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Behaviorism[](https://iep.utm.edu/behavior/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Behaviorism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behaviorism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Behaviorist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260492)

text# Bioconservatism

## Introduction
Bioconservatism opposes radical biotech enhancement, favoring natural human limits. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 21st-century bioethics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Preserve humanity. Life meaning: Natural dignity. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Francis Fukuyama, Leon Kass.

## Influence
Bioethics policy.

## Related Religions

text# Biology, Philosophy of

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology examines life concepts like evolution, teleology. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Post-Darwin 19th century.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Bioethical issues. Life meaning: Evolutionary adaptation. Afterlife: None implied.

## Key Thinkers
Ernst Mayr, Elliott Sober, Peter Godfrey-Smith.

## Influence
Evolutionary ethics, ecology.

## Related Religions
See [evolution.md](/philosophies/evolution.md) [contextual].

biology-philosophy-of-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Biology, Philosophy of

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology analyzes life sciences' foundations. Branch: Science. Historical context: Darwin 1859, modern genomics. Cultures: Western science, global bioethics.

## Branches
Evolutionary theory, teleology, reductionism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Function vs. teleology in evolution. Ethics: Genetic engineering morals. Life meaning: Natural selection. Afterlife: Materialist, no spiritual. Debates: Species realism, adaptationism.

## Key Thinkers
Mayr (population thinking), Sober (fitness), Rosenberg (reduction).

## Influence
Bioethics, conservation.

## Related Religions
See [evolution.md](/philosophies/evolution.md), [naturalism.md](/philosophies/naturalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Biology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/biology-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Biology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-biology)

text# Biosophy

## Introduction
Biosophy is wisdom of life, holistic philosophy integrating biology and ethics. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century vitalism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Life-centered harmony. Life meaning: Organic unity. Afterlife: Cyclical continuation.

## Key Thinkers
Hanns André (founder).

Eco-philosophy, transhumanism.

text# British Idealism

## Introduction
British Idealism posits reality as spiritual or mental, emphasizing absolute idealism. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Late 19th-century Britain.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral unity in absolute. Life meaning: Spiritual realization. Afterlife: Soul persistence in absolute.

## Key Thinkers
T.H. Green, F.H. Bradley, Bernard Bosanquet.

## Influence
Social reform, neo-Hegelianism.

## Related Religions

Budapest School is a Marxist humanist philosophical group. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: 20th-century Hungary.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Humanist critique of bureaucracy. Life meaning: Emancipation. Afterlife: Materialist, none.

text# Buddhist Philosophy

## Introduction
Buddhist Philosophy addresses suffering, no-self, and enlightenment. Branch: Eastern. Cultural context: Ancient India, global spread.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Eightfold Path, compassion. Life meaning: End suffering via nirvana. Afterlife: Reincarnation until liberation.

## Key Thinkers
Gautama Buddha, Nagarjuna, Vasubandhu.

## Influence
Eastern thought, mindfulness.

## View Illustrative Image

buddhist-philosophy-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Buddhist Philosophy

## Introduction
Buddhist Philosophy explores impermanence, suffering, no-self. Branch: Eastern. Historical context: Buddha (5th century BCE), schools in India/Tibet/China. Cultures: South/East Asia.

## Branches
Theravada, Mahayana, Vajrayana.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Four Noble Truths, dependent origination. Ethics: Karma, ahimsa. Life meaning: Awakening from illusion. Afterlife: Samsara rebirth, nirvana end. Debates: Emptiness (shunyata).

## Key Thinkers
Buddha, Nagarjuna (Madhyamaka), Asanga (Yogacara).

## Influence
Psychology, ethics, meditation.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Buddha Statue](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_(Dhammajak_Mutra).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, ancient artifact)

## Related Religions
See [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [zen-variants-chan-buddhism.md](/philosophies/zen-variants-chan-buddhism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Buddhist Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/buddha/)
[^2]: Britannica - Buddhist Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Buddhist-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Buddhism[](https://iep.utm.edu/buddha/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Buddhist Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddhist_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Buddhist Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260493)
buddhist-philosophy-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Buddhist Philosophy

## Introduction
Buddhist Philosophy delves into suffering's causes, cessation. Branch: Eastern. Historical context: Siddhartha Gautama (Buddha) 5th BCE, evolving schools. Cultures: India, Tibet, Japan, Southeast Asia.

## Branches
Theravada (Hinayana), Mahayana (Zen, Pure Land), Vajrayana (Tantra).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dukkha (suffering), anicca (impermanence), anatta (no-self). Ethics: Sila (morality), karuna (compassion). Life meaning: Path to nirvana. Afterlife: Rebirth wheel until enlightenment. Debates: Realism vs. idealism, Theravada conservatism vs. Mahayana expansiveness.

## Key Thinkers
Buddha (sutras), Nagarjuna (emptiness), Dharmakirti (epistemology), Dogen (Zen).

## Influence
Western mindfulness, existentialism, neuroscience.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Buddha Statue](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Buddha_in_Sarnath_Museum_(Dhammajak_Mutra).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, ancient artifact)

## Related Religions
See [buddhism.md](/religions/buddhism.md), [tibetan-buddhism-variants-bon-influence.md](/philosophies/tibetan-buddhism-variants-bon-influence.md).

## Sources

text# Cambridge Platonists

## Introduction
Cambridge Platonists are 17th-century rational theologians blending Plato and Christianity. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: English Enlightenment.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rational virtue. Life meaning: Divine reason. Afterlife: Immortal soul.

## Key Thinkers
Ralph Cudworth, Henry More.

## Influence
Rational religion, idealism.

capitalism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Capitalism

## Introduction
Capitalism is a political-economic philosophy of free markets, private ownership. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Industrial Revolution.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual pursuit, profit. Life meaning: Economic freedom. Afterlife: Secular.

## Key Thinkers
Adam Smith, Milton Friedman, Ayn Rand.

## Influence
Global economy, liberalism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Adam Smith Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AdamSmith.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [liberalism.md](/philosophies/liberalism.md).

[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Capitalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/capitalism/)

capitalism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Capitalism

## Introduction
Capitalism advocates market-driven production, private property. Branch: Political. Historical context: 18th-century Enlightenment, Smith’s Wealth of Nations. Cultures: Western, globalized.

## Branches
Laissez-faire, welfare capitalism, state capitalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Invisible hand, supply-demand. Ethics: Self-interest benefits all. Life meaning: Innovation, wealth. Afterlife: Not addressed. Debates: Inequality vs. efficiency.

## Key Thinkers
Adam Smith, Friedrich Hayek, Karl Marx (critic).

## Influence
Industrialization, globalization.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Adam Smith Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AdamSmith.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [liberalism.md](/philosophies/liberalism.md), [neoliberalism.md](/philosophies/neoliberalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Capitalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/capitalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Capitalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/capitalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Capitalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitalism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Capitalist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260494)
capitalism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Capitalism

## Introduction
Capitalism is economic system based on private ownership, market competition. Branch: Political. Historical context: Mercantilism to Smith (1776), industrial expansion. Cultures: Europe, US, Asia.

## Branches
Classical, Keynesian, neoliberal.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Profit motive, capital accumulation. Ethics: Rand’s objectivism vs. socialist critiques. Life meaning: Opportunity, entrepreneurship. Afterlife: Materialist. Debates: Free market vs. regulation, Marx’s alienation.

## Key Thinkers
Smith (invisible hand), Friedman (monetarism), Rand (objectivism).

## Influence
Wealth creation, inequality debates.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Adam Smith Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AdamSmith.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [liberalism.md](/philosophies/liberalism.md), [neoliberalism.md](/philosophies/neoliberalism.md), [communism.md](/philosophies/communism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Capitalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/capitalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Capitalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/capitalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Capitalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capitalism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Capitalist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260494)
[^6]: IEP - Smith[](https://iep.utm.edu/smith/)

text# Carlyleanism

## Introduction
Carlyleanism is a social philosophy emphasizing hero worship and strong leadership. Branch: Social. Cultural context: 19th-century Britain.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Admiration for great individuals. Life meaning: Guided by heroes. Afterlife: Not central.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Carlyle (On Heroes, Hero-Worship).

## Influence
Victorian thought, authoritarianism.

## Related Religions
See [authoritarianism.md](/philosophies/authoritarianism.md).

## Sources

Carolingian Renaissance is a historical revival of classical learning under Charlemagne. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: 8th-9th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas

Alcuin of York, Charlemagne.

cartesianism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Cartesianism

## Introduction
Cartesianism is metaphysics of doubt to certainty, mind-body dualism. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 17th-century France.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rational clarity. Life meaning: Cogito ergo sum. Afterlife: Immortal soul.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes (Meditations).

## Influence
Modern philosophy, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [mind-body-dualism.md](/philosophies/mind-body-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Descartes[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/descartes/)
[^2]: Britannica - Cartesianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cartesianism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Cartesianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesianism)
cartesianism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Cartesianism

## Introduction
Cartesianism emphasizes methodical doubt, dualism. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: 17th-century Europe, scientific revolution. Cultures: French, Western rationalism.

## Branches
Epistemology (doubt), ontology (dualism).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Cogito foundation. Ethics: Clear ideas. Life meaning: Rational self. Afterlife: Soul separate from body. Debates: Interactionism.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Spinoza (critic).

## Influence
Enlightenment, dualism debates.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [mind-body-dualism.md](/philosophies/mind-body-dualism.md), [rationalism.md](/philosophies/rationalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Descartes[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/descartes/)
[^2]: Britannica - Cartesianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Cartesianism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Descartes[](https://iep.utm.edu/descarte/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Cartesianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cartesianism)

text# Categorical Imperative

## Introduction
Categorical Imperative is Kant’s universal moral law. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 18th-century Germany.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Duty universalized. Life meaning: Rational morality. Afterlife: Postulates immortality.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant (Groundwork).

## Influence
Deontology, rights.

## View Illustrative Image

categorical-imperative-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Categorical Imperative

## Introduction
Categorical Imperative commands unconditionally. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Kant’s 1785 Groundwork. Cultures: German Enlightenment, global ethics.

## Branches
Formulations (universal law, humanity as end).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Act if maxim universal. Ethics: Deontological. Life meaning: Moral autonomy. Afterlife: Necessary postulate. Debates: Rigidity vs. consequences.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Hegel (critic).

## Influence
Human rights, law.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md), [deontology.md](/philosophies/kantian-deontology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant’s Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)
[^2]: Britannica - Categorical Imperative[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/categorical-imperative)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant[](https://iep.utm.edu/kantmeta/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Categorical Imperative[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorical_imperative)
[^5]: JSTOR - Kantian Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260496)
categorical-imperative-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Categorical Imperative

## Introduction
Categorical Imperative is Kant’s absolute moral command. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 1780s Prussia, Critique of Practical Reason. Cultures: European rationalism, universal ethics.

## Branches
First (universal law), second (humanity end), third (kingdom of ends).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Hypothetical vs. categorical. Ethics: Duty over inclination. Life meaning: Moral legislation. Afterlife: Immortality for justice. Debates: Absolutism vs. relativism, application to lies/torture.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Schopenhauer (critic), Rawls (veil).

## Influence
UN rights, bioethics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md), [deontology.md](/philosophies/kantian-deontology.md), [moral-absolutism.md](/philosophies/moral-absolutism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant’s Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)
[^2]: Britannica - Categorical Imperative[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/categorical-imperative)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant[](https://iep.utm.edu/kantmeta/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Categorical Imperative[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorical_imperative)
[^5]: JSTOR - Kantian Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260496)
[^6]: IEP - Deontology[](https://iep.utm.edu/deon/)

Philosophy of Chance examines randomness in reality. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Modern probability.

## Key Ideas

## Key Thinkers

## Influence
Statistics, quantum.

text# Charvaka

## Introduction
Charvaka is ancient Indian materialism denying afterlife. Branch: Ancient. Cultural context: Vedic period India.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Sense pleasure. Life meaning: Empirical enjoyment. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Brihaspati (attributed).

Indian skepticism, hedonism.

christian-existentialism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Christian Existentialism

## Introduction
Christian Existentialism emphasizes faith as personal choice in absurd world. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Kierkegaard 1840s, post-WWII theology. Cultures: European, American.

## Branches
Kierkegaardian (leap), Bultmannian (demythologizing).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Authentic existence via Christ. Ethics: Paradoxical faith. Life meaning: Relation to God. Afterlife: Eternal through choice. Debates: Faith vs. reason.

## Key Thinkers
Kierkegaard, Bultmann, Tillich.

## Influence
Liberation theology, postmodern faith.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Søren Kierkegaard Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard_(1813-1855)_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [christian-philosophy.md](/philosophies/christian-philosophy.md), [existentialism.md](/philosophies/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Existentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/existentialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Christian Existentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Christian-existentialism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kierkegaard[](https://iep.utm.edu/kierkega/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Christian Existentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_existentialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Christian Existentialism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260497)

text# Christian Humanism

## Introduction
Christian Humanism integrates Renaissance humanism with Christian faith, emphasizing human dignity. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: 15th-16th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Dignity from God, virtuous life. Life meaning: Divine-human partnership. Afterlife: Eternal union.

## Key Thinkers
Erasmus of Rotterdam, Thomas More.

## Influence
Reformation, education.

## Related Religions
See [humanism.md](/philosophies/humanism.md), [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md).

text# Christian Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Christian Neoplatonism fuses Neoplatonism with Christian theology. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Late antiquity.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Soul ascent to God. Life meaning: Divine emanation. Afterlife: Union with the One.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus (Neoplatonic source), Pseudo-Dionysius, Augustine.

## Influence
Mystical theology, scholasticism.

## Related Religions
See [neoplatonism.md](/philosophies/neoplatonism.md), [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md).

christian-philosophy-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Christian Philosophy

## Introduction
Christian Philosophy synthesizes biblical revelation with philosophical reason. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 2nd-century apologetics to medieval scholasticism. Cultures: European, global Christianity.

## Branches
Patristic (Augustine), medieval (Aquinas), modern (Kierkegaard).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Faith seeking understanding (Anselm). Ethics: Virtues, natural law. Life meaning: Created for God. Afterlife: Judgment, salvation. Debates: Grace vs. works.

## Key Thinkers
Augustine (City of God), Aquinas (Summa), Kierkegaard (fear/trembling).

## Influence
Ethics, metaphysics, existentialism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Thomas Aquinas Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Thomas_Aquinas,_by_Caravaggio.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md), [thomism.md](/philosophies/thomism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Christian Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/christiantheology-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Christian Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Christian-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Christian Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/christph/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Christian Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Christian Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260498)
christian-philosophy-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Christian Philosophy

## Introduction
Christian Philosophy unites faith and reason in exploring existence. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 1st-century apostolic fathers to 20th-century phenomenology. Cultures: Mediterranean to global.

## Branches
Apologetics, scholasticism, existential theology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Logos (reason in Christ). Ethics: Agape love, justice. Life meaning: Telos in God. Afterlife: Resurrection. Debates: Fideism vs. rationalism, original sin.

## Key Thinkers
Augustine (confessions), Aquinas (five ways), Descartes (meditations), Kierkegaard (knight of faith).

## Influence
Law, science, ethics; critiques from postmodernism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Thomas Aquinas Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Thomas_Aquinas,_by_Caravaggio.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [christianity.md](/religions/christianity.md), [thomism.md](/philosophies/thomism.md), [existentialism.md](/philosophies/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Christian Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/christiantheology-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Christian Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Christian-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Christian Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/christph/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Christian Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christian_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Christian Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260498)
[^6]: IEP - Augustine[](https://iep.utm.edu/augustine/)
chinese-philosophy.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Chinese Philosophy

## Introduction
Chinese Philosophy emphasizes harmony, dao, ethics. Branch: Eastern. Cultural context: Zhou dynasty onward.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Ren, li. Life meaning: Balance with nature. Afterlife: Ancestral spirits.

## Key Thinkers
Confucius, Laozi, Zhuangzi.

## Influence
East Asian culture, governance.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Confucius Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Confucius_(Confucius_K%C3%B6nig).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

chinese-philosophy-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Chinese Philosophy

## Introduction
Chinese Philosophy centers relational ethics, cosmic harmony. Branch: Eastern. Historical context: Warring States (Confucius 551 BCE). Cultures: China, East Asia.

## Branches
Confucianism, Daoism, Legalism, Mohism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Tian (heaven) mandate. Ethics: Filial piety, wu wei. Life meaning: Social harmony. Afterlife: Ancestor veneration. Debates: Human nature (Mencius vs. Xunzi).

## Key Thinkers
Confucius (Analects), Laozi (Dao De Jing), Mozi (universal love).

## Influence
Bureaucracy, martial arts, modern ethics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Confucius Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Confucius_(Confucius_K%C3%B6nig).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md), [daoism-variants-philosophical-daoism.md](/philosophies/daoism-variants-philosophical-daoism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Chinese Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/chinese-phil/)
[^2]: Britannica - Chinese Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Chinese-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Chinese Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/chinese-phil/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Chinese Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Chinese Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260499)
chinese-philosophy-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Chinese Philosophy

## Introduction
Chinese Philosophy explores human-nature-society harmony. Branch: Eastern. Historical context: Axial Age, Confucius to Han synthesis. Cultures: Han Chinese, Korean, Japanese.

## Branches
Ru (Confucian), Dao (Daoist), Fa (Legalist), Mo (Mohist).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Yin-yang duality. Ethics: Li (ritual), ren (benevolence). Life meaning: Dao following. Afterlife: Spirit continuity. Debates: Heaven's role, ruler's mandate.

## Key Thinkers
Confucius, Laozi, Xunzi, Han Feizi.

## Influence
Imperial exams, martial ethics, global harmony concepts.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Confucius Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Confucius_(Confucius_K%C3%B6nig).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md), [daoism-variants-philosophical-daoism.md](/philosophies/daoism-variants-philosophical-daoism.md), [legalism.md](/philosophies/legalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Chinese Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/chinese-phil/)
[^2]: Britannica - Chinese Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Chinese-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Chinese Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/chinese-phil/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Chinese Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_philosophy)
[^5]: JSTOR - Chinese Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260499)
[^6]: IEP - Confucianism[](https://iep.utm.edu/confucius/)

text# Classical Marxism

## Introduction
Classical Marxism analyzes class struggle, historical materialism. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 19th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Proletarian revolution. Life meaning: Classless society. Afterlife: Materialist, none.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels.

## Influence
Socialism, communism.

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/philosophies/marxism.md).

## Sources

classical-marxism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Classical Marxism

## Introduction
Classical Marxism views history as class conflict leading to communism. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1848 Manifesto, industrial Europe. Cultures: European, global leftist.

## Branches
Dialectical materialism, historical materialism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Base-superstructure. Ethics: Exploitation critique. Life meaning: Revolutionary praxis. Afterlife: Denied. Debates: Determinism vs. agency.

## Key Thinkers
Marx (Das Kapital), Engels (Dialectics).

## Influence
Russian Revolution, labor rights.

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/philosophies/marxism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marx[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marx/)
[^2]: Britannica - Classical Marxism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Marxism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Classical Marxism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_Marxism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Marxist Classics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260500)

cognitivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Cognitivism

## Introduction
Cognitivism holds moral statements express truth-apt propositions. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Objective morals. Life meaning: Truth-seeking. Afterlife: Not central.

## Key Thinkers
R.M. Hare (prescriptivism critic), John Searle.

## Influence
Moral realism debates.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/philosophies/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Cognitivism vs Non-Cognitivism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-cognitivism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Cognitivism (ethics)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitivism_(ethics))
[^3]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)

text# Collegium Conimbricense

## Introduction
Collegium Conimbricense is Jesuit scholastic philosophy school. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: 16th-century Portugal.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Thomistic virtue. Life meaning: Faith-reason harmony. Afterlife: Soul salvation.

## Key Thinkers
Francisco de Toledo, Manuel de São, Benito Pereira.

## Influence
Jesuit education, theology.

## Related Religions
See [thomism.md](/philosophies/thomism.md), [christian-philosophy.md](/philosophies/christian-philosophy.md).

text# Color, Philosophy of

## Introduction
Philosophy of Color examines perception, ontology. Branch: Aesthetics. Cultural context: Modern perception studies.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Subjective experience. Life meaning: Sensory reality. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
John Locke, George Berkeley, Wittgenstein.

## Influence
Cognitive science, art.

text# Common Sense, Philosophy of

## Introduction
Common Sense Philosophy trusts intuitive beliefs. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 18th-century Scotland.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Practical morals. Life meaning: Everyday reason. Afterlife: Intuitive acceptance.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Reid, James Beattie.

Empiricism, realism.

Communism envisions classless, stateless society. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 19th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Collective ownership. Life meaning: Equality. Afterlife: Materialist, none.

communism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Communism

## Introduction
Communism seeks abolition of private property for communal good. Branch: Political. Historical context: Marx/Engels 1848 Manifesto. Cultures: European, Soviet, Chinese.

## Branches
Marxist-Leninist, Maoist, Trotskyist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dictatorship of proletariat to classless society. Ethics: From each according to ability. Life meaning: Historical progress. Afterlife: Denied. Debates: Human nature, implementation.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Lenin, Mao.

## Influence
20th-century revolutions, welfare states.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/philosophies/marxism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Communism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/communism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Communism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/communism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Communism[](https://iep.utm.edu/communism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Communism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Communist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260501)
communism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Communism

## Introduction
Communism aims for stateless, classless society via collective ownership. Branch: Political. Historical context: Utopian socialists to Marx 1848. Cultures: Industrial Europe, global revolutions.

## Branches
Scientific (Marxist), utopian (Owen), Leninist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Surplus value exploitation. Ethics: Solidarity, equality. Life meaning: Dialectical progress. Afterlife: Atheist. Debates: Democracy vs. vanguard, market socialism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx (Das Kapital), Engels, Lenin (state withering), Trotsky.

## Influence
Cold War, social democracy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/philosophies/marxism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md), [socialism.md](/philosophies/socialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Communism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/communism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Communism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/communism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Communism[](https://iep.utm.edu/communism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Communism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Communist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260501)
[^6]: IEP - Marx[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/)
communitarianism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Communitarianism

## Introduction
Communitarianism emphasizes community over individual rights. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Late 20th-century liberalism critique.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Social responsibilities. Life meaning: Community bonds. Afterlife: Not central.

## Key Thinkers
Amitai Etzioni, Michael Sandel, Charles Taylor.

## Influence
Social policy, multiculturalism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Amitai Etzioni Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Amitai_Etzioni.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2010)

## Related Religions

communitarianism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Communitarianism

## Introduction
Communitarianism prioritizes community values. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1980s response to liberalism. Cultures: Western, multicultural.

## Branches
Political (Etzioni), philosophical (Sandel).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Rights with responsibilities. Ethics: Common good. Life meaning: Shared identity. Afterlife: Secular. Debates: Individual vs. group.

## Key Thinkers
Etzioni (responsive community), Sandel (justice), Taylor (recognition).

## Influence
Third Way politics, civil society.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Amitai Etzioni Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Amitai_Etzioni.jpg) (CC-BY-SA, Wikimedia Commons, 2010)

## Related Religions
See [socialism.md](/philosophies/socialism.md), [liberalism.md](/philosophies/libertarianism.md).

## Sources

compatibilism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Compatibilism

## Introduction
Compatibilism reconciles free will with determinism. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Enlightenment philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral responsibility possible. Life meaning: Determined freedom. Afterlife: Compatible if exists.

## Key Thinkers
David Hume, Daniel Dennett.

## Influence
Philosophy of mind, ethics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View David Hume Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:David_Hume.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [free-will.md](/philosophies/free-will.md).

## Sources

compatibilism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Compatibilism

## Introduction
Compatibilism argues free will and determinism coexist. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Hume 1748, modern neuroscience. Cultures: Western philosophy.

## Branches
Classical (Hume), contemporary (Dennett).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Free will as uncoerced action. Ethics: Determinism doesn't negate responsibility. Life meaning: Agency in causal chain. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Libertarianism critique.

## Key Thinkers
Hume, Hobbes, Dennett.

## Influence
Law, psychology.

## View Illustrative Image
[View David Hume Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:David_Hume.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [free-will.md](/philosophies/free-will.md), [determinism.md](/philosophies/strong-determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Compatibilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/compatibilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Free Will[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/free-will)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Free Will[](https://iep.utm.edu/freewill/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Compatibilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compatibilism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Compatibilist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260503)

text# Computationalism

## Introduction
Computationalism views the mind as a computational process, akin to software on hardware. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 20th-century AI and cognitive science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Algorithmic decision-making. Life meaning: Computable existence. Afterlife: Possible simulation.

## Key Thinkers
Hilary Putnam, Alan Turing.

## Influence
AI, philosophy of mind.

## Related Religions
See [transhumanism.md](/religions/transhumanism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Computational Theory of Mind[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/computational-mind/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Computationalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_theory_of_mind)
[^3]: Britannica - Philosophy of Mind[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-mind)
conceptu.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Conceptu

## Introduction
Conceptu is historical conceptualism, viewing universals as mental concepts. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: Medieval philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Conceptual morality. Life meaning: Abstract understanding. Afterlife: Not focused.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Abelard, William of Ockham (related).

## Influence
Nominalism debates.

## Related Religions
See [nominalism.md](/philosophies/nominalism.md).

connectionism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Connectionism

## Introduction
Connectionism models mind as neural networks, emphasizing connections. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 1980s AI.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Distributed responsibility. Life meaning: Networked learning. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
David Rumelhart, Geoffrey Hinton.

Deep learning, neuroscience.
