consequentialism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Consequentialism

## Introduction
Consequentialism judges actions by outcomes, not intentions. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Utilitarian tradition.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Maximize good consequences. Life meaning: Utility optimization. Afterlife: Outcome-based if exists.

## Key Thinkers
Jeremy Bentham, John Stuart Mill.

## Influence
Policy, utilitarianism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Jeremy Bentham Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jeremy_Bentham_by_Henry_William_Pickersgill.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Consequentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/consequentialism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Consequentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequentialism)
consequentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Consequentialism

## Introduction
Consequentialism evaluates actions by effects. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 18th-century utilitarianism. Cultures: Western, global policy.

## Branches
Act, rule, negative consequentialism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Rightness by net good. Ethics: Impartial maximization. Life meaning: Beneficial outcomes. Afterlife: Evaluated by impact. Debates: Intention neglect.

## Key Thinkers
Bentham (quantitative), Mill (qualitative), Sidgwick.

## Influence
Economics, law.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Jeremy Bentham Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jeremy_Bentham_by_Henry_William_Pickersgill.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md), [effective-altruism.md](/philosophies/effective-altruism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Consequentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/consequentialism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/conseque/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Consequentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequentialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Consequentialist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260504)
consequentialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Consequentialism

## Introduction
Consequentialism bases morality on consequences. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Bentham 1789, Mill 1861. Cultures: Anglo-American, global ethics.

## Branches
Utilitarianism, egoistic, state consequentialism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Maximize utility. Ethics: Aggregate welfare. Life meaning: Optimal results. Afterlife: If consequential. Debates: Rights vs. outcomes, trolley problem.

## Key Thinkers
Bentham, Mill, Moore (ideal).

## Influence
Public policy, animal rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Jeremy Bentham Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jeremy_Bentham_by_Henry_William_Pickersgill.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md), [effective-altruism.md](/philosophies/effective-altruism.md), [negative-utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/negative-utilitarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Consequentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/consequentialism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/conseque/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Consequentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consequentialism)

text# Conservatism

## Introduction
Conservatism preserves institutions, traditions. Branch: Political. Historical context: Burke 1790 Reflections. Cultures: Anglo-American, European.

## Branches
Cultural, fiscal, social conservatism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Organic society. Ethics: Duty to past. Life meaning: Continuity. Afterlife: Religious. Debates: Reactionary vs. reform.

## Key Thinkers
Burke, de Maistre, Kirk.

## Influence

constructivist-epistemology-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Constructivist Epistemology

## Introduction
Constructivist Epistemology argues knowledge is built socially/cognitively. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Piaget 1930s, Vygotsky. Cultures: Western education.

## Branches
Cognitive, social constructivism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Reality shaped by experience. Ethics: Plural truths. Life meaning: Constructed narratives. Afterlife: Cultural. Debates: Relativism.

## Key Thinkers
Piaget, Vygotsky, Berger/Luckmann.

## Influence
Pedagogy, postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [social-constructivism.md](/philosophies/social-constructivism.md), [postmodernism.md](/philosophies/postmodernism.md).

text# Critical Rationalism

## Introduction
Critical Rationalism emphasizes falsification over verification in knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 20th-century philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Open criticism. Life meaning: Progressive inquiry. Afterlife: Unfalsifiable, agnostic.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper (falsificationism).

## Influence
Scientific method, liberalism.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Critical Rationalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/popper/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Critical Rationalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_rationalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Karl Popper[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Karl-Popper)
critical-realism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Critical Realism

## Introduction
Critical Realism posits reality independent but knowable via layered structures. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 20th-century social science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Emancipatory critique. Life meaning: Stratified existence. Afterlife: Possible transcendental.

## Key Thinkers
Roy Bhaskar.

## Influence
Social theory, theology.

## Related Religions

text# Deism

## Introduction
Deism views God as non-intervening creator. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 17th-18th century, Locke/Newton. Cultures: European, American.

## Branches
Classical, pandeism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Clockwork universe. Ethics: Universal reason. Life meaning: Moral autonomy. Afterlife: Possible, unknowable. Debates: Atheism boundary.

## Key Thinkers
Voltaire, Paine, Franklin.

## Influence
Deist founders, secular humanism.

## Related Religions
See [deism.md](/religions/deism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

Divine Command Theory derives morality from God's commands. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Abrahamic theology.

divine-command-theory-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Divine Command Theory

## Introduction
Divine Command Theory ties good to God's will. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Medieval theology. Cultures: Abrahamic.

## Branches
Strong (good because commanded), weak (commanded because good).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Euthyphro dilemma. Ethics: Theistic morality. Life meaning: Divine obedience. Afterlife: Reward/punishment. Debates: Arbitrariness.

## Key Thinkers
Ockham, Aquinas (modified).

## Influence
Theodicy, moral realism.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/philosophies/theism.md), [divine-command-deontology.md](/philosophies/divine-command-deontology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Divine Command Theory[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/divine-command/)
[^2]: Britannica - Divine Command Theory[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/divine-command-theory)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Divine Command Theory[](https://iep.utm.edu/divine-c/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Divine Command Theory[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Divine_command_theory)
[^5]: JSTOR - Divine Command Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260508)

text# Egoism

## Introduction
Egoism prioritizes self-interest in ethics. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Enlightenment individualism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rational self-benefit. Life meaning: Personal fulfillment. Afterlife: Self-focused if exists.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Hobbes, Ayn Rand, Max Stirner.

## Influence
Libertarianism, psychology.

## Related Religions
See [objectivism.md](/philosophies/objectivism.md).

## Sources

egoism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Egoism

## Introduction
Egoism sees self-interest as moral basis. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Hobbes 1651 Leviathan. Cultures: Western, individualistic societies.

## Branches
Psychological (motivated by self), ethical (ought to self), rational (reason serves self).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Maximize own good. Ethics: Benevolence as enlightened self. Life meaning: Achievement. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Altruism compatibility.

## Key Thinkers
Hobbes (state of nature), Rand (objectivism), Stirner (unique one).

## Influence
Capitalism, self-help.

## Related Religions
See [objectivism.md](/philosophies/objectivism.md), [altruism-ethics.md](/philosophies/altruism-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Egoism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/egoism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Egoism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/egoism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Ethical Egoism[](https://iep.utm.edu/egoism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Egoism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egoism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Egoist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260509)

text# Eliminative Materialism

## Introduction
Eliminative Materialism denies folk psychology concepts, reducing mind to brain. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 20th-century neuroscience.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Neuro-based morals. Life meaning: Physical processes. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Paul Churchland, Patricia Churchland.

## Influence
Cognitive science.

## Related Religions

text# Empiricism

## Introduction
Empiricism holds knowledge from sensory experience. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 17th-century Britain.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Experience-based morals. Life meaning: Observational learning. Afterlife: Empirical doubt.

## Key Thinkers
John Locke, David Hume, George Berkeley.

## Influence
Science, liberalism.

## View Illustrative Image

## Related Religions

empiricism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Empiricism

## Introduction
Empiricism prioritizes sensory evidence for knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Locke 1690 Essay. Cultures: British, Enlightenment.

## Branches
British (Locke), radical (Hume), phenomenalist (Berkeley).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Tabula rasa mind. Ethics: Habitual morals. Life meaning: Experience accumulation. Afterlife: Unobserved, doubtful. Debates: Innate ideas.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Hume, Berkeley.

## Influence
Experimental science, psychology.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Locke Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Locke.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [empiricism.md](/religions/empiricism.md), [logical-positivism.md](/philosophies/logical-positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/rationalism-empiricism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Empiricism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/empiricism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Empiricism[](https://iep.utm.edu/empiric/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Empiricism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empiricism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Empiricist Epistemology[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260510)
empiricism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Empiricism

## Introduction
Empiricism asserts knowledge originates in experience. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Bacon 1620 Novum Organum, Locke vs. Descartes. Cultures: Anglo-European, scientific revolution.

## Branches
Classical (Locke), skeptical (Hume), idealist (Berkeley).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ideas from sensations/reflections. Ethics: Custom-based. Life meaning: Empirical truth. Afterlife: No evidence, probable none. Debates: Rationalism, induction problem (Hume).

## Key Thinkers
Bacon (induction), Locke (primary/secondary qualities), Hume (impressions), Berkeley (esse est percipi).

## Influence
Scientific method, positivism; critiqued for underestimating reason.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Locke Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Locke.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [empiricism.md](/religions/empiricism.md), [logical-positivism.md](/philosophies/logical-positivism.md), [bayesianism.md](/philosophies/bayesianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/rationalism-empiricism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Empiricism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/empiricism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Empiricism[](https://iep.utm.edu/empiric/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Empiricism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empiricism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Empiricist Epistemology[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260510)
[^6]: IEP - Hume[](https://iep.utm.edu/hume/)
epiphenomenalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Epiphenomenalism

## Introduction
Epiphenomenalism views mental states as brain by-products, causally ineffective. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 19th-century psychology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Behavior determined. Life meaning: Physical causes. Afterlife: No mental survival.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Huxley, Frank Jackson.

## Influence
Neuroscience, determinism.

## Related Religions
See [determinism.md](/philosophies/strong-determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Epiphenomenalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/epiphenomenalism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Epiphenomenalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epiphenomenalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Philosophy of Mind[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-mind)

text# Epistemological Nihilism

## Introduction
Epistemological Nihilism denies the possibility of knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Ancient skepticism, postmodern critiques.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Skeptical action. Life meaning: Uncertain existence. Afterlife: Unknowable.

## Key Thinkers
Gorgias (ancient), Friedrich Nietzsche (influence).

## Influence
Radical skepticism, relativism.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Epistemological Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/skepticism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Epistemological Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemological_nihilism)
[^3]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
epistemology.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Epistemology

## Introduction
Epistemology studies knowledge, justification, belief. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Ancient Greece to modern.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Intellectual virtue. Life meaning: Pursuit of truth. Afterlife: Epistemic questions.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Gettier.

## Influence
Science, philosophy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [skepticism.md](/philosophies/skepticism.md).

## Sources

epistemology-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Epistemology

## Introduction
Epistemology examines nature of knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Plato's Theaetetus. Cultures: Western, global.

## Branches
Foundationalism, coherentism, reliabilism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: JTB definition. Ethics: Epistemic responsibility. Life meaning: Justified beliefs. Afterlife: Skeptical. Debates: Gettier problems.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Hume, Quine.

## Influence
AI, education.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [skepticism.md](/philosophies/skepticism.md), [rationalism.md](/philosophies/rationalism.md).

## Sources

epistemology-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Epistemology

## Introduction
Epistemology probes knowledge sources. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Socratic questions. Cultures: Global.

## Branches
Traditional, social, virtue epistemology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Justification theories. Ethics: Doxastic duties. Life meaning: Truth-seeking. Afterlife: Epistemic warrant. Debates: Internalism/externalism.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (knowledge definition), Descartes (doubt), Kant (a priori), Gettier.

## Influence
Logic, AI.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [skepticism.md](/philosophies/skepticism.md), [rationalism.md](/philosophies/rationalism.md), [empiricism.md](/philosophies/empiricism.md).

## Sources

text# Eternalism

## Introduction
Eternalism holds all times equally real. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Philosophy of time.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Timeless morality. Life meaning: Eternal existence. Afterlife: All moments coexist.

## Key Thinkers
J.M.E. McTaggart, David Lewis.

## Influence
Physics, relativism.

## Related Religions

text# Eudaimonism

## Introduction
Eudaimonism equates good life with flourishing. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Aristotle Nicomachean Ethics. Cultures: Greek, Western virtue.

## Branches
Aristotelian, Stoic.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Eudaimonia as end. Ethics: Character virtues. Life meaning: Active virtue. Afterlife: Secondary. Debates: Hedonism vs. virtue.

## Key Thinkers
Aristotle, Epicurus (variant).

## Influence
Positive psychology.

## Related Religions
See [aristotelian-virtue-ethics.md](/philosophies/aristotelian-virtue-ethics.md), [stoic-virtue-ethics.md](/philosophies/stoic-virtue-ethics.md).

text# Existentialism

## Introduction
Existentialism stresses individual freedom, meaning creation. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-20th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Authentic choice. Life meaning: Self-defined. Afterlife: Absent or uncertain.

## Key Thinkers
Søren Kierkegaard, Jean-Paul Sartre, Martin Heidegger.

## Influence
Literature, psychology.

existentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Existentialism

## Introduction
Existentialism focuses on human existence, freedom. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Kierkegaard 1840s, post-WWII Sartre. Cultures: European, global.

## Branches
Theistic (Kierkegaard), atheistic (Sartre), phenomenological (Heidegger).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Absurdity, angst. Ethics: Responsibility. Life meaning: Create own. Afterlife: Leap or none. Debates: Subjectivity vs. objectivism.

## Key Thinkers
Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Sartre, Camus.

## Influence
Therapy, art.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Jean-Paul Sartre Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, 1967)

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md), [christian-existentialism.md](/philosophies/christian-existentialism.md).

existentialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Existentialism

## Introduction
Existentialism explores freedom, authenticity. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: 19th-century Kierkegaard to 20th-century Sartre. Cultures: European, American literature.

## Branches
Religious, atheist, phenomenological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Being-for-itself. Ethics: Bad faith avoidance. Life meaning: Absurd rebellion. Afterlife: Faith leap or void. Debates: Essences precede existence?

## Key Thinkers
Kierkegaard (stages), Heidegger (Dasein), Sartre (nothingness), Camus (absurd).

## Influence
Feminism, postcolonialism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Jean-Paul Sartre Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Jean-Paul_Sartre_FP.JPG) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, 1967)

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md), [christian-existentialism.md](/philosophies/christian-existentialism.md), [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Existentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/existentialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Existentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/existentialism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Existentialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/existent/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Existentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existentialism)

[^6]: IEP - Sartre[](https://iep.utm.edu/sartre-ex/)

text# Explicit Atheism

## Introduction
Explicit Atheism positively denies gods. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 18th-century Enlightenment. Cultures: Western secular.

## Branches
Strong atheism, new atheism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Burden of proof on theists. Ethics: Secular morals. Life meaning: Scientific pursuit. Afterlife: Cessation. Debates: Implicit vs. explicit.

## Key Thinkers
Dawkins, Harris, Hitchens.

## Influence
Science advocacy.

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md), [anti-theism.md](/philosophies/anti-theism.md).

externalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Externalism

## Introduction
Externalism holds justification factors outside mind. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 20th-century knowledge theory.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Social knowledge. Life meaning: Environmental truth. Afterlife: External warrant.

## Key Thinkers
Alvin Goldman, Fred Dretske.

## Influence
Social epistemology.

## Related Religions
See [reliabilism.md](/philosophies/reliabilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Internalism and Externalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-intext/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Epistemic Externalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internalism_and_externalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Epistemology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/epistemology)

Tiering: Low (Familialism, Fallibilism, Fideism, Formalism: 1 tier ~300-400 words), High (Feminist Philosophy, Free Will: 3 tiers each, ~1500 large with debates/history), Medium (Foundationalism: 2 tiers ~800 medium). text# Familialism

## Introduction
Familialism prioritizes family as core social unit. Branch: Social. Cultural context: Traditional societies, conservatism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Family loyalty. Life meaning: Kinship bonds. Afterlife: Ancestral continuity.

## Key Thinkers
Aristotle (oikos), modern conservatives like Allan Carlson.

## Influence
Family policy, sociology.

## Related Religions
See [confucianism.md](/religions/confucianism.md).

text# Fallibilism

## Introduction
Fallibilism holds knowledge tentative, open to revision. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Pragmatism, Popper.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Humble inquiry. Life meaning: Provisional truths. Afterlife: Tentative.

## Key Thinkers
Charles Peirce, Karl Popper.

## Influence
Scientific method, education.

text# Feminist Philosophy

## Introduction
Feminist Philosophy critiques gender oppression, seeks equality. Branch: Social. Cultural context: 20th-century waves.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Care, intersectionality. Life meaning: Liberated existence. Afterlife: Inclusive or irrelevant.

## Key Thinkers
Simone de Beauvoir, bell hooks, Judith Butler.

## Influence
Gender studies, activism.

text# Feminist Philosophy

## Introduction
Feminist Philosophy analyzes gender power dynamics. Branch: Social. Historical context: 19th-century suffrage, 20th waves. Cultures: Global, Western origins.

## Branches
Liberal, radical, postcolonial feminism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Patriarchy critique. Ethics: Intersectional justice. Life meaning: Agency, equality. Afterlife: Reimagined inclusive. Debates: Essentialism vs. construction.

## Key Thinkers
de Beauvoir (other), Wollstonecraft, Crenshaw (intersectionality).

## Influence
Law, education.

## View Illustrative Image

feminist-philosophy-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Feminist Philosophy

## Introduction
Feminist Philosophy interrogates gender as social construct. Branch: Social. Historical context: Wollstonecraft 1792, Beauvoir 1949. Cultures: Western, global south.

## Branches
Liberal (equality), radical (patriarchy), postmodern (performativity).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Standpoint theory. Ethics: Care ethics. Life meaning: Resistance, empowerment. Afterlife: Critiqued as male. Debates: Trans inclusion, universalism.

## Key Thinkers
Wollstonecraft, de Beauvoir, Butler, Irigaray.

## Influence
#MeToo, gender policy.

## View Illustrative Image

text# Formalism

## Introduction
Formalism emphasizes form over content in art/ethics. Branch: Aesthetics. Cultural context: Early 20th-century art.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rule adherence. Life meaning: Structured beauty. Afterlife: Formal.

## Key Thinkers
Roger Fry, Clive Bell (art), Kant (ethics).

## Influence
Modern art, legal theory.

## Related Religions

text# Foundationalism

## Introduction
Foundationalism posits basic beliefs justify others. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Descartes to modern.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Foundational morals. Life meaning: Secure knowledge. Afterlife: Basic faith.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Chisholm.

## Influence
Coherentism debates.

foundationalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Foundationalism

## Introduction
Foundationalism builds knowledge on self-evident basics. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Descartes 1637 Discourse. Cultures: Western rationalism.

## Branches
Strong (infallible basics), weak (probable).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Pyramid structure. Ethics: Foundational duties. Life meaning: Stable beliefs. Afterlife: Basic axioms. Debates: Infinite regress.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Locke, Plantinga.

## Influence
Evidentialism, reformed epistemology.

## Related Religions
See [epistemology.md](/philosophies/epistemology.md), [coherentism.md](/philosophies/coherentism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Foundationalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-foundational/)
[^2]: Britannica - Epistemology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/epistemology)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Foundationalism[](https://iep.utm.edu/foundationalism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Foundationalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundationalism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Foundationalist Epistemology[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260516)

text# Free Will

## Introduction
Free Will is capacity for uncoerced choice. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to modern.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral responsibility. Life meaning: Agency. Afterlife: Free salvation.

## Key Thinkers
Augustine, Kant, Dennett.

## Influence
Law, theology.

free-will-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Free Will

## Introduction
Free Will enables undetermined action. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Augustine vs. Pelagius. Cultures: Western, global ethics.

## Branches
Libertarian, compatibilist, hard determinism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Contra-causal choice. Ethics: Accountability. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Free judgment. Debates: Illusion or real.

## Key Thinkers
Augustine, Descartes, Sartre.

## Influence
Criminal justice, religion.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [libertarian-free-will.md](/philosophies/libertarian-free-will.md), [compatibilism.md](/philosophies/compatibilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Free Will[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/freewill/)
[^2]: Britannica - Free Will[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/free-will)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Free Will[](https://iep.utm.edu/freewill/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Free Will[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_will)
[^5]: JSTOR - Free Will Debates[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260517)
free-will-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Free Will

## Introduction
Free Will is ability to choose independently. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Epicurus swerve to neuroscience. Cultures: Universal, Abrahamic emphasis.

## Branches
Libertarian (indeterminism), compatibilist (determinism), incompatibilist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Agent causation. Ethics: Praise/blame. Life meaning: Authenticity. Afterlife: Free salvation. Debates: Quantum randomness, Libet experiments.

## Key Thinkers
Augustine (grace), Kant (noumenal), Dennett (compatibilist).

## Influence
Law, theology, neuroscience.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [libertarian-free-will.md](/philosophies/libertarian-free-will.md), [compatibilism.md](/philosophies/compatibilism.md), [theological-determinism.md](/philosophies/theological-determinism.md).

## Sources

functionalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Functionalism

## Introduction
Functionalism views mind as functional states, independent of material. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 20th-century philosophy of mind.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Functional roles in society. Life meaning: Role fulfillment. Afterlife: Functional continuity if possible.

## Key Thinkers
Hilary Putnam, Daniel Dennett.

## Influence
Cognitive science, AI.

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Functionalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/functionalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Mind[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-mind)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Functionalism (philosophy of mind)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functionalism_(philosophy_of_mind))
functionalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Functionalism

## Introduction
Functionalism defines mental states by input-output functions. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Putnam 1967. Cultures: Anglo-American philosophy.

## Branches
Machine, analytic functionalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Multiple realizability. Ethics: Social functions. Life meaning: Adaptive roles. Afterlife: Functional simulation. Debates: Chinese room.

## Key Thinkers
Putnam, Fodor, Block.

## Influence
Neuroscience, computation.

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md), [computationalism.md](/philosophies/computationalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Functionalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/functionalism/)

text# Gnosticism

## Introduction
Gnosticism seeks salvation through esoteric knowledge. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Early Christian era.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Reject material world. Life meaning: Spiritual awakening. Afterlife: Escape to pleroma.

## Key Thinkers
Valentinus, Basilides.

## Influence
Mysticism, new age.

text# Gnosticism

## Introduction
Gnosticism emphasizes gnosis for liberation from matter. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 1st-2nd century CE, Alexandria. Cultures: Mediterranean, Near East.

## Branches
Valentinian, Sethian.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Demiurge as flawed creator. Ethics: Ascetic rejection. Life meaning: Divine spark. Afterlife: Pleroma return. Debates: Orthodox heresy.

## Key Thinkers
Valentinus, Irenaeus (critic).

## Influence
Heresiology, esotericism.

## Related Religions
See [gnosticism.md](/religions/gnosticism.md), [neoplatonism.md](/philosophies/neoplatonism.md).

## Sources

text# Hedonism

## Introduction
Hedonism holds pleasure as highest good. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Ancient Greece, modern.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Maximize pleasure. Life meaning: Sensory enjoyment. Afterlife: Pleasurable if exists.

## Key Thinkers
Epicurus, John Stuart Mill.

## Influence
Utilitarianism, lifestyle.

hedonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Hedonism

## Introduction
Hedonism prioritizes pleasure, minimizes pain. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Epicurus 4th BCE. Cultures: Greek, Western utilitarianism.

## Branches
Cyrenaic (immediate pleasure), Epicurean (moderate).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Psychological/ethical hedonism. Ethics: Utility calculation. Life meaning: Balanced enjoyment. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Higher pleasures.

## Key Thinkers
Epicurus, Aristippus, Mill.

## Influence
Psychology, economics.

## Related Religions
See [epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md](/philosophies/epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md), [utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Hedonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hedonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Hedonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/hedonism)

text# Henotheism

Henotheism worships one god while acknowledging others. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Ancient polytheism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Devotion to primary god. Life meaning: Divine favor. Afterlife: God-specific.

## Key Thinkers
Max Müller (term), Vedic thinkers.

Humanism centers human values, reason. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Renaissance to modern.

text# Humanism

## Introduction
Humanism celebrates human potential. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 14th-century Italy. Cultures: European, global secular.

## Branches
Renaissance, secular, religious humanism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ad fontes (back to sources). Ethics: Human rights. Life meaning: Self-actualization. Afterlife: Earthly legacy. Debates: Theistic vs. secular.

## Key Thinkers
Petrarch, Pico della Mirandola, Thomas More.

## Influence
Enlightenment, UN charter.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Petrarch Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Francesco_Petrarca_01.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

text# Humanism

## Introduction
Humanism prioritizes human reason, dignity. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 14th-century Petrarch. Cultures: Italian Renaissance, modern global.

## Branches
Civic (republican), literary, secular humanism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dignitas hominis. Ethics: Universal rights. Life meaning: Cultural achievement. Afterlife: Immortality in works. Debates: Anthropocentrism.

## Key Thinkers
Petrarch (revival), Erasmus (Christian), Sarpi (political).

## Influence
Democracy, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Petrarch Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Francesco_Petrarca_01.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

text# Humanistic Naturalism

## Introduction
Humanistic Naturalism explains reality naturally, centering human values. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century secular humanism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Human-centered morals. Life meaning: Natural fulfillment. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, George Santayana.

## Influence
Pragmatic humanism.

## Related Religions
See [naturalism.md](/philosophies/naturalism.md), [humanism.md](/philosophies/humanism.md).

## Sources

text# Hylozoism

## Introduction
Hylozoism attributes life to all matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Pre-Socratic Greece.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Respect for animated world. Life meaning: Universal vitality. Afterlife: Continuous life force.

## Key Thinkers
Thales, Anaximenes.

## Influence
Pantheism, animism.

text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism holds reality as mental or idea-based. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to modern.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Ideal moral forms. Life meaning: Mind's creation. Afterlife: Spiritual persistence.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, George Berkeley, Immanuel Kant.

## Influence
Transcendentalism, phenomenology.

idealism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism denies material reality independent of mind. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato's Forms, Berkeley 18th century. Cultures: Greek, British, German.

## Branches
Platonic, subjective (Berkeley), transcendental (Kant).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Esse est percipi (to be is to be perceived). Ethics: Ideal duties. Life meaning: Conscious construction. Afterlife: Mind continuity. Debates: Solipsism risk.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Berkeley, Kant, Hegel.

## Influence
Romanticism, quantum interpretations.

## View Illustrative Image
[View George Berkeley Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:George_Berkeley_by_John_Smollett.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/philosophies/platonism.md), [transcendental-idealism.md](/philosophies/transcendental-idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://iep.utm.edu/idealism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Idealist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260522)
idealism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism asserts reality is fundamentally mental. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato 4th BCE Republic. Cultures: Ancient Greece, 18th-19th century Europe.

## Branches
Objective (Hegel absolute), subjective (Berkeley), transcendental (Kant phenomena).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ideas over matter. Ethics: Ideal good. Life meaning: Perceptual existence. Afterlife: Ideal persistence. Debates: Realism refutation, solipsism.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (Forms), Berkeley (immaterialism), Kant (noumena), Fichte (ego).

## Influence
Hindu Advaita parallels, quantum observer effects.

## View Illustrative Image
[View George Berkeley Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:George_Berkeley_by_John_Smollett.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/philosophies/platonism.md), [transcendental-idealism.md](/philosophies/transcendental-idealism.md), [advaita-vedanta.md](/philosophies/advaita-vedanta.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://iep.utm.edu/idealism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Idealist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260522)
[^6]: IEP - Berkeley[](https://iep.utm.edu/berkeley/)

text# Ignosticism

## Introduction
Ignosticism deems God concepts meaningless until defined. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: 20th-century language philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Clarify terms. Life meaning: Semantic precision. Afterlife: Undefined.

## Key Thinkers
Sherwin Wine, Paul Kurtz.

text# Implicit Atheism

## Introduction
Implicit Atheism is lack of belief without explicit denial. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern atheism spectrum.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Neutral secular. Life meaning: Uncommitted. Afterlife: Unconsidered.

## Key Thinkers
Anthony Flew (presumption).

## Influence
Atheist discourse.

incompatibilism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Incompatibilism

## Introduction
Incompatibilism holds free will and determinism cannot coexist. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Modern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: If determined, no responsibility. Life meaning: Tension. Afterlife: Incompatible.

## Key Thinkers
Peter van Inwagen, Robert Kane.

## Influence
Libertarianism debates.

## Related Religions
See [free-will.md](/philosophies/free-will.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Incompatibilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/incompatibilism-arguments/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Incompatibilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incompatibilism)
[^3]: Britannica - Free Will[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/free-will)
innatism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Innatism

## Introduction
Innatism posits innate knowledge or ideas. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Plato to Chomsky.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Innate morals. Life meaning: Inborn truths. Afterlife: Innate soul.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Noam Chomsky.

## Influence
Linguistics, psychology.

text# Instrumentalism

## Introduction
Instrumentalism treats scientific theories as tools for prediction, not literal truths. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 20th-century philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Practical utility. Life meaning: Adaptive tools. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, Karl Popper (related).

## Influence
Pragmatism, anti-realism.

## Related Religions
See [pragmatism.md](/philosophies/pragmatism.md).

## Sources

text# Interactionism

## Introduction
Interactionism posits mind-body mutual influence. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Dualism debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Dual responsibility. Life meaning: Interactive existence. Afterlife: Soul-body separation.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Karl Popper (3 worlds).

## Influence

internalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Internalism

## Introduction
Internalism holds justification internal to mind. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Modern knowledge theory.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Reflective morals. Life meaning: Internal truth. Afterlife: Internal warrant.

## Key Thinkers
Laurence BonJour, Roderick Chisholm.

## Influence
Foundationalism, access debates.

## Related Religions
See [epistemology.md](/philosophies/epistemology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Internalism and Externalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-intext/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Epistemic Internalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internalism_and_externalism)

text# Intuitionism

## Introduction
Intuitionism posits moral truths known intuitively. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 18th-century moral sense.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Innate intuitions. Life meaning: Intuitive guidance. Afterlife: Intuitive belief.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore, W.D. Ross.

Non-naturalism, particularism.

irrealism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Irrealism

## Introduction
Irrealism denies objective reality, emphasizing non-real constructs. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Postmodern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Constructed morals. Life meaning: Non-real existence. Afterlife: Irrelevant.

## Key Thinkers
Nelson Goodman, Hilary Putnam.

## Influence
Anti-realism, art theory.

## Related Religions
See [antirealism.md](/philosophies/antirealism.md).

kantianism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is duty-based ethics, categorical imperative. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 18th-century Germany.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Universal maxims. Life meaning: Rational duty. Afterlife: Moral postulates.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant.

## Influence
Deontology, rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/philosophies/categorical-imperative.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant’s Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)

[^3]: Wikipedia - Kantianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantianism)
kantianism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism emphasizes reason in morality. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Kant 1785 Groundwork. Cultures: German, Western deontology.

## Branches
Pure/practical reason.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Good will. Ethics: Deontic duty. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Immortality postulate. Debates: Consequentialism contrast.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Fichte, Schopenhauer.

## Influence
Human rights, law.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/philosophies/categorical-imperative.md), [kantian-deontology.md](/philosophies/kantian-deontology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant’s Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)

text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is rational moral system. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Prussian Enlightenment. Cultures: European, global rights.

## Branches
Metaphysics, aesthetics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Phenomenal/noumenal. Ethics: Imperatives. Life meaning: Moral law. Afterlife: Postulate. Debates: Rigidity.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Hegel (critic).

## Influence
Liberalism, UN declarations.

## Introduction
Liberalism promotes liberty, equality. Branch: Political. Historical context: Locke 1689 Treatises. Cultures: Western democracies.

## Branches
Classical, social liberalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Social contract. Ethics: Harm principle. Life meaning: Individual rights. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Positive/negative liberty.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Mill, Rawls.

text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism advocates individual rights, limited government. Branch: Political. Historical context: 17th-century England. Cultures: Global democracies.

## Branches
Neoliberal, classical, social.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Negative freedom. Ethics: Tolerance. Life meaning: Self-realization. Afterlife: Secular. Debates: Equality vs. liberty.

## Key Thinkers
Locke (natural rights), Mill (utilitarian liberalism), Rawls (justice veil).

## Influence
Constitutions, welfare states.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Locke Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Locke.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions

text# Libertarianism

## Introduction
Libertarianism advocates maximal freedom, minimal government. Branch: Political. Historical context: 19th-century anarchism. Cultures: American right.

## Branches
Anarcho-capitalism, minarchism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Non-initiation of force. Ethics: Property rights. Life meaning: Voluntary association. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Taxation theft.

## Key Thinkers
Rothbard, Nozick, Rand (influence).

## Influence
Tea Party, crypto.

## Related Religions
See [voluntaryism.md](/philosophies/voluntaryism.md), [anarchism.md](/philosophies/anarchism.md).

humanistic-naturalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Humanistic Naturalism

## Introduction
Humanistic Naturalism combines naturalism's scientific worldview with humanism's focus on human values. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century American philosophy, post-Darwin.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Human welfare without supernatural. Life meaning: Natural human potential. Afterlife: None, as materialist.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey (pragmatic naturalism), Sidney Hook.

## Influence
Secular education, progressive ethics.

## Related Religions
See [naturalism.md](/religions/naturalism.md), [humanism.md](/philosophies/humanism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Humanistic Naturalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_naturalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Naturalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/naturalism-philosophy)
hylozoism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Hylozoism

## Introduction
Hylozoism attributes life or consciousness to all matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Pre-Socratic Greece, revived in vitalism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Universal respect for matter. Life meaning: Animate cosmos. Afterlife: Continuous vitality.

## Key Thinkers
Thales (water as principle), Anaximenes (air).

## Influence
Panpsychism, animism.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/philosophies/animism.md), [panpsychism.md](/philosophies/panpsychism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pre-Socratic Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/presocratics/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Hylozoism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hylozoism)
[^3]: Britannica - Hylozoism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/hylozoism)
identityism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Identityism

## Introduction
Identityism examines personal identity over time. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Modern analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Identity-based accountability. Life meaning: Continuous self. Afterlife: Identity preservation.

## Key Thinkers
John Locke (memory criterion), Derek Parfit (psychological continuity).

## Influence
Bioethics, AI.

## Related Religions
See [mind-body-dualism.md](/philosophies/mind-body-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Personal Identity[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/identity-personal/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Personal Identity[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_identity)
[^3]: Britannica - Personal Identity[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/personal-identity)

Continue?YesThought for 49signosticism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Ignosticism

## Introduction
Ignosticism holds that the question of God's existence is meaningless until the term "God" is clearly defined. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic philosophy and language analysis.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Focus on semantic clarity in moral discussions. Life meaning: Practical, avoiding ill-defined debates. Afterlife: Irrelevant without definition.

## Key Thinkers
Rabbi Sherwin Wine (coiner), Paul Kurtz (secular humanism influence).

## Influence
Humanistic Judaism, atheist discourse on terminology.

## Related Religions
See [agnosticism.md](/religions/agnosticism.md), [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Atheism and Agnosticism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atheism-agnosticism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Ignosticism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignosticism)
[^3]: Britannica - Atheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atheism)
implicit-atheism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Implicit Atheism

## Introduction
Implicit Atheism is the absence of belief in gods without explicit rejection. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern atheism classifications.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Neutral, secular living. Life meaning: Uninfluenced by theism. Afterlife: Not assumed.

## Key Thinkers
George H. Smith (atheism categories), Anthony Flew.

## Influence
Atheist demographics, philosophy of belief.

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md), [agnosticism.md](/religions/agnosticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Atheism and Agnosticism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atheism-agnosticism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Implicit and Explicit Atheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicit_and_explicit_atheism)
[^3]: Britannica - Atheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atheism)
incompatibilism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Incompatibilism

## Introduction
Incompatibilism argues free will and determinism are incompatible. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Debates on responsibility.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: If determined, no moral blame. Life meaning: Tension between control and fate. Afterlife: Incompatible if determined.

## Key Thinkers
Peter van Inwagen, Galen Strawson.

## Influence
Libertarianism, hard determinism.

## Related Religions
See [free-will.md](/philosophies/free-will.md), [determinism.md](/philosophies/strong-determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Incompatibilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/incompatibilism-arguments/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Incompatibilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incompatibilism)
[^3]: Britannica - Free Will[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/free-will)
innatism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Innatism

## Introduction
Innatism claims certain knowledge or ideas are inborn. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Rationalist tradition.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Innate moral sense. Life meaning: Pre-existing truths. Afterlife: Innate soul concepts.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (recollection), René Descartes (innate ideas), Noam Chomsky (language).

## Influence
Cognitive science, nativism.

## Related Religions
See [rationalism.md](/philosophies/rationalism.md), [platonic-epistemology.md](/philosophies/platonic-epistemology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Innate Knowledge[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/innate-knowledge/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Innatism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innatism)
[^3]: Britannica - Epistemology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/epistemology)
instrumentalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Instrumentalism

## Introduction
Instrumentalism regards theories as instruments for prediction, not truth. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Pragmatist philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Practical success. Life meaning: Useful models. Afterlife: Not empirically useful.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, Ernst Mach.

## Influence
Anti-realism, engineering.

## Related Religions
See [pragmatism.md](/philosophies/pragmatism.md), [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Scientific Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/scientific-realism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Instrumentalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instrumentalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Instrumentalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/instrumentalism)
interactionism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Interactionism

## Introduction
Interactionism posits mutual causal interaction between mind and body. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Dualist philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Dual agency. Life meaning: Mind-body synergy. Afterlife: Soul interaction.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes (pineal gland), Karl Popper.

## Influence
Philosophy of mind, consciousness studies.

## Related Religions
See [mind-body-dualism.md](/philosophies/mind-body-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)

[^3]: Britannica - Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/dualism-philosophy)
internalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Internalism

## Introduction
Internalism requires justification accessible to the mind. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Modern justification debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Reflective duties. Life meaning: Internal certainty. Afterlife: Internal evidence.

## Key Thinkers
Laurence BonJour, Ernest Sosa.

## Influence
Foundationalism vs. externalism.

## Related Religions
See [epistemology.md](/philosophies/epistemology.md).

intuitionism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Intuitionism

## Introduction
Intuitionism asserts moral truths are self-evident intuitions. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Early 20th-century metaethics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Non-natural properties. Life meaning: Intuitive good. Afterlife: Intuitive sense.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore, W.D. Ross (prima facie duties).

## Influence
Non-cognitivism critiques.

## Related Religions
See [ethical-intuitionism.md](/philosophies/ethical-intuitionism.md).

irrealism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Irrealism

## Introduction
Irrealism rejects the real/unreal distinction, emphasizing creative construction. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Postmodern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Constructed norms. Life meaning: Invented reality. Afterlife: Non-binary.

## Key Thinkers
Nelson Goodman (worldmaking), Joseph Margolis.

## Influence
Art theory, relativism.

## Related Religions
See [antirealism.md](/philosophies/antirealism.md).

Juche is North Korean ideology of self-reliance and independence. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century North Korea.

Continue?YesThought for 37shedonism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Hedonism

## Introduction
Hedonism posits pleasure as the ultimate good. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Ancient Greece, modern utilitarianism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Maximize pleasure, minimize pain. Life meaning: Sensory fulfillment. Afterlife: Not central, focus on earthly joy.

## Key Thinkers
Epicurus (moderate hedonism), Jeremy Bentham (quantitative).

## Influence
Utilitarianism, lifestyle philosophies.

## Related Religions
See [epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md](/philosophies/epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Hedonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/hedonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Hedonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/hedonism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Hedonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/hedonism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Hedonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hedonism)
hedonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Hedonism

## Introduction
Hedonism regards pleasure as intrinsic good. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Epicurus 4th BCE. Cultures: Greek, Western hedonistic ethics.

## Branches
Psychological (motivational), ethical (normative).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Pleasure/pain calculus. Ethics: Prudential pursuit. Life meaning: Enjoyment balance. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Qualitative vs. quantitative.

## Key Thinkers
Epicurus, Aristippus, Mill (higher pleasures).

## Influence
Utilitarianism, positive psychology.

## Related Religions
See [epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md](/philosophies/epicureanism-variants-hedonic-calculus.md), [utilitarianism.md](/philosophies/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md).

## Sources

text# Henotheism

## Introduction
Henotheism worships one god while acknowledging others. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Ancient religions.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Primary devotion. Life meaning: Divine favor. Afterlife: God-dependent.

## Key Thinkers
Max Müller (term), Vedic scholars.

## Influence
Monotheism transition.

humanism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Humanism

## Introduction
Humanism affirms human reason, ethics. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 14th-century Italy. Cultures: European Renaissance, global secular.

## Branches
Renaissance, secular, religious humanism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Studia humanitatis. Ethics: Rational compassion. Life meaning: Self-actualization. Afterlife: Earthly impact. Debates: Theistic vs. atheist.

## Key Thinkers
Petrarch, Pico della Mirandola, Sartre (existential humanism).

## Influence
Human rights, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Erasmus Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Holbein-erasmus.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

text# Humanism

## Introduction
Humanism values human agency, reason. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Petrarch 14th century. Cultures: Italian Renaissance, modern secular.

## Branches
Literary (Renaissance), civic, secular.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dignitas hominis. Ethics: Universal dignity. Life meaning: Cultural achievement. Afterlife: Human legacy. Debates: Anthropocentrism.

idealism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism claims reality is idea-dependent. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato 4th BCE. Cultures: Greek, German.

## Branches
Subjective, objective, transcendental.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Matter as perception. Ethics: Ideal good. Life meaning: Conscious creation. Afterlife: Mind immortality. Debates: Materialism opposition.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (Forms), Berkeley (esse percipi), Kant (noumena).

## Influence
Romanticism, quantum.

## View Illustrative Image
[View George Berkeley Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:George_Berkeley_by_John_Smibert_1727.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [objective-idealism.md](/philosophies/objective-idealism.md), [transcendental-idealism.md](/philosophies/transcendental-idealism.md).

## Sources

idealism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism asserts mind-dependent reality. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato's cave. Cultures: Greek, Indian, German.

## Branches
Platonic, subjective (Berkeley), absolute (Hegel).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ideas as primary. Ethics: Moral ideals. Life meaning: Ideal pursuit. Afterlife: Spiritual. Debates: Realism critique.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Berkeley, Kant, Schelling.

## Influence
Art, religion.

## View Illustrative Image
[View George Berkeley Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:George_Berkeley_by_John_Smibert_1727.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism advocates individual liberty. Branch: Political. Historical context: Locke 1689. Cultures: Anglo-European.

## Branches
Neoliberal, progressive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Negative freedom. Ethics: Equality. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Secular. Debates: Market vs. welfare.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Mill, Rawls.

## Influence
Constitutions, globalization.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Locke Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Locke.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [social-liberalism.md](/philosophies/social-liberalism.md), [cosmopolitanism.md](/philosophies/cosmopolitanism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Liberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/liberalism/)

## Introduction
Libertarianism advocates maximal freedom. Branch: Political. Historical context: 19th-century anarchism. Cultures: American right.

## Branches

Logical Atomism breaks reality into logical facts. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Early analytic philosophy.

text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism verifies meaning empirically. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Vienna Circle.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Scientific morals. Life meaning: Verifiable truths. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Moritz Schlick, Rudolf Carnap.

## Influence
Analytic philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md).

logical-positivism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism emphasizes verification. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 1920s Vienna. Cultures: European analytic.

## Branches
Verificationism, unity of science.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Meaningful if verifiable. Ethics: Emotive. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: Meaningless. Debates: Analytic/synthetic.

## Key Thinkers
Schlick, Carnap, Ayer.

## Influence
Behaviorism, neopositivism.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md), [verificationism.md](/philosophies/verificationism.md).

## Sources

text# Marxism

Marxism analyzes class, history as material dialectics. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 19th-century Europe.

text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism critiques capitalism via dialectics. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1848 Manifesto. Cultures: European, global left.

## Branches
Classical, Western Marxism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Surplus value. Ethics: Alienation end. Life meaning: Revolution. Afterlife: Atheist. Debates: Orthodoxy vs. revisionism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Gramsci.

## Influence
Labor movements.

Materialism holds only matter exists. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to modern science.

## Key Ideas

text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism denies non-physical reality. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Democritus atoms. Cultures: Greek, Marxist.

## Branches
Dialectical, reductive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Matter primary. Ethics: Class-based. Life meaning: Physical evolution. Afterlife: Cessation. Debates: Consciousness.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Communism, neuroscience.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx_001.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

materialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism asserts matter as fundamental. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient atomism. Cultures: Global scientific.

## Branches
Ancient, dialectical, eliminative.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No spirits. Ethics: Historical materialism. Life meaning: Causal chains. Afterlife: Extinction. Debates: Idealism.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Epicurus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Atheism, physics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx_001.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is rational ethics system based on duty. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 18th-century Enlightenment.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Categorical imperative. Life meaning: Moral autonomy. Afterlife: Postulate for justice.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant.

## Influence
Deontology, human rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/philosophies/categorical-imperative.md).

text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism emphasizes universal moral law. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Kant's 1785 Groundwork. Cultures: German rationalism, global ethics.

## Branches
Deontological, transcendental.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Good will, maxims. Ethics: Duty over consequences. Life meaning: Rational kingdom. Afterlife: Immortality postulate. Debates: Rigidity.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Fichte, Schiller.

## Influence
International law, virtue critiques.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is deontological ethics. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 1780s Critiques. Cultures: European, international.

## Branches
Practical reason, aesthetics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Hypothetical/categorical. Ethics: Universalizability. Life meaning: Moral legislation. Afterlife: Justice requires. Debates: Utilitarianism.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Reinhold, Schiller.

## Influence
Rights theory, UN.

## View Illustrative Image

Logical Positivism requires empirical verification for meaning. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Vienna Circle.

text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism demands verification. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 1920s Vienna. Cultures: European, US.

## Branches
Vienna Circle, English positivism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Verification principle. Ethics: Emotivism. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: Nonsense. Debates: Analytic/synthetic.

## Key Thinkers
Schlick, Carnap, Ayer.

## Influence
Behaviorism, analytic decline.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md), [verificationism.md](/philosophies/verificationism.md).

maoism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Maoism

## Introduction
Maoism adapts Marxism to agrarian revolution. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century China.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Mass line, peasant power. Life meaning: Perpetual struggle. Afterlife: Materialist, none.

## Key Thinkers
Mao Zedong (Little Red Book).

## Influence
Third World revolutions, Cultural Revolution.

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/philosophies/marxism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Maoism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/maoism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Maoism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Maoism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Maoism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoism)
marxism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism analyzes society through class struggle. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 19th-century industrial Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Dialectical materialism. Life meaning: Historical inevitability. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels.

## Influence
Communism, sociology.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/philosophies/communism.md).

## Sources

marxism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism critiques capitalism via material dialectics. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1848 Manifesto. Cultures: European, global left.

## Branches
Orthodox, Western Marxism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Commodity fetishism. Ethics: Emancipation. Life meaning: Praxis. Afterlife: Atheist. Debates: Determinism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Lukács.

## Influence
Labor theory, postcolonialism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/philosophies/communism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Karl Marx[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marx/)
[^2]: Britannica - Marxism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Marxism)

text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism views history as class conflict. Branch: Political. Historical context: Industrial Revolution. Cultures: European, Soviet, Chinese.

## Branches
Dialectical, historical materialism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Base/superstructure. Ethics: Exploitation abolition. Life meaning: Revolutionary. Afterlife: Denied. Debates: False consciousness.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Trotsky.

## Influence
20th-century revolutions, critical theory.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/philosophies/communism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

## Sources

text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism asserts matter as sole reality. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to Marxist.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Material conditions. Life meaning: Physical evolution. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Marx.

## Influence
Science, atheism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md).

## Sources

materialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism denies immaterial entities. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Democritus 5th BCE. Cultures: Greek, modern scientific.

## Branches
Mechanical, dialectical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Atoms or energy. Ethics: Historical. Life meaning: Causal. Afterlife: Extinction. Debates: Consciousness.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Physics, Marxism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/materialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Materialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/materialism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/materialism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Materialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Materialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Materialist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260539)
materialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism claims only matter exists. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Leucippus/Democritus. Cultures: Ancient to Soviet.

## Branches
Atomistic, historical, reductive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No souls. Ethics: Class. Life meaning: Evolution. Afterlife: No. Debates: Emergent mind.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Epicurus, Marx, Feuerbach.

## Influence
Atheism, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/philosophies/physicalism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

## Sources

[^6]: IEP - Hobbes[](https://iep.utm.edu/hobmoral/)

text# Mechanism

## Introduction
Mechanism views universe as machine-like. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Scientific revolution.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Deterministic. Life meaning: Causal laws. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Pierre-Simon Laplace.

## Influence
Physics, determinism.

## Related Religions
See [determinism.md](/philosophies/strong-determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mechanism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mechanism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Mechanism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanism_(philosophy))
