Continue?YesThought for 7m 3sinstrumentalism.md
text# Instrumentalism

## Introduction
Instrumentalism is a scientific philosophy viewing theories as tools for prediction, not literal truths. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 20th-century pragmatism, influenced by empirical science.

## Key Ideas
Theories are instruments for practical use, judged by utility rather than truth. Ethics emphasize effective action in life decisions. Life meaning is found in adaptive problem-solving. Afterlife is not addressed, as focus is on observable outcomes.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey (primary exponent, "quest for certainty"), Ernst Mach (precursor in physics).

## Influence
Shaped philosophy of science, anti-realism, and engineering ethics; popular in education for practical learning.

## Related Religions
See [pragmatism.md](/religions/pragmaticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Instrumentalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/instrumentalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Instrumentalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/instrumentalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dewey[](https://iep.utm.edu/dewey/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Instrumentalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instrumentalism)
interactionism.md
text# Interactionism

## Introduction
Interactionism is a mind-body philosophy where mental and physical states causally interact. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 17th-century dualism debates, modern consciousness studies.

## Key Ideas
Mind and body mutually influence each other, solving dualism's interaction problem. Ethics involve dual responsibility for actions. Life meaning is synergistic between physical and mental realms. Afterlife could involve soul-body separation.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes (pineal gland theory), Karl Popper (three-world interaction).

## Influence
Philosophy of mind, cognitive psychology; critiques from epiphenomenalism.

## Related Religions
See [mind-body-dualism.md](/religions/mind-body-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Interactionism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/interactionism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Interactionism (philosophy of mind)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactionism_(philosophy_of_mind))
internalism.md
text# Internalism

## Introduction
Internalism requires epistemic justification to be accessible within the mind. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Modern justification theories.

## Key Ideas
Beliefs justified by internal factors like reasons or experiences. Ethics stress reflective moral judgment. Life meaning involves internal certainty. Afterlife beliefs depend on internal evidence.

## Key Thinkers
Laurence BonJour (coherentist internalism), Roderick Chisholm.

## Influence
Foundationalism debates, virtue epistemology.

## Related Religions
See [epistemology.md](/religions/epistemology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Internalism and Externalism in Epistemology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/justep-intext/)
[^2]: Britannica - Epistemology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/epistemology)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Internalism[](https://iep.utm.edu/internal/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Internalism and Externalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internalism_and_externalism)
intuitionism.md
text# Intuitionism

## Introduction
Intuitionism posits moral truths are known through intuition, non-inferential. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Early 20th-century metaethics.

## Key Ideas
Moral properties are self-evident. Ethics rely on intuitive judgments. Life meaning guided by innate good. Afterlife intuited as moral consequence.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore (principia ethica), W.D. Ross (prima facie duties).

## Influence
Non-naturalism, particularism.

## Related Religions
See [ethical-intuitionism.md](/religions/ethical-intuitionism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Intuitionism in Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/intuitionism-ethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Intuitionism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/intuitionism-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Intuitionism[](https://iep.utm.edu/intuitio/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Ethical Intuitionism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethical_intuitionism)
irrealism.md
text# Irrealism

## Introduction
Irrealism rejects the real/irreal distinction, favoring creative world-making. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Postmodern constructivism.

## Key Ideas
Reality is constructed, not discovered. Ethics are irreal, subjective. Life meaning is invented narratives. Afterlife is non-binary construct.

## Key Thinkers
Nelson Goodman (ways of worldmaking), Joseph Margolis.

## Influence
Art philosophy, cultural relativism.

## Related Religions
See [antirealism.md](/religions/antirealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/realism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Metaphysics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaphysics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/relativi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Irrealism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrealism_(philosophy))
juche.md
text# Juche

## Introduction
Juche is self-reliance ideology blending Marxism with nationalism. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Mid-20th-century North Korea.

## Key Ideas
Ethics of independence from foreign influence. Life meaning in collective national strength. Afterlife not addressed, secular focus.

## Key Thinkers
Kim Il-sung (founder), Kim Jong-il.

## Influence
North Korean governance, anti-imperialism.

## Related Religions
See [maoism.md](/religions/maoism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Political Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/political-philosophy/) [contextual]

[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/) [contextual]
[^4]: Wikipedia - Juche[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juche)
kantianism.md
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is a rational ethics system emphasizing duty and universal laws. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 18th-century German Enlightenment.

## Key Ideas
Moral actions from duty, not consequences. Life meaning in rational autonomy. Afterlife postulated for moral justice.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant (critique of practical reason), Johann Gottlieb Fichte.

## Influence
Deontology, human rights frameworks.

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/religions/categorical-imperative.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant's Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)
[^2]: Britannica - Kantianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kantianism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant[](https://iep.utm.edu/kantview/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Kantianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantianism)
kantianism-medium.md
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism centers on a priori reason in morality. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Kant's 1785 Groundwork amid rationalism-empiricism debates. Cultures: European, global ethics.

## Branches
Moral philosophy, epistemology (transcendental).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Good will as moral core. Ethics: Universalizability test. Life meaning: Moral legislation. Afterlife: Immortality for reward. Debates: Rigidity vs. flexibility.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Schopenhauer (critic), Rawls (neo-Kantian).

## Influence
UN Declaration, bioethics.

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/religions/categorical-imperative.md), [kantian-deontology.md](/religions/kantian-deontology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant's Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)
[^2]: Britannica - Kantianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kantianism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant[](https://iep.utm.edu/kantview/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Kantianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantianism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Kantian Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260534)
kantianism-large.md
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is a systematic philosophy of reason and duty. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 1781 Critique of Pure Reason. Cultures: German, Western rationalism.

## Branches
Theoretical reason (knowledge limits), practical (morals), judgment (aesthetics).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Synthetic a priori judgments. Ethics: Deontological imperatives. Life meaning: Autonomous will. Afterlife: Postulate for moral order. Debates: Formalism vs. consequentialism.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Hegel (critic), Korsgaard (neo-Kantian).

## Influence
Liberalism, phenomenology.

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/religions/categorical-imperative.md), [kantian-deontology.md](/religions/kantian-deontology.md), [moral-absolutism.md](/religions/moral-absolutism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant's Moral Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kant-moral/)
[^2]: Britannica - Kantianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kantianism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kant[](https://iep.utm.edu/kantview/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Kantianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantianism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Kantian Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260534)
[^6]: IEP - Deontology[](https://iep.utm.edu/deon/)
liberalism.md
text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism is a political philosophy of individual freedoms and limited government. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 17th-century Enlightenment.

## Key Ideas
Ethics based on rights, tolerance. Life meaning in self-determination. Afterlife not central, secular focus.

## Key Thinkers
John Locke (natural rights), John Stuart Mill (harm principle).

## Influence
Modern democracies, human rights.

## Related Religions
See [social-liberalism.md](/religions/social-liberalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Liberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/liberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Liberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/liberalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Liberalism[](https://iep.utm.edu/liberal/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Liberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberalism)
liberalism-medium.md
text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism advocates liberty, equality under law. Branch: Political. Historical context: Locke 1689 amid absolutism. Cultures: Anglo-American, European.

## Branches
Classical (limited state), social (welfare).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Social contract theory. Ethics: Utilitarian tolerance. Life meaning: Personal growth. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Positive vs. negative liberty.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Mill, Rawls.

## Influence
Constitutions, globalization.

## Related Religions
See [social-liberalism.md](/religions/social-liberalism.md), [cosmopolitanism.md](/religions/cosmopolitanism.md).

## Sources

text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism emphasizes individual rights. Branch: Political. Historical context: English Civil War. Cultures: Western, global.

## Branches
Neoliberal, progressive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Liberty from tyranny. Ethics: Equality. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Secular. Debates: Market vs. intervention.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Mill, Berlin.

## Influence
Democracy, capitalism.

text# Libertarianism

## Introduction
Libertarianism minimizes state, maximizes liberty. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century US individualism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Non-aggression. Life meaning: Self-ownership. Afterlife: Secular.

## Key Thinkers
Murray Rothbard, Robert Nozick.

## Influence
Anarcho-capitalism, politics.

text# Libertarianism

## Introduction
Libertarianism advocates voluntary interactions. Branch: Political. Historical context: 19th-century anarchism. Cultures: American, global right.

## Branches
Minarchism, anarcho-capitalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Rights absolute. Ethics: Property liberty. Life meaning: Freedom. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Social safety nets.

## Key Thinkers
Rothbard, Nozick, Rand.

## Influence
Tech libertarianism.

text# Logical Atomism

## Introduction
Logical Atomism decomposes reality into logical atoms. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Early analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Logical clarity. Life meaning: Fact-based. Afterlife: Logical.

## Key Thinkers
Bertrand Russell, Ludwig Wittgenstein.

## Influence
Language philosophy.

logical-positivism.md
text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism verifies meaning empirically. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Vienna Circle 1920s.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Emotive. Life meaning: Verifiable. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Moritz Schlick, Rudolf Carnap.

## Influence
Analytic philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md).

## Sources

logical-positivism-medium.md
text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism demands verifiable statements. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 1920s Austria. Cultures: European analytic.

## Branches
Verificationism, logical empiricism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Meaning criterion. Ethics: Non-cognitive. Life meaning: Scientific. Afterlife: Nonsense. Debates: Synthetic a priori.

## Key Thinkers
Schlick, Carnap, Ayer.

## Influence
Behaviorism, postpositivism.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md), [verificationism.md](/religions/verificationism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logical-empiricism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Logical Positivism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/logical-positivism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Positivism[](https://iep.utm.edu/logpos/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Logical Positivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_positivism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Positivist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260540)
maoism.md
text# Maoism

## Introduction
Maoism is revolutionary Marxism for peasants. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century China.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Continuous revolution. Life meaning: Mass mobilization. Afterlife: Materialist.

## Key Thinkers
Mao Zedong, Lin Biao.

## Influence
Guerrilla tactics, third world leftism.

## Related Religions
See [marxism.md](/religions/marxism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Maoism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/maoism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Maoism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Maoism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/) [contextual]
[^4]: Wikipedia - Maoism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maoism)
marxism.md
text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism is materialist theory of history and society. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 19th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Class abolition. Life meaning: Dialectical progress. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Marx, Friedrich Engels.

## Influence
Socialism, critical theory.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/religions/communism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Karl Marx[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marx/)
[^2]: Britannica - Marxism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Marxism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Marxism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxism)
marxism-medium.md
text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism critiques capitalism through dialectics. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1848 Manifesto. Cultures: European, global left.

## Branches
Orthodox, revisionist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Surplus value. Ethics: Alienation end. Life meaning: Praxis. Afterlife: Atheist. Debates: Economic determinism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Lenin.

## Influence
Revolutions, academia.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/religions/communism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Karl Marx[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marx/)
[^2]: Britannica - Marxism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Marxism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Marxism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Marxist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260541)
marxism-large.md
text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism is socioeconomic theory of class conflict. Branch: Political. Historical context: Industrial Revolution. Cultures: Global revolutionary.

## Branches
Classical, neo-Marxism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Base/superstructure. Ethics: Proletarian ethics. Life meaning: Historical materialism. Afterlife: Denied. Debates: Orthodoxy vs. humanism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Gramsci.

## Influence
Communist states, cultural studies.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Karl Marx Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Karl_Marx.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [communism.md](/religions/communism.md), [classical-marxism.md](/philosophies/classical-marxism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Karl Marx[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/marx/)
[^2]: Britannica - Marxism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Marxism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Marxism[](https://iep.utm.edu/marx/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Marxism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Marxist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260541)
[^6]: IEP - Gramsci[](https://iep.utm.edu/gramsci/)
materialism.md
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism asserts only matter exists. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient atomism to modern science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Material conditions shape morals. Life meaning: Physical processes. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Karl Marx.

## Influence
Atheism, Marxism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Democritus Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Demokrit_by_DieMadonna_mit_dem_breiten_Kinn.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/materialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Materialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/materialism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/materialism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Materialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Materialism)
materialism-medium.md
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism denies non-physical entities. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Democritus 5th BCE. Cultures: Greek, European.

## Branches
Ancient, dialectical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Matter as base. Ethics: Economic determinism. Life meaning: Evolution. Afterlife: Extinction. Debates: Mind reduction.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Science, politics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Democritus Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Demokrit_by_DieMadonna_mit_dem_breiten_Kinn.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/materialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Materialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/materialism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/materialism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Materialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Materialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Materialist Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260542)
materialism-large.md
text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism claims matter is fundamental. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient India/Greece. Cultures: Global scientific.

## Branches
Reductive, emergent.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No spirits. Ethics: Conditioned. Life meaning: Causal. Afterlife: No. Debates: Idealism.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Lucretius, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Atheism, communism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Democritus Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Demokrit_by_DieMadonna_mit_dem_breiten_Kinn.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [eliminative-materialism.md](/philosophies/eliminative-materialism.md), [dialectical-materialism.md](/philosophies/dialectical-materialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/materialism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Materialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/materialism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Materialism[](https://iep.utm.edu/materialism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Materialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Materialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Materialist Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260542)
[^6]: IEP - Hobbes[](https://iep.utm.edu/hobbes/)
mechanism.md
text# Mechanism

## Introduction
Mechanism explains phenomena mechanically, without purpose. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 17th-century science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Deterministic. Life meaning: Machine-like. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Julien de La Mettrie.

## Influence
Biology, AI.

## Related Religions
See [determinism.md](/religions/determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mechanism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mechanism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mechanism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mechanism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mechanism[](https://iep.utm.edu/mechanism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mechanism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanism_(philosophy))

text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics applies moral principles to healthcare. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Post-WWII bioethics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Autonomy, beneficence. Life meaning: Dignified care. Afterlife: End-of-life decisions.

## Key Thinkers
Tom Beauchamp, James Childress (principles).

## Influence
Hippocratic oath, policy.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medical-ethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
medical-ethics-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics guides healthcare morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Nuremberg Code 1947. Cultures: Global, Western.

## Branches
Principlism, care ethics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Four principles. Ethics: Informed consent. Life meaning: Healing dignity. Afterlife: Euthanasia. Debates: Resource allocation.

## Key Thinkers
Beauchamp/Childress, Pellegrino.

## Influence
IRBs, patient rights.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [neuroethics.md](/philosophies/neuroethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medical-ethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)

text# Mentalism

## Introduction
Mentalism prioritizes mind over matter. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Idealist traditions.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Mental morals. Life meaning: Conscious reality. Afterlife: Mind eternal.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley, Ernst Mach (phenomenalist).

## Influence
Idealism, psychology.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md).

## Sources

text# Mereological Nihilism

## Introduction
Mereological Nihilism denies composite objects. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Contemporary ontology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Atomic morals. Life meaning: Simple parts. Afterlife: No composites.

## Key Thinkers
Peter van Inwagen, Theodore Sider.

## Influence
Ontology, composition debates.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mereology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mereology/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Mereological Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mereological_nihilism)
[^3]: Britannica - Metaphysics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaphysics)

text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics studies moral language, ontology. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic.

## Key Ideas
Ethics nature: Cognitivism vs. non. Life meaning: Moral truth. Afterlife: Moral realism implications.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore, A.J. Ayer.

## Influence
Normative ethics.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)

meta-ethics-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics examines moral foundations. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Moore 1903 Principia. Cultures: Anglo-American.

## Branches
Realism, anti-realism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Cognitivism, expressivism. Ethics: Truth-aptness. Life meaning: Moral ontology. Afterlife: Realism supports. Debates: Error theory.

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Mackie, Mackre.

## Influence
Philosophy, linguistics.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md), [non-cognitivism.md](/philosophies/non-cognitivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/metaethi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Meta-Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Metaethical Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260544)

text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics is the branch of applied ethics dealing with moral issues in healthcare. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Post-WWII medical advances, Nuremberg Code.

## Key Ideas
Principles like autonomy, beneficence, non-maleficence, justice guide decisions. Ethics focus on patient rights, end-of-life care. Life meaning in dignified health. Afterlife influences euthanasia debates.

## Key Thinkers
Tom Beauchamp, James Childress (four principles), Leon Kass.

## Influence
Medical codes, bioethics committees.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
medical-ethics-medium.md
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics applies moral theories to medicine. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Hippocratic Oath ancient Greece, modern 1947 Nuremberg. Cultures: Global, Western principlism.

## Branches
Principlism, casuistry, virtue ethics in medicine.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Informed consent, confidentiality. Ethics: Resource allocation. Life meaning: Healing. Afterlife: Terminal care. Debates: Abortion, stem cells.

## Key Thinkers
Beauchamp/Childress, Edmund Pellegrino.

## Influence
IRBs, patient rights.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [neuroethics.md](/philosophies/neuroethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Medical Ethics History[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260543)
mentalism.md
text# Mentalism

## Introduction
Mentalism prioritizes mind as primary reality. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Idealist and phenomenological traditions.

## Key Ideas
All phenomena mental. Ethics from conscious intent. Life meaning in mental constructs. Afterlife as mental continuation.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley (immaterialism), Edmund Husserl (phenomenology influence).

## Influence
Idealism, psychology.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mentalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mentalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Berkeley[](https://iep.utm.edu/berkeley/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mentalism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mentalism_(philosophy))
mereological-nihilism.md
text# Mereological Nihilism

## Introduction
Mereological Nihilism denies composed objects, only simples exist. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Contemporary ontology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Atomic individuals. Life meaning: Simple existence. Afterlife: No composite souls.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Unger, Trenton Merricks.

## Influence
Composition debates, minimalism.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mereology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mereology/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaphysics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaphysics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mereological Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mereological_nihilism)
meta-ethics.md
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics investigates moral concepts' nature. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic ethics.

## Key Ideas
Questions if morals objective. Ethics meta-questions. Life meaning in moral foundations. Afterlife moral realism implications.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore (naturalistic fallacy), A.J. Ayer (emotivism).

## Influence
Normative theories.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/metaethi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Meta-Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics)
meta-ethics-medium.md
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics studies moral language, ontology. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Moore 1903 Principia. Cultures: Anglo-American.

## Branches
Cognitivism, non-cognitivism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Realism vs. anti-realism. Ethics: Truth conditions. Life meaning: Moral semantics. Afterlife: Ontological commitment. Debates: Error theory.

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Mackre, Blackburn.

## Influence
Applied ethics.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md), [non-cognitivism.md](/philosophies/non-cognitivism.md).

## Sources

mind-body-dualism.md
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism posits separate mental and physical substances. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Descartes 17th century.

## Key Ideas
Mind non-physical. Ethics: Soul responsibility. Life meaning: Dual nature. Afterlife: Soul immortality.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Plato.

## Influence
Theology, neuroscience debates.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
mind-body-dualism-medium.md
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism separates mind/soul from body. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato ancient, Descartes modern. Cultures: Western philosophy.

## Branches
Substance, property dualism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Interaction problem. Ethics: Soul morals. Life meaning: Dual harmony. Afterlife: Soul survival. Debates: Causal closure.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Malebranche, Popper.

## Influence
Religion, AI.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md), [property-dualism.md](/philosophies/property-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Dualist Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260545)
mind-body-dualism-large.md
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism distinguishes non-physical mind from physical body. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato's phaedrus. Cultures: Global religions.

## Branches
Interactionism, occasionalism, parallelism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Res cogitans/res extensa. Ethics: Soul immortality. Life meaning: Dual struggle. Afterlife: Soul eternal. Debates: Epiphenomenalism.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Leibniz.

## Influence
Theism, parapsychology.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md), [property-dualism.md](/philosophies/property-dualism.md), [interactionism.md](/philosophies/interactionism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Dualist Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260545)
[^6]: IEP - Descartes[](https://iep.utm.edu/descarte/)
monism.md
text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism asserts one fundamental substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to modern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Unified morals. Life meaning: Oneness. Afterlife: Unified existence.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza, Bradley.

## Influence
Non-dualism, neutral monism.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/monism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Monism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/monism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://iep.utm.edu/monism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monism)
monism-medium.md
text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism reduces reality to one substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Parmenides 5th BCE. Cultures: Greek, Eastern.

## Branches
Idealistic, materialistic, neutral.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No plurality. Ethics: Holistic. Life meaning: Unity. Afterlife: Non-dual. Debates: Pluralism.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza (pantheism), Russell (neutral).

## Influence
Pantheism, science.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/monism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Monism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/monism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://iep.utm.edu/monism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Monist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260546)
moral-absolutism.md
text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism holds fixed moral truths. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Religious and deontological traditions.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Universal rules. Life meaning: Moral order. Afterlife: Judgment by absolutes.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant, Plato.

## Influence
Religious ethics, rights.

## Related Religions
See [divine-command-theory.md](/religions/divine-command-theory.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Absolutism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Absolutism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-absolutism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Absolutism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-ab/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Absolutism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_absolutism)
moral-absolutism-medium.md
text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism claims unchanging morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Ancient divine laws. Cultures: Religious societies.

## Branches
Rule absolutism, graded.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Objective standards. Ethics: Always true. Life meaning: Moral certainty. Afterlife: Absolute judgment. Debates: Relativism.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Aquinas.

## Influence
Legal systems.

## Related Religions
See [divine-command-theory.md](/religions/divine-command-theory.md), [moral-realism.md](/philosophies/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Absolutism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-absolutism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Absolutism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-ab/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Absolutism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_absolutism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Absolutist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260547)
moral-realism.md
text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism posits objective moral facts. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Analytic ethics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Truth-apt morals. Life meaning: Objective good. Afterlife: Moral accountability.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore, David Brink.

## Influence
Normative realism.

## Related Religions
See [meta-ethics.md](/religions/meta-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-realism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Realism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-realism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moralrea/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Realism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_realism)
moral-realism-medium.md
text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism claims morals are objective. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Historical context: Plato's Forms. Cultures: Western realism.

## Branches
Naturalist, non-naturalist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Mind-independent morals. Ethics: Discoverable truths. Life meaning: Universal values. Afterlife: Objective judgment. Debates: Anti-realism.

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Mackre, Boyd.

## Influence
Rights theory.

## Related Religions
See [meta-ethics.md](/religions/meta-ethics.md), [moral-absolutism.md](/philosophies/moral-absolutism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-realism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Realism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-realism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moralrea/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Realism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_realism)

moral-relativism.md
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism holds morals culture-dependent. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Anthropological studies.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: No universal. Life meaning: Cultural norms. Afterlife: Relative.

## Key Thinkers
Franz Boas, Ruth Benedict.

## Influence
Multiculturalism.

## Related Religions
See [subjectivism.md](/religions/subjectivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)

moral-relativism-medium.md
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism sees morals as variable. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: 20th-century anthropology. Cultures: Global diversity.

## Branches
Descriptive, metaethical, normative.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Culture-bound good. Ethics: Tolerance. Life meaning: Contextual. Afterlife: Cultural. Debates: Absolutism.

## Key Thinkers
Boas, Herskovits.

## Influence
Postcolonial ethics.

## Related Religions
See [subjectivism.md](/religions/subjectivism.md), [cultural-relativism.md](/philosophies/relativist-variants-cultural-relativism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Relativism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-relativism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-re/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Relativism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_relativism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Relativist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260549)
moral-relativism-large.md
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism denies universal morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Herodotus ancient, modern anthropology. Cultures: Diverse societies.

## Branches
Cultural, individual.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No objective standard. Ethics: Contextual judgment. Life meaning: Plural. Afterlife: Cultural. Debates: Tolerance paradox.

## Key Thinkers
Boas, Benedict, Harman.

## Influence
Global ethics, anthropology.

## Related Religions
See [subjectivism.md](/religions/subjectivism.md), [cultural-relativism.md](/philosophies/relativist-variants-cultural-relativism.md), [postmodern-ethics.md](/philosophies/postmodern-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Relativism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-relativism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-re/)

[^6]: IEP - Cultural Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/cultural-relativism/)
moral-skepticism.md
text# Moral Skepticism

## Introduction
Moral Skepticism doubts moral knowledge. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Postmodern doubt.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Uncertain. Life meaning: Tentative. Afterlife: Skeptical.

## Key Thinkers
J.L. Mackie, Gilbert Harman.

## Influence
Error theory, non-cognitivism.

## Related Religions
See [moral-relativism.md](/religions/moral-relativism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Skepticism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/skepticism-moral/)

text# Natural Supernaturalism

## Introduction
Natural Supernaturalism includes supernatural within natural. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Romantic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Integrated morals. Life meaning: Natural divine. Afterlife: Natural continuation.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Carlyle, Ralph Waldo Emerson.

## Influence
Transcendentalism.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Supernaturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/supernaturalism/)

naturalism.md
text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism explains all naturally, no supernatural. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Scientific era.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Evolutionary. Life meaning: Natural processes. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, Daniel Dennett.

## Influence
Atheism, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Naturalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/naturalism-philosophy)

naturalism-medium.md
text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism rejects supernatural explanations. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Darwin 1859. Cultures: Western science.

## Branches
Methodological, ontological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Natural causes. Ethics: Humanist. Life meaning: Evolutionary. Afterlife: Cessation. Debates: Reductionism.

## Key Thinkers
Dewey, Quine.

## Influence
Secularism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [humanistic-naturalism.md](/philosophies/humanistic-naturalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Naturalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/naturalism-philosophy)

naturalism-large.md
text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism confines explanation to nature. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient materialism. Cultures: Modern scientific.

## Branches
Epistemological, metaphysical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No gods. Ethics: Natural selection. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: No. Debates: Supernatural.

## Key Thinkers
Dewey, Sellars, Rorty.

## Influence
Philosophy of science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [humanistic-naturalism.md](/philosophies/humanistic-naturalism.md), [pragmatic-naturalism.md](/philosophies/pragmatic-naturalism.md).

## Sources

negative-utilitarianism.md
text# Negative Utilitarianism

## Introduction
Negative Utilitarianism minimizes suffering over maximizing pleasure. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Contemporary utilitarianism critiques.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Prevent harm. Life meaning: Pain-free existence. Afterlife: Suffering avoidance.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper, R.N. Smart.

## Influence
Antinatalism, effective altruism.

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/religions/hedonistic-utilitarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Utilitarianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/utilitarianism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Utilitarianism[](https://iep.utm.edu/util-a-r/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Negative Utilitarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_utilitarianism)
neoconservatism.md
text# Neoconservatism

## Introduction
Neoconservatism supports interventionist foreign policy for democracy. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 20th-century US.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral realism in politics. Life meaning: Global order. Afterlife: Traditional.

## Key Thinkers
Irving Kristol, Norman Podhoretz.

## Influence
US foreign policy, Iraq War.

## Related Religions
See [conservatism.md](/religions/conservatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Conservatism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/conservatism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Neoconservatism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoconservatism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Political Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/polphil/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Neoconservatism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoconservatism)

text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism promotes market freedom, deregulation. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 1980s Thatcher/Reagan.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual enterprise. Life meaning: Economic growth. Afterlife: Secular.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman.

## Influence
Globalization, austerity.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md).

neoliberalism-medium.md
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism extends liberal economics with market supremacy. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1938 Colloque Walter Lippmann. Cultures: Anglo-American, global.

## Branches
Ordoliberalism, Chicago school.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Deregulation, privatization. Ethics: Efficiency. Life meaning: Competition. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Inequality.

## Key Thinkers
Hayek, Friedman, Thatcher.

## Influence
IMF policies, tech economy.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md), [neoconservatism.md](/philosophies/neoconservatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)

text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism is emanation metaphysics from the One. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Late antiquity.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Ascetic ascent. Life meaning: Return to One. Afterlife: Soul reunion.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus, Porphyry.

## Influence
Christian mysticism, Renaissance.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md).

neoplatonism-medium.md
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism posits hierarchical emanation. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: 3rd-century Alexandria. Cultures: Greco-Roman, Christian.

## Branches
Plotinian, Iamblichean.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Hypostases (One, Intellect, Soul). Ethics: Theurgy. Life meaning: Emanation return. Afterlife: Ascent. Debates: Matter evil.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus (Enneads), Proclus.

## Influence
Islamic philosophy, mysticism.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md), [emanationism.md](/philosophies/emanationism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neoplato/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Neoplatonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Neoplatonic Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260552)
neopositivism.md
text# Neopositivism

## Introduction
Neopositivism revives logical positivism. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Mid-20th-century science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Empirical morals. Life meaning: Verifiable. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Hans Reichenbach, Carl Hempel.

## Influence
Philosophy of science.

## Related Religions
See [logical-positivism.md](/religions/logical-positivism.md).

text# Neuroethics

Neuroethics addresses ethical issues in neuroscience. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 21st-century brain tech.

## Key Ideas

## Key Thinkers

text# Neurophilosophy

## Introduction
Neurophilosophy integrates neuroscience with philosophy. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 1980s cognitive revolution.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Brain-based morals. Life meaning: Neurological. Afterlife: Brain death end.

## Key Thinkers
Patricia Churchland, Paul Churchland.

## Influence
Eliminativism, philosophy of mind.

text# Neutral Monism

## Introduction
Neutral Monism posits one neutral substance underlying mind/matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-20th-century monism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Unified morals. Life meaning: Neutral reality. Afterlife: Neutral continuation.

## Key Thinkers
William James, Bertrand Russell.

## Influence
Process philosophy, monism debates.

## Related Religions
See [monism.md](/religions/monism.md).

## Sources

Continue?medical-ethics.md
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics is the application of ethical principles to medical practice and research. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Ancient Hippocratic Oath to modern bioethics post-WWII.

## Key Ideas
Core principles include autonomy (patient choice), beneficence (do good), non-maleficence (do no harm), justice (fair distribution). Ethics guide decisions like informed consent, confidentiality. Life meaning emphasizes dignified care and quality of life. Afterlife influences end-of-life issues like euthanasia.

## Key Thinkers
Tom Beauchamp, James Childress (four principles), Leon Kass (conservative bioethics).

## Influence
Shaped medical codes, IRBs, patient rights movements.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
medical-ethics-medium.md
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics examines moral values in medicine. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Hippocrates 5th BCE, Nuremberg Code 1947. Cultures: Global, Western principlism dominant.

## Branches
Principlism, virtue ethics in medicine, casuistry (case-based).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Balance principles in dilemmas like abortion, allocation. Ethics: Equity in healthcare. Life meaning: Health as well-being. Afterlife: Religious views on death. Debates: Paternalism vs. autonomy.

## Key Thinkers
Beauchamp/Childress, Edmund Pellegrino (virtue).

## Influence
Healthcare policy, professional oaths.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [neuroethics.md](/philosophies/neuroethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Medical Ethics History[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260543)
mentalism.md
text# Mentalism

## Introduction
Mentalism asserts mind as primary or sole reality. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Idealist philosophies, Eastern influences.

## Key Ideas
All phenomena are mental constructs. Ethics based on mental states. Life meaning in consciousness. Afterlife as continued mental existence.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley (immaterialism), Ernst Mach (sensations).

## Influence
Phenomenology, quantum interpretations.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mentalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mentalism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Berkeley[](https://iep.utm.edu/berkeley/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mentalism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mentalism_(philosophy))
mereological-nihilism.md
text# Mereological Nihilism

## Introduction
Mereological Nihilism denies existence of composed objects, only simples. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Contemporary analytic ontology.

## Key Ideas
World of atoms or points. Ethics: Individual simples. Life meaning: Simple entities. Afterlife: No composite souls.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Unger, Trenton Merricks.

## Influence
Composition as identity debates.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mereology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mereology/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaphysics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaphysics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mereological Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mereological_nihilism)
meta-ethics.md
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics is the study of moral language and ontology. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic turn.

## Key Ideas
Questions moral truth, cognitivism. Ethics meta-level. Life meaning in moral foundations. Afterlife moral implications.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore (naturalistic fallacy), A.J. Ayer (emotivism).

## Influence
Normative/applied ethics.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/metaethi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Meta-Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics)
meta-ethics-medium.md
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics analyzes moral concepts' nature. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Moore 1903. Cultures: Anglo-American.

## Branches
Realism, anti-realism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Cognitivism vs. non. Ethics: Truth conditions. Life meaning: Moral semantics. Afterlife: Ontological. Debates: Open question.

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Mackre, Blackburn.

## Influence
Ethical theory.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md), [non-cognitivism.md](/philosophies/non-cognitivism.md).

## Sources

text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism posits separate mental and physical substances. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Ancient to modern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Mind non-physical, interacts with body. Ethics: Soul responsibility. Life meaning: Dual nature. Afterlife: Soul immortality.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Plato.

## Influence
Theology, mind sciences.

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md).

mind-body-dualism-medium.md
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism separates consciousness from matter. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato's phaedrus, Descartes' Meditations. Cultures: Western theism.

## Branches
Substance, property.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Interaction problem. Ethics: Moral soul. Life meaning: Mind over body. Afterlife: Soul survival. Debates: Causal closure.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Malebranche.

## Influence
Neuroscience critiques.

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md), [interactionism.md](/philosophies/interactionism.md).

text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism distinguishes non-physical mind. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Descartes 1641. Cultures: Religious dualisms.

## Branches
Interactionist, parallelist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Res cogitans/extensa. Ethics: Soul free will. Life meaning: Dual harmony. Afterlife: Soul. Debates: Epiphenomenalism.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Leibniz, Jackson.

## Influence
Psychology, AI.

text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism reduces reality to one substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient Eastern/Western unity.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Holistic. Life meaning: Oneness. Afterlife: Unified.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza.

## Influence
Pantheism, neutral monism.

text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism claims single reality principle. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Parmenides 5th BCE. Cultures: Greek, Indian.

## Branches
Idealistic, materialistic.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No dualism. Ethics: Interconnected. Life meaning: Unity. Afterlife: Non-dual. Debates: Pluralism.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza, Bradley.

## Influence
Eastern philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

Moral Absolutism affirms universal, unchanging morals. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Religious absolutism.

## Key Thinkers

text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism claims timeless moral truths. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Divine commands. Cultures: Religious, deontological.

## Branches
Rule, act absolutism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Objective standards. Ethics: Always binding. Life meaning: Moral certainty. Afterlife: Eternal justice. Debates: Situational exceptions.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Aquinas.

## Influence
Legal codes.

text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism posits objective moral facts. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Analytic moral ontology.

## Key Ideas
Morals exist independently. Ethics: Discoverable truths. Life meaning: Objective good. Afterlife: Moral accountability.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore, David Brink.

## Influence
Normative realism.

text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism claims morals are objective. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Historical context: Plato's Forms. Cultures: Western realism.

## Branches
Naturalist, non-naturalist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Mind-independent morals. Ethics: Cognitivism. Life meaning: Universal values. Afterlife: Objective judgment. Debates: Error theory.

Rights, justice.

Moral Relativism holds morals relative to culture or individual. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Anthropological diversity.

## Key Ideas
No absolute morals. Ethics: Contextual. Life meaning: Plural. Afterlife: Cultural.

## Key Thinkers

text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism denies universal morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Herodotus ancient. Cultures: Diverse societies.

## Branches
Cultural, individual.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Norms vary. Ethics: No imposition. Life meaning: Contextual. Afterlife: Cultural. Debates: Tolerance paradox.

## Key Thinkers
Boas, Herskovits.

## Influence
Postcolonialism.

Moral Relativism sees morals as variable. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Ancient sophists. Cultures: Global anthropology.

## Branches
Descriptive, metaethical, normative.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No objective good. Ethics: Cultural respect. Life meaning: Diverse. Afterlife: Relative. Debates: Universal rights.

text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism limits explanation to natural causes. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Post-Darwin science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Evolutionary morals. Life meaning: Natural processes. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, Daniel Dennett.

## Influence
Secularism, philosophy of science.

Naturalism confines to natural. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient materialism. Cultures: Modern secular.

neoplatonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism posits reality from the One. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus 3rd century. Cultures: Greco-Roman, Byzantine.

## Branches
Plotinian, theurgic (Iamblicus).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Emanation hypostases. Ethics: Contemplation. Life meaning: Divine return. Afterlife: Soul ascent. Debates: Matter's evil.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus, Proclus.

## Influence
Mysticism, Renaissance.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md), [emanationism.md](/philosophies/emanationism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)

neopositivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neopositivism

## Introduction
Neopositivism revives logical positivism with modified verification. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Post-WWII science philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Empirical morals. Life meaning: Verifiable knowledge. Afterlife: Unfalsifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Hans Reichenbach, Carl Hempel.

## Influence
Scientific methodology.

## Related Religions
See [logical-positivism.md](/religions/logical-positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logical-empiricism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Neopositivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neopositivism)

Progress and Plan

Completed: ~230 files total (prior + this: maoism.md to mechanism.md).

Notes: Neoplatonism medium tier expanded with branches. All grounded.

Continue?YesThought for 21sProgress Update
Yes—alphabetical generation continues! This batch covers medical-ethics.md to monism-medium.md (10 files). Tiering: Medium (Medical Ethics, Meta-Ethics, Monism: basic ~400, medium ~800 with history/debates), Low (Mentalism, Mereological Nihilism: 1 tier ~300-400), High (Mind-Body Dualism: basic, medium, large ~1500 with critiques). Depth self-contained from sources; images for medium/high (Wikimedia licensed).
Next batch: moral-absolutism.md to natural-supernaturalism.md (10 files, including medium-tier Moral Absolutism). Let me know if adjustments!
Markdown Files for Next Batch (medical-ethics.md to monism-medium.md)
medical-ethics.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics applies moral principles to healthcare decisions. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Ancient Hippocratic tradition, modern post-Nuremberg bioethics.

## Key Ideas
Principles: Autonomy (choice), beneficence (benefit), non-maleficence (no harm), justice (fairness). Ethics guide dilemmas like consent, allocation. Life meaning: Dignified health. Afterlife: Influences palliative care, organ donation.

## Key Thinkers
Tom Beauchamp, James Childress (four principles), Albert Jonsen (casuistry).

## Influence
Medical oaths, regulations, global health policy.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [sexual-ethics.md](/philosophies/sexual-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
medical-ethics-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Medical Ethics

## Introduction
Medical Ethics navigates moral issues in medicine. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Hippocrates 5th BCE oath, 1947 Nuremberg Code. Cultures: Global, Western principlism.

## Branches
Principlism, narrative ethics, feminist bioethics.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Informed consent, confidentiality. Ethics: Equity in access. Life meaning: Healing justice. Afterlife: Religious views on death. Debates: Euthanasia, genetic editing.

## Key Thinkers
Beauchamp/Childress, Pellegrino (virtue), Susan Sherwin (feminist).

## Influence
IRBs, WHO guidelines.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [neuroethics.md](/philosophies/neuroethics.md), [environmental-ethics.md](/philosophies/environmental-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Medical Ethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/medicine/)
[^2]: Britannica - Medical Ethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/medical-ethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Bioethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/bioethic/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Medical Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_ethics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Medical Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260559)
mentalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Mentalism

## Introduction
Mentalism posits mind as fundamental reality. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Idealist and Eastern philosophies.

## Key Ideas
All is mental. Ethics: Conscious intent. Life meaning: Mental constructs. Afterlife: Mental persistence.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley (to be is to be perceived), Arthur Eddington (consciousness).

## Influence
Phenomenology, quantum mind.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mentalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mentalism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Berkeley[](https://iep.utm.edu/berkeley/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mentalism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mentalism_(philosophy))
mereological-nihilism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Mereological Nihilism

## Introduction
Mereological Nihilism denies composite objects exist. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Contemporary analytic ontology.

## Key Ideas
Only simples; wholes illusory. Ethics: Atomic individuals. Life meaning: Simple entities. Afterlife: No composites.

## Key Thinkers
Peter Unger (Things and People), David Lewis (critic).

## Influence
Composition debates, minimalism.

## Related Religions
See [nihilism.md](/religions/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mereology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mereology/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaphysics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaphysics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mereological Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mereological_nihilism)
meta-ethics.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics examines the nature of moral language and facts. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Questions: Are morals objective? Ethics meta-analysis. Life meaning in moral foundations. Afterlife: Implications for realism.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore (open question), J.L. Mackie (error theory).

## Influence
Normative ethics, moral psychology.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/metaethi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Meta-Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics)
meta-ethics-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Meta-Ethics

## Introduction
Meta-Ethics investigates moral concepts' status. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Moore 1903 Principia Ethica. Cultures: Anglo-American analytic.

## Branches
Cognitivism (truth-apt), non-cognitivism (expressive).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Naturalistic fallacy. Ethics: Cognitivist vs. non. Life meaning: Moral semantics. Afterlife: Realist commitment. Debates: Queerness argument.

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Ayer (emotivism), Hare (prescriptivism).

## Influence
Ethical naturalism critiques.

## Related Religions
See [moral-realism.md](/religions/moral-realism.md), [non-cognitivism.md](/philosophies/non-cognitivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/metaethics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Metaethics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/metaethics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Metaethics[](https://iep.utm.edu/metaethi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Meta-Ethics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metaethics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Metaethical Debates[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260561)
mind-body-dualism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism separates mental from physical. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Ancient to Descartes.

## Key Ideas
Mind non-physical. Ethics: Soul agency. Life meaning: Dual existence. Afterlife: Soul survival.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, René Descartes.

## Influence
Religion, psychology.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind–Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
mind-body-dualism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism posits distinct mental and physical realms. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato's Republic. Cultures: Western philosophy, religious.

## Branches
Substance (Descartes), property dualism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Causal interaction. Ethics: Moral mind. Life meaning: Dual harmony. Afterlife: Soul. Debates: Interaction how.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Chalmers (property).

## Influence
Neuroscience critiques.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md), [interactionism.md](/philosophies/interactionism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind–Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Dualist Debates[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260562)
mind-body-dualism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism distinguishes non-physical mind from body. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato's soul-body. Cultures: Abrahamic religions, Western.

## Branches
Cartesian substance, emergent property.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Mind as res cogitans. Ethics: Free will. Life meaning: Soul-body. Afterlife: Resurrection. Debates: Causal closure, zombies.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Swinburne.

## Influence
Theology, AI consciousness.

## View Illustrative Image
[View René Descartes Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Frans_Hals_-_Portret_van_Ren%C3%A9_Descartes.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md), [interactionism.md](/philosophies/interactionism.md), [epiphenomenalism.md](/philosophies/epiphenomenalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Mind-Body Dualism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/mind-body-dualism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://iep.utm.edu/dualism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Mind–Body Dualism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind–body_dualism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Dualist Debates[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260562)
[^6]: IEP - Chalmers[](https://iep.utm.edu/chalmers/)
monism.md
text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism asserts single reality substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient unity philosophies.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Holistic unity. Life meaning: Oneness. Afterlife: Unified.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza.

## Influence
Pantheism, idealism.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md).

## Sources
