monism-medium.md
text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism reduces to one kind. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Parmenides. Cultures: Greek, Indian.

## Branches
Material, ideal.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No duality. Ethics: Interdependent. Life meaning: Unity. Afterlife: Non-dual. Debates: Pluralism.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza, Schopenhauer.

## Influence
Advaita Vedanta parallels.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/monism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Monism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/monism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Monism[](https://iep.utm.edu/monism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Monist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260563)

moral-absolutism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism holds certain actions right/wrong regardless of context. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Religious and deontological traditions.

## Key Ideas
Universal moral rules (e.g., no lying). Ethics: Absolute duties. Life meaning: Moral order. Afterlife: Absolute judgment.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant (categorical imperative), Thomas Aquinas (natural law).

## Influence
Human rights, religious ethics.

## Related Religions
See [kantianism.md](/religions/kantianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Absolutism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-absolutism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Absolutism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-ab/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Absolutism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_absolutism)
moral-absolutism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism claims timeless moral truths. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Divine commands in Abrahamic texts. Cultures: Religious, Western deontology.

## Branches
Theological (God-given), secular (rational).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No exceptions (e.g., always truth). Ethics: Objective standards. Life meaning: Moral certainty. Afterlife: Eternal consequences. Debates: Conflicts (e.g., lying to save life).

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Aquinas, R.M. Hare (universal prescriptivism).

## Influence
Legal absolutism, pacifism critiques.

## Related Religions
See [kantianism.md](/religions/kantianism.md), [divine-command-theory.md](/philosophies/divine-command-theory.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Absolutism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-absolutism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Absolutism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-ab/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Absolutism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_absolutism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Absolutist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260564)
moral-realism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism asserts objective moral facts exist. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Analytic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Morals true independently of belief. Ethics: Discoverable. Life meaning: Objective good. Afterlife: Moral accountability.

## Key Thinkers
G.E. Moore (non-natural), Russ Shafer-Landau.

## Influence
Normative ethics.

## Related Religions
See [meta-ethics.md](/religions/meta-ethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-realism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Realism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-realism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moralrea/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Realism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_realism)
moral-realism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism posits morals as objective. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Historical context: Plato's Forms. Cultures: Western analytic.

## Branches
Naturalist (evolutionary), non-naturalist (Moore).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Truth-makers for morals. Ethics: Cognitivism. Life meaning: Universal truths. Afterlife: Objective. Debates: Queerness (Mackie).

## Key Thinkers
Moore, Parfit, Enoch.

## Influence
Moral psychology.

## Related Religions
See [meta-ethics.md](/religions/meta-ethics.md), [moral-absolutism.md](/philosophies/moral-absolutism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-realism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Realism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-realism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Realism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moralrea/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Moral Realism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_realism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Moral Realist Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260565)
moral-relativism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism claims morals vary by culture/individual. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Anthropological relativism.

## Key Ideas
No universal morals. Ethics: Contextual. Life meaning: Plural values. Afterlife: Cultural.

## Key Thinkers
Ruth Benedict, Gilbert Harman.

## Influence
Tolerance, multiculturalism.

## Related Religions
See [moral-skepticism.md](/religions/moral-skepticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Relativism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-relativism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-re/)

moral-relativism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism denies absolute morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Herodotus 5th BCE. Cultures: Global anthropology.

## Branches
Cultural, individual.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Norms relative. Ethics: No imposition. Life meaning: Diverse goods. Afterlife: Relative. Debates: Tolerance obligation.

## Key Thinkers
Boas, Rorty.

## Influence
Postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [moral-skepticism.md](/religions/moral-skepticism.md), [subjectivism.md](/philosophies/subjectivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Moral Relativism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/moral-relativism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/moral-re/)

[^5]: JSTOR - Relativist Ethics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260566)
moral-relativism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism views morals as contextual. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Ancient sophists. Cultures: Anthropological.

## Branches
Descriptive (facts), meta (theory), normative (should tolerate).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No objective standard. Ethics: Cultural respect. Life meaning: Plural. Afterlife: Cultural. Debates: Universal human rights.

## Key Thinkers
Protagoras, Benedict, Wong.

## Influence
Cultural studies, diplomacy.

## Related Religions
See [moral-skepticism.md](/religions/moral-skepticism.md), [subjectivism.md](/philosophies/subjectivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Moral Relativism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/moral-relativism/)

[^6]: IEP - Cultural Relativism[](https://iep.utm.edu/cultural-relativism/)

text# Moral Skepticism

## Introduction
Moral Skepticism questions moral knowledge. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Postmodern doubt.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: No certainty. Life meaning: Provisional. Afterlife: Skeptical.

## Key Thinkers
Mackie (error theory), Sextus Empiricus.

## Influence
Relativism, nihilism.

See [moral-relativism.md](/religions/moral-relativism.md).

text# Natural Supernaturalism

## Introduction
Natural Supernaturalism integrates supernatural into natural. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Romanticism, Carlyle.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Immanent divine. Life meaning: Natural transcendence. Afterlife: Natural spirit.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Carlyle, Emerson.

## Influence
Transcendentalism.

text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism explains everything naturally. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Post-Darwin science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Natural selection morals. Life meaning: Empirical processes. Afterlife: None.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey, Richard Dawkins.

## Influence
Atheism, science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

naturalism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism rejects supernatural causes. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Ancient atomism, Darwin. Cultures: Western science.

## Branches
Methodological (science), ontological (reality).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Natural laws suffice. Ethics: Evolutionary. Life meaning: Adaptation. Afterlife: Cessation. Debates: Normativity.

## Key Thinkers
Dewey, Quine, Dennett.

## Influence
Secular ethics.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [humanistic-naturalism.md](/philosophies/humanistic-naturalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Naturalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/naturalism-philosophy)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://iep.utm.edu/naturali/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Naturalism (philosophy)[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturalism_(philosophy))
[^5]: JSTOR - Naturalist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260567)
naturalism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism limits to natural. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Democritus, Darwin. Cultures: Scientific global.

## Branches
Reductive, non-reductive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No dualism. Ethics: Naturalist fallacy avoidance. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: No. Debates: Supernatural evidence.

## Key Thinkers
Dewey, Hooker, Papineau.

## Influence
Philosophy of science.

## View Illustrative Image
[View John Dewey Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:John_Dewey_cph.3a51565.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [physicalism.md](/religions/physicalism.md), [humanistic-naturalism.md](/philosophies/humanistic-naturalism.md), [pragmatism.md](/philosophies/pragmatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Naturalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/naturalism-philosophy)

Continue?YesThought for 6m 21snegative-utilitarianism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Negative Utilitarianism

## Introduction
Negative utilitarianism is a form of consequentialism that prioritizes minimizing suffering over maximizing happiness. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century utilitarianism critiques, influenced by Popper's 1945 heuristic.

## Key Ideas
Actions are moral if they reduce aggregate suffering; happiness is neutral or secondary. Ethics focus on preventing harm, potentially leading to antinatalism or extinction if they end pain. Life meaning: Pain-free existence. Afterlife: Not addressed, secular focus.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper (negative utility heuristic), R.N. Smart, David Pearce (abolitionist version).

## Influence
Effective altruism, population ethics; criticisms for repugnant conclusions like world destruction.

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/religions/utilitarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Wikipedia - Negative Utilitarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_utilitarianism)
[^2]: Utilitarianism.com - Negative Utilitarianism FAQ[](https://www.utilitarianism.com/nu/nufaq.html)
[^3]: LessWrong - Negative Utilitarianism[](https://www.lesswrong.com/tag/negative-utilitarianism)
[^4]: Center for Reducing Suffering - Critique of Ord's Argument[](https://centerforreducingsuffering.org/point-by-point-critique-of-why-im-not-a-negative-utilitarian/)
neoconservatism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neoconservatism

## Introduction
Neoconservatism is a political philosophy advocating assertive US foreign policy to promote democracy, combining traditional conservatism with individualism. Branch: Political. Cultural context: 1960s US, ex-liberals rejecting counterculture.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral realism in international affairs. Life meaning: Spreading democratic values. Afterlife: Traditional conservative.

## Key Thinkers
Irving Kristol (founder), Norman Podhoretz, Leo Strauss (influence).

## Influence
Reagan/Bush policies, Iraq War; criticisms for militarism.

## Related Religions
See [conservatism.md](/religions/conservatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Wikipedia - Neoconservatism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoconservatism)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoconservatism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoconservatism)
[^3]: Vox - What is Neoconservatism?[](https://www.vox.com/2015/9/28/9407721/neoconservatism-explained)
[^4]: Cato Unbound - Neoconservatism Unmasked[](https://www.cato-unbound.org/2011/03/07/c-bradley-thompson/neoconservatism-unmasked)
neoliberalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism is a political and economic philosophy advocating robust liberal capitalist institutions, free markets, and limited state intervention. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Mid-20th-century revival of classical liberalism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Economic efficiency, individual freedom. Life meaning: Market-driven prosperity. Afterlife: Secular.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman, James Buchanan.

## Influence
Globalization, deregulation; criticisms for inequality.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^4]: The Guardian - Neoliberalism Ideology[](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/15/neoliberalism-ideology-problem-george-monbiot)
neoliberalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism promotes capitalist institutions with limited democracy and welfare. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1938 Colloque Walter Lippmann, post-WWII critique of large states. Cultures: Anglo-American, global policy.

## Branches
Ordoliberalism (German), Chicago School (US).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Free markets for knowledge use. Ethics: Negative freedom. Life meaning: Economic growth. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Inequality vs. prosperity.

## Key Thinkers
Hayek (knowledge), Friedman (monetarism), Buchanan (public-choice).

## Influence
IMF policies, Thatcher/Reagan.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md), [libertarianism.md](/philosophies/libertarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^4]: The Guardian - Neoliberalism Ideology[](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2016/apr/15/neoliberalism-ideology-problem-george-monbiot)
[^5]: Transnational Institute - Short History of Neoliberalism[](https://www.tni.org/en/article/a-short-history-of-neoliberalism)

text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism is a metaphysical philosophy of emanation from the One. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Late antiquity Rome.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Soul ascent. Life meaning: Divine return. Afterlife: Reunion with One.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus, Porphyry, Proclus.

## Influence
Mysticism, Christianity.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md).

neoplatonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism is Platonic revival with mystical emanation. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: 3rd-century Plotinus. Cultures: Greco-Roman, Byzantine.

## Branches
Plotinian (contemplative), theurgic (ritual).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: The One, Intellect, Soul. Ethics: Purification. Life meaning: Emanation ascent. Afterlife: Soul return. Debates: Matter evil.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus (Enneads), Iamblichus, Proclus.

## Influence
Islamic, Christian mysticism.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md), [emanationism.md](/philosophies/emanationism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)

neopositivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neopositivism

## Introduction
Neopositivism is revived logical positivism with relaxed verification. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Post-WWII philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Empirical morals. Life meaning: Verifiable knowledge. Afterlife: Unfalsifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Hans Reichenbach, Carl Hempel.

## Influence
Scientific philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [logical-positivism.md](/religions/logical-positivism.md).

## Sources

text# Neutral Monism

## Introduction
Neutral Monism posits one neutral substance for mind/matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-20th-century monism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Unified morals. Life meaning: Neutral reality. Afterlife: Neutral continuation.

## Key Thinkers
William James, Bertrand Russell.

Process philosophy.

Continue?107 web pagesyesThought for 59shumanistic-naturalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Humanistic Naturalism

## Introduction
Humanistic Naturalism combines naturalism's scientific worldview with humanism's focus on human values and potential. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century American pragmatism, influenced by evolutionary biology.

## Key Ideas
Reality is natural, no supernatural. Ethics emphasize human flourishing through reason and empathy. Life meaning derived from natural human experiences. Afterlife denied, as materialist.

## Key Thinkers
John Dewey (pragmatic naturalism), Corliss Lamont (humanistic focus).

## Influence
Secular humanism, progressive education.

## Related Religions
See [naturalism.md](/religions/naturalism.md), [secular-humanism.md](/philosophies/secular-humanism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Naturalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/naturalism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Humanistic Naturalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanistic_naturalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Humanism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/humanism)
hylozoism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Hylozoism

## Introduction
Hylozoism attributes life or animation to all matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Pre-Socratic Greek philosophy, revived in vitalist ideas.

## Key Ideas
Matter inherently alive. Ethics: Respect for all things. Life meaning: Universal vitality. Afterlife: Continuous animation.

## Key Thinkers
Thales (water as alive), Anaximenes (air as principle).

## Influence
Panpsychism, early science.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/philosophies/animism.md), [vitalism.md](/philosophies/vitalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pre-Socratics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/presocratics/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Hylozoism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hylozoism)
[^3]: Britannica - Hylozoism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/hylozoism)
idealism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism posits that reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient Plato to 19th-century German idealism.

## Key Ideas
Mind shapes existence. Ethics: Ideal moral forms. Life meaning: Consciousness realization. Afterlife: Spiritual continuity.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (Forms), George Berkeley (perceived existence), Immanuel Kant (transcendental).

## Influence
Romanticism, phenomenology.

## Related Religions
See [subjective-idealism.md](/philosophies/subjective-idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://iep.utm.edu/idealism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism)
idealism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism argues reality depends on mind. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato's cave allegory. Cultures: Greek, German, Indian parallels.

## Branches
Platonic (objective forms), subjective (Berkeley), absolute (Hegel).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Matter as idea. Ethics: Moral ideals. Life meaning: Perceptual world. Afterlife: Mind immortal. Debates: Solipsism, realism.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Berkeley, Kant, Hegel.

## Influence
Art, religion.

## Related Religions
See [subjective-idealism.md](/philosophies/subjective-idealism.md), [objective-idealism.md](/philosophies/objective-idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://iep.utm.edu/idealism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Idealist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260522)
idealism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Idealism

## Introduction
Idealism claims ideas or mind as reality base. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plato 4th BCE. Cultures: European, Eastern non-dualism.

## Branches
Ontological (reality mental), epistemological (knowledge mental).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Esse est percipi. Ethics: Ideal good. Life meaning: Conscious creation. Afterlife: Ideal realm. Debates: Materialist reduction.

## Key Thinkers
Plato (Forms), Berkeley (immaterialism), Kant (noumenal), Schelling.

## Influence
Quantum observer, Eastern philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [subjective-idealism.md](/philosophies/subjective-idealism.md), [objective-idealism.md](/philosophies/objective-idealism.md), [transcendental-idealism.md](/philosophies/transcendental-idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://iep.utm.edu/idealism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Idealist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260522)
[^6]: IEP - Berkeley[](https://iep.utm.edu/berkeley/)

Identityism focuses on personal identity continuity. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Modern identity debates.

## Key Ideas

text# Ignosticism

## Introduction
Ignosticism holds God concepts meaningless until defined. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Analytic atheism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Semantic clarity. Life meaning: Defined terms. Afterlife: Undefined.

## Key Thinkers
Sherwin Wine, Paul Kurtz.

## Influence
Humanistic Judaism.

## Related Religions

text# Incompatibilism

## Introduction
Incompatibilism argues free will and determinism conflict. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Free will debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: No blame if determined. Life meaning: Choice illusion. Afterlife: Incompatible.

## Key Thinkers
Peter van Inwagen, Galen Strawson.

## Influence
Libertarianism.

kantianism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is duty-based rational ethics. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Enlightenment Germany.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Universal maxims. Life meaning: Rational autonomy. Afterlife: Moral postulate.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant.

## Influence
Deontology, rights.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [categorical-imperative.md](/religions/categorical-imperative.md).

kantianism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism centers reason in morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Kant's Critiques 1781-1790. Cultures: German, Western.

## Branches
Moral, epistemological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Good will. Ethics: Deontological. Life meaning: Duty. Afterlife: Immortality. Debates: Consequentialism.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Fichte.

## Influence
International law.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Immanuel Kant Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Immanuel_Kant_(painted_portrait).jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions

text# Kantianism

## Introduction
Kantianism is systematic rational philosophy. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Prussian Enlightenment. Cultures: European.

## Branches
Critique Pure/Practical Reason.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Synthetic a priori. Ethics: Imperatives. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Postulate. Debates: Empiricism.

## Key Thinkers
Kant, Hegel (critic).

## Influence
Liberalism, phenomenology.

text# Liberalism

## Introduction
Liberalism advocates liberty, limited government. Branch: Political. Historical context: Locke 1689. Cultures: Western democracies.

## Branches
Classical, social.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Negative/positive liberty. Ethics: Harm principle. Life meaning: Autonomy. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Equality vs. liberty.

## Key Thinkers
Locke, Mill, Rawls.

## Influence
Human rights.

Libertarianism advocates voluntary society. Branch: Political. Historical context: 19th-century anarchism. Cultures: American, global right.

## Branches

## Key Ideas

Logical Positivism verifies meaning empirically. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Vienna Circle 1920s.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Emotive. Life meaning: Verifiable. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers

logical-positivism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Logical Positivism

## Introduction
Logical Positivism demands verifiable statements. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 1920s Austria. Cultures: European, US.

## Branches
Vienna Circle, logical empiricism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Meaning criterion. Ethics: Non-cognitive. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: Nonsense. Debates: Synthetic a priori.

## Key Thinkers
Schlick, Carnap, Ayer.

## Influence
Behaviorism, postpositivism.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md), [verificationism.md](/philosophies/verificationism.md).

text# Marxism

## Introduction
Marxism critiques capitalism through dialectics. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1848 Manifesto. Cultures: European, global left.

## Branches
Orthodox, Western Marxism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Surplus value. Ethics: Alienation end. Life meaning: Praxis. Afterlife: Atheist. Debates: Economic determinism.

## Key Thinkers
Marx, Engels, Gramsci.

## Influence
Revolutions, academia.

text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism denies immaterial entities. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Democritus 5th BCE. Cultures: Greek, European.

## Branches
Ancient, dialectical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Matter primary. Ethics: Economic. Life meaning: Causal. Afterlife: Extinction. Debates: Mind reduction.

## Key Thinkers
Democritus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence
Science, politics.

text# Materialism

## Introduction
Materialism claims matter fundamental. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Leucippus/Democritus. Cultures: Global scientific.

## Branches
Reductive, emergent.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No souls. Ethics: Conditioned. Life meaning: Causal. Afterlife: No. Debates: Emergent mind.

Democritus, Epicurus, Hobbes, Marx.

## Influence

mind-body-dualism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism separates mental/physical. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Descartes 17th.

## Key Ideas
Mind non-physical. Ethics: Soul agency. Life meaning: Dual. Afterlife: Soul.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Plato.

## Influence
Religion, psychology.

## Related Religions
See [substance-dualism.md](/religions/substance-dualism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Dualism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/dualism/)

mind-body-dualism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism distinguishes mind from body. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Plato ancient. Cultures: Western.

## Branches
Substance, property.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Interaction. Ethics: Moral mind. Life meaning: Dual harmony. Afterlife: Soul. Debates: Causal.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Descartes, Chalmers.

## Influence
Neuroscience critiques.

text# Mind-Body Dualism

## Introduction
Mind-Body Dualism posits distinct substances. Branch: Mind. Historical context: Descartes Meditations. Cultures: Religious dualisms.

## Branches
Interactionist, occasionalist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Res cogitans/extensa. Ethics: Free will. Life meaning: Soul-body. Afterlife: Resurrection. Debates: Zombies.

## Key Thinkers

## Influence

text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism holds one fundamental substance. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient unity.

text# Monism

## Introduction
Monism reduces to single reality. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Parmenides. Cultures: Greek, Indian.

## Branches
Material, ideal.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No duality. Ethics: Interdependent. Life meaning: Unity. Afterlife: Non-dual. Debates: Pluralism.

## Key Thinkers
Parmenides, Spinoza, Hegel.

## Influence
Advaita, quantum.

## Related Religions
See [neutral-monism.md](/religions/neutral-monism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism asserts fixed moral truths. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Religious absolutism.

## Key Ideas
Universal morals. Ethics: No exceptions. Life meaning: Moral order. Afterlife: Judgment.

## Key Thinkers
Immanuel Kant, Thomas Aquinas.

## Influence

moral-absolutism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Moral Absolutism

## Introduction
Moral Absolutism claims unchanging morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Divine laws. Cultures: Religious, Western.

## Branches
Rule, graded absolutism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Objective commands. Ethics: Always binding. Life meaning: Moral certainty. Afterlife: Eternal justice. Debates: Conflicting absolutes.

## Key Thinkers
Kant (imperatives), Aquinas (natural law).

## Influence
Religious doctrines, human rights.

## Related Religions
See [divine-command-theory.md](/religions/divine-command-theory.md), [moral-realism.md](/philosophies/moral-realism.md).

text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism posits objective moral facts. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Analytic ethics.

## Key Ideas

## Key Thinkers

moral-realism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Moral Realism

## Introduction
Moral Realism claims morals objective. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Historical context: Plato's Forms. Cultures: Western realism.

## Branches
Naturalist, non-naturalist.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Mind-independent morals. Ethics: Cognitivism. Life meaning: Universal values. Afterlife: Objective judgment. Debates: Error theory.

## Key Thinkers
Moore (non-natural), Parfit, Boyd (natural).

## Influence
Moral psychology.

## Related Religions
See [meta-ethics.md](/religions/meta-ethics.md), [moral-absolutism.md](/philosophies/moral-absolutism.md).

text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism holds morals relative to culture or individual. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Anthropological diversity.

## Key Ideas
No universal morals. Ethics: Contextual. Life meaning: Plural. Afterlife: Cultural.

## Key Thinkers
Franz Boas, Ruth Benedict.

## Influence
Multiculturalism, tolerance.

## Related Religions
See [subjectivism.md](/religions/subjectivism.md).

text# Moral Relativism

## Introduction
Moral Relativism denies absolute morals. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Herodotus 5th BCE. Cultures: Global diversity.

## Branches
Cultural, individual.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Norms vary. Ethics: No imposition. Life meaning: Contextual. Afterlife: Relative. Debates: Tolerance paradox.

## Key Thinkers
Boas, Rorty.

## Influence
Postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [subjectivism.md](/religions/subjectivism.md), [cultural-relativism.md](/philosophies/relativist-variants-cultural-relativism.md).

Moral Relativism sees morals as contextual. Branch: Ethics. Historical context: Ancient sophists. Cultures: Anthropological.

## Branches
Descriptive, metaethical, normative.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: No objective good. Ethics: Cultural respect. Life meaning: Plural. Afterlife: Relative. Debates: Universal rights.

text# Moral Skepticism

## Introduction
Moral Skepticism doubts moral knowledge. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: Postmodern skepticism.

## Key Ideas
No moral certainty. Ethics: Provisional. Life meaning: Tentative. Afterlife: Skeptical.

## Key Thinkers
J.L. Mackie (error theory), Gilbert Harman.

## Influence
Relativism, nihilism.

text# Natural Supernaturalism

## Introduction
Natural Supernaturalism integrates supernatural in natural world. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Romantic philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Divine in nature. Ethics: Immanent reverence. Life meaning: Natural transcendence. Afterlife: Natural spirit.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Carlyle (Sartor Resartus), Ralph Waldo Emerson.

## Influence

text# Naturalism

## Introduction
Naturalism explains phenomena naturally. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Scientific materialism.

## Key Ideas
No supernatural. Ethics: Evolutionary. Life meaning: Natural. Afterlife: None.

text# Naturalism

Naturalism rejects supernatural. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Darwin. Cultures: Western science.

## Branches
Methodological, ontological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Natural causes. Ethics: Humanist. Life meaning: Empirical. Afterlife: Extinction. Debates: Normativity.

Neoplatonism is Platonic revival with mysticism. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus 3rd century. Cultures: Greco-Roman.

## Branches

## Key Ideas

[^4]: Wikipedia - Neutral Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_monism)

new-formalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# New Formalism

## Introduction
New Formalism revives focus on form in art, literature. Branch: Aesthetics. Cultural context: 20th-century modernist revival.

## Key Ideas
Form over content. Ethics: Aesthetic judgment. Life meaning: Structured beauty. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Cleanth Brooks, John Crowe Ransom.

## Influence
New Criticism, literary theory.

## Related Religions
See [formalism.md](/religions/formalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Aesthetics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/aesthetics/)
[^2]: Britannica - New Formalism[](https://www.britannica.com/art/New-Criticism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Literary Theory[](https://iep.utm.edu/literary/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - New Formalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Formalism)
nihilism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism denies inherent meaning, values. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-century Russia, Nietzsche.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: No objective. Life meaning: Absurd void. Afterlife: None or meaningless.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche, Ivan Turgenev.

## Influence
Existentialism, postmodernism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche,_by_Walter_Kaufmann.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nihilism)
nihilism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism rejects value, meaning. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Turgenev 1862 novel, Nietzsche 1880s. Cultures: Russian, German.

## Branches
Political (anarchist), existential (absurd).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: God is dead. Ethics: Beyond good/evil. Life meaning: Self-overcome. Afterlife: Illusion. Debates: Passive vs. active nihilism.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre.

## Influence
Absurdism, deconstruction.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche,_by_Walter_Kaufmann.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [absurdism.md](/philosophies/absurdism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nihilism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Nihilist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260585)
nihilism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism asserts life's lack of meaning. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Russian nihilists 1860s, Nietzsche's "God is dead". Cultures: European, global existential.

## Branches
Metaphysical (no reality), ethical (no morals), existential (no purpose).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Value void. Ethics: Revaluation. Life meaning: Create own. Afterlife: None. Debates: Nihilism as liberation or despair.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche (active nihilism), Turgenev, Camus (absurd response).

## Influence
Postmodernism, therapy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche,_by_Walter_Kaufmann.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [absurdism.md](/philosophies/absurdism.md), [moral-nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism-variants-moral-nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nihilism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Nihilist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260585)
[^6]: IEP - Nietzsche[](https://iep.utm.edu/nietzsch/)

text# Nominalism

## Introduction
Nominalism denies universals, only particulars exist. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Medieval philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual morals. Life meaning: Particular. Afterlife: Particular soul.

## Key Thinkers
William of Ockham, David Hume.

## Influence
Empiricism, analytic.

## Related Religions
See [conceptualism.md](/religions/conceptualism.md) [contextual].

text# Non-Cognitivism

## Introduction
Non-Cognitivism holds moral statements non-truth-apt. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Emotivist ethics.

## Key Ideas

## Key Thinkers

text# Non-Theism

## Introduction
Non-Theism is absence of theism without atheism. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Secular spirituality.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Humanist. Life meaning: Natural. Afterlife: Ambiguous.

## Key Thinkers
Paul Kurtz, secular Buddhists.

## Influence
Humanism, agnosticism.

## Related Religions

negative-utilitarianism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Negative Utilitarianism

## Introduction
Negative Utilitarianism is an ethical theory that prioritizes minimizing suffering over maximizing happiness. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century utilitarian critiques, focusing on pain reduction.

## Key Ideas
Actions are judged by how much suffering they prevent. Ethics favor preventing harm, potentially endorsing antinatalism or extinction if it ends pain. Life meaning: A world with less suffering. Afterlife: Irrelevant, as focus is earthly pain.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper (negative approach to utility), R.N. Smart (original formulation).

## Influence
Antinatalism, effective altruism; debated for extreme conclusions like benevolent world-exploder.

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/religions/utilitarianism.md), [antinatalism.md](/philosophies/antinatalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Utilitarianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/utilitarianism-philosophy)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Negative Utilitarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_utilitarianism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Utilitarianism[](https://iep.utm.edu/util-a-r/)
neoconservatism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neoconservatism

## Introduction
Neoconservatism is a political philosophy combining conservative values with interventionist foreign policy to promote democracy. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Mid-20th-century US, from former liberals.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral clarity in global affairs, using power for good. Life meaning: Spreading freedom. Afterlife: Traditional conservative views.

## Key Thinkers
Irving Kristol, Norman Podhoretz, Leo Strauss (influence).

## Influence
US foreign policy (e.g., Iraq War); debated for imperialism.

## Related Religions
See [conservatism.md](/religions/conservatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Conservatism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/conservatism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Neoconservatism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoconservatism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoconservatism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoconservatism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Political Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/polphil/)
neoliberalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism is a political-economic philosophy advocating free-market capitalism, deregulation, and reduced state intervention. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Late 20th-century response to Keynesianism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual responsibility, market efficiency. Life meaning: Economic prosperity through competition. Afterlife: Secular focus.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman, Margaret Thatcher.

## Influence
Globalization, IMF policies; criticized for inequality.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
neoliberalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism revives classical liberalism with emphasis on markets. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1938 Lippmann Colloque, 1970s stagflation. Cultures: Anglo-American, global institutions.

## Branches
Ordoliberalism (German), Chicago School (US).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Privatization, free trade. Ethics: Efficiency over equity. Life meaning: Entrepreneurial self. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Austerity vs. social welfare.

## Key Thinkers
Hayek (Road to Serfdom), Friedman (monetarism), Reagan/Thatcher (practitioners).

## Influence
WTO, EU policies; backlash in populism.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md), [libertarianism.md](/philosophies/libertarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Neoliberal Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260560)
neoplatonism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism is a philosophical system of emanation from the One. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 3rd-century Roman Empire, influencing medieval thought.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Soul purification through contemplation. Life meaning: Ascent to divine. Afterlife: Soul reunion with the One.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus (Enneads), Porphyry, Iamblichus.

## Influence
Christian mysticism, Islamic philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoplatonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neoplato/)
neoplatonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism integrates Platonic ideas with mysticism. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus in 3rd-century Alexandria. Cultures: Greco-Roman, Byzantine, Islamic.

## Branches
Plotinian (philosophical), Iamblichean (theurgic, ritualistic).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: The One emanates Intellect, Soul, matter. Ethics: Theurgy and virtue for ascent. Life meaning: Return to unity. Afterlife: Soul immortal ascent. Debates: Matter as evil or necessary.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus, Porphyry, Proclus, Pseudo-Dionysius (Christian adaptation).

## Influence
Renaissance humanism, Kabbalah.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md), [kabbalah.md](/philosophies/kabbalah.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoplatonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neoplato/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Neoplatonic Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260561)
neopositivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neopositivism

## Introduction
Neopositivism refines logical positivism with relaxed verification. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Post-WWII philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Empirical verification. Life meaning: Scientific knowledge. Afterlife: Unverifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Hans Reichenbach, Carl Hempel (confirmation theory).

## Influence
Philosophy of science, analytic tradition.

## Related Religions
See [logical-positivism.md](/religions/logical-positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logical-empiricism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neopositivism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neopositivism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neopositivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neopositivism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Positivism[](https://iep.utm.edu/logpos/)

text# Neuroethics

## Introduction
Neuroethics is the ethics of neuroscience and brain technologies. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 21st-century brain research.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Privacy in brain data. Life meaning: Enhanced cognition. Afterlife: Consciousness upload debates.

## Key Thinkers
Martha Farah, Jonathan Moreno.

## Influence
Policy on neuroenhancement, AI ethics.

text# Neurophilosophy

## Introduction
Neurophilosophy uses neuroscience to address philosophical questions. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 1980s cognitive neuroscience.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Brain-based morals. Life meaning: Neurological self. Afterlife: Brain death end.

## Key Thinkers
Patricia Churchland, Paul Churchland (eliminative materialism).

Philosophy of mind, reductionism.

neutral-monism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neutral Monism

## Introduction
Neutral Monism posits one neutral substance underlying mind and matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-century philosophy of psychology.

## Key Ideas
Neither mental nor physical primary. Ethics: Unified moral framework. Life meaning: Neutral existence. Afterlife: Neutral continuation.

## Key Thinkers
William James (radical empiricism), Bertrand Russell (logical construction).

## Influence
Philosophy of mind, process thought.

## Related Religions
See [monism.md](/religions/monism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neutral Monism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neutral-monism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neutral Monism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neutral-monism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neutral Monism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neutmon/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Neutral Monism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neutral_monism)

text# Objective Idealism

## Introduction
Objective Idealism posits reality as objective mind or spirit. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-century absolute idealism.

## Key Ideas
Reality spiritual but objective. Ethics: Absolute morals. Life meaning: Spiritual unity. Afterlife: Eternal mind.

## Key Thinkers
F.H. Bradley, Josiah Royce.

## Influence
British idealism, holism.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/) [contextual]

occasionalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Occasionalism

## Introduction
Occasionalism holds God causes all events. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Islamic and Cartesian philosophy.

## Key Ideas
No natural causality. Ethics: Divine will. Life meaning: God's plan. Afterlife: Divine judgment.

## Key Thinkers
Al-Ghazali, Nicolas Malebranche.

## Influence
Theism, determinism.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md).

## Sources

[^3]: Wikipedia - Occasionalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occasionalism)
ontotheology.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Ontotheology

## Introduction
Ontotheology treats being as theological. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Heidegger's critique.

## Key Ideas
God as being ground. Ethics: Ontological morals. Life meaning: Being's theology. Afterlife: Ontological.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Heidegger (critic), Anselm.

## Influence
Post-metaphysical thought.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md).

text# Pandeism

## Introduction
Pandeism combines pantheism with deism, God became universe. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern synthesis.

## Key Ideas

## Key Thinkers

panentheism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism: God in all, but transcends. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Mystical theism.

## Key Ideas
God immanent/transcendent. Ethics: Divine unity. Life meaning: Cosmic participation. Afterlife: Divine absorption.

## Key Thinkers
Alfred North Whitehead, Charles Hartshorne.

## Influence
Process theology, eco-theology.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)

[^3]: Wikipedia - Panentheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panentheism)
panentheism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism sees God encompassing universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus influence. Cultures: Process philosophy.

## Branches
Classical, process panentheism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: God greater than sum. Ethics: Interconnected care. Life meaning: Divine process. Afterlife: Eternal in God. Debates: Pantheism distinction.

## Key Thinkers
Whitehead, Hartshorne, Ramanuja (qualified).

## Influence
Eco-theology, quantum.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md), [process-theology.md](/philosophies/process-theology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panentheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panentheism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://iep.utm.edu/panenthe/)

panpsychism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Panpsychism

## Introduction
Panpsychism attributes consciousness to all matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient animism, modern mind philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Mind in everything. Ethics: Universal respect. Life meaning: Conscious universe. Afterlife: Panconscious.

## Key Thinkers
Gottfried Leibniz, David Chalmers (contemporary).

## Influence
Consciousness studies, environmental ethics.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/religions/animism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panpsychism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panpsychism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panpsychism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panpsychism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Panpsychism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panpsychism)
panpsychism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Panpsychism

## Introduction
Panpsychism posits mind in matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Leibniz monads. Cultures: Western, Eastern parallels.

## Branches
Combination panpsychism, cosmopsychism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Proto-minds in atoms. Ethics: Matter compassion. Life meaning: Universal consciousness. Afterlife: Conscious continuity. Debates: Combination problem.

## Key Thinkers
Leibniz, James, Strawson.

## Influence
Quantum consciousness, animal rights.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/religions/animism.md), [hylozoism.md](/philosophies/hylozoism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panpsychism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panpsychism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panpsychism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panpsychism)

[^4]: Wikipedia - Panpsychism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panpsychism)

pantheism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Pantheism

## Introduction
Pantheism identifies God with universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to Spinoza.

## Key Ideas
Divine immanence. Ethics: Nature reverence. Life meaning: Cosmic unity. Afterlife: Eternal nature.

## Key Thinkers
Baruch Spinoza, John Toland.

## Influence
Environmentalism, new age.

## Related Religions
See [pandeism.md](/religions/pandeism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/)

pantheism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Pantheism

## Introduction
Pantheism equates God and nature. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Heraclitus, Spinoza 17th century. Cultures: Eastern, Western mysticism.

## Branches
Classical, scientific pantheism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: All is God. Ethics: Ecological. Life meaning: Divine nature. Afterlife: Cyclical. Debates: Personal God.

## Key Thinkers
Spinoza (Deus sive Natura), Einstein (cosmic religion).

## Influence
Romanticism, ecology.

## Related Religions
See [pandeism.md](/religions/pandeism.md), [panentheism.md](/philosophies/panentheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/)

perennial-philosophy.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Perennial Philosophy

## Introduction
Perennial Philosophy identifies common truths in religions. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Renaissance, modern esotericism.

## Key Ideas
Universal wisdom. Ethics: Transcendent morals. Life meaning: Eternal truth. Afterlife: Perennial soul.

## Key Thinkers
Aldous Huxley, René Guénon.

## Influence
Interfaith, mysticism.

## Related Religions
See [theosophy.md](/religions/theosophy.md).

## Sources

perspectivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Perspectivism

## Introduction
Perspectivism holds truth relative to perspective. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Nietzschean philosophy.

## Key Ideas
No absolute truth. Ethics: Plural morals. Life meaning: Multi-perspective. Afterlife: Perspective-dependent.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche, José Ortega y Gasset.

## Influence
Postmodernism, relativism.

## Related Religions
See [relativism-epistemic.md](/religions/relativism-epistemic.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Perspectivism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/perspectivism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Perspectivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspectivism)
[^3]: Britannica - Nietzsche[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Friedrich-Nietzsche)
phenomenalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Phenomenalism

## Introduction
Phenomenalism reduces reality to phenomena. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Empiricist philosophy.

## Key Ideas
To be is perceived. Ethics: Sensory morals. Life meaning: Phenomenal. Afterlife: Unperceived none.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley, John Stuart Mill, A.J. Ayer.

## Influence
Logical positivism, idealism.

## Related Religions
See [empiricism.md](/religions/empiricism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Phenomenalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/phenomenalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Phenomenalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/phenomenalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Phenomenalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenomenalism)

text# Philosophy of Archaeology

Philosophy of Archaeology examines methods, interpretations in studying past. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Modern archaeology debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Cultural heritage. Life meaning: Historical understanding. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Ian Hodder, Lewis Binford.

## Influence
Post-processual archaeology.

philosophy-of-biology-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Biology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology explores biological concepts philosophically. Branch: Science. Historical context: Darwin 1859. Cultures: Western science.

## Branches
Evolutionary theory, teleology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Function in biology. Ethics: Genetic determinism. Life meaning: Adaptation. Afterlife: Evolutionary. Debates: Reductionism.

## Key Thinkers
Mayr (population thinking), Gould (spandrels).

## Influence
Genetics, ecology.

## Related Religions
See [biology-philosophy-of.md](/religions/biology-philosophy-of.md), [environmental-ethics.md](/philosophies/environmental-ethics.md).

text# Philosophy of Natural Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Natural Science analyzes natural sciences. Branch: Science. Historical context: Bacon 1620. Cultures: Western empiricism.

## Branches
Realism, instrumentalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Demarcation. Ethics: Research ethics. Life meaning: Scientific. Afterlife: Empirical. Debates: Paradigms.

## Key Thinkers
Popper (falsification), Kuhn (shifts).

## Influence
Policy, education.

See [philosophy-of-science.md](/religions/philosophy-of-science.md), [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md).

text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science analyzes scientific knowledge. Branch: Science. Historical context: Aristotle to modern.

## Branches
General, specific (biology, physics).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Confirmation. Ethics: Misconduct. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Skeptical. Debates: Realism vs. anti.

## Key Thinkers
Bacon, Hume, Popper, Feyerabend.

## Influence
Science education.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md), [critical-rationalism.md](/philosophies/critical-rationalism.md).

platonic-epistemology-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Platonic Epistemology

## Introduction
Platonic Epistemology posits innate knowledge recalled. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Plato's dialogues. Cultures: Greek, Western.

## Branches
Theory of Forms, anamnesis.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Knowledge as recollection. Ethics: Ideal virtue. Life meaning: Forms pursuit. Afterlife: Soul preexistence. Debates: Empiricism.

## Key Thinkers
Plato, Socrates.

## Influence
Innatism, education.

## Related Religions
See [platonism.md](/religions/platonism.md), [innatism.md](/philosophies/innatism.md).

text# Political Philosophy

## Introduction
Political Philosophy examines state, power. Branch: Political. Historical context: Plato's Republic. Cultures: Global.

## Branches
Liberal, communitarian.

## Key Ideas

text# Pragmatism

Pragmatism judges ideas by practical effects. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 19th-century America.

## Key Ideas

text# Pragmatism

## Introduction
Pragmatism tests truth by consequences. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Peirce 1870s. Cultures: American, global.

## Branches
Classical, neo-pragmatism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Truth as workable. Ethics: Experimental. Life meaning: Growth. Afterlife: Practical. Debates: Correspondence truth.

## Key Thinkers
Peirce, James, Dewey, Rorty.

## Influence
Democracy, science.

text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism asserts reason as knowledge source. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Descartes 1637. Cultures: European rationalists.

## Branches
Continental, critical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Innate ideas. Ethics: Rational duty. Life meaning: Deductive truth. Afterlife: Immortal reason. Debates: Empiricism.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz.

## Influence
Mathematics, philosophy.

rationalism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism favors reason over experience. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 17th-century Continent. Cultures: French, Dutch.

## Branches
Epistemological, metaphysical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: A priori knowledge. Ethics: Rational imperatives. Life meaning: Innate ideas. Afterlife: Rational soul. Debates: Tabula rasa.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes (cogito), Spinoza (pantheism), Leibniz (monads).

## Influence
Idealism, logic.

## Related Religions
See [innatism.md](/religions/innatism.md), [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md), [platonic-epistemology.md](/philosophies/platonic-epistemology.md).

religious-philosophy.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Religious Philosophy

## Introduction
Religious Philosophy studies religious concepts philosophically. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Global theology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Divine command. Life meaning: Faith reason. Afterlife: Philosophical proofs.

## Key Thinkers
Thomas Aquinas, Søren Kierkegaard.

## Influence
Apologetics, interfaith.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Religion[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/philosophy-religion/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Religion[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-religion)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Religion[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_religion)
religious-philosophy-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Religious Philosophy

## Introduction
Religious Philosophy rationalizes religion. Branch: Theism. Historical context: Ancient theodicies. Cultures: Global.

## Branches
Analytic, continental theology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Ontological argument. Ethics: Theodicy. Life meaning: Divine purpose. Afterlife: Immortality arguments. Debates: Evil problem.

## Key Thinkers
Anselm, Aquinas, Plantinga.

## Influence
Religious studies.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md), [theodicy.md](/philosophies/theodicy.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Religion[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/philosophy-religion/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Religion[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-religion)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Religion[](https://iep.utm.edu/religion/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Religion[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_religion)
[^5]: JSTOR - Religious Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260576)
