Continue?yesThought for 1m 0sobjective-idealism.md
text# Objective Idealism

## Introduction
Objective Idealism posits reality as an objective spiritual or mental structure, not subjective perception. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-century British and German idealism, reacting to materialism.

## Key Ideas
Reality is mind-like but independent of individual minds, often as absolute spirit. Ethics: Moral ideals embedded in reality. Life meaning: Participation in absolute. Afterlife: Spiritual continuity in absolute.

## Key Thinkers
F.H. Bradley (appearance and reality), Josiah Royce (absolute idealism), T.H. Green.

## Influence
Influenced neo-Hegelianism, process philosophy, and holistic ethics; shaped social reform and idealism debates.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md), [pantheism.md](/philosophies/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Objective Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/objective-idealism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Objective Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective_idealism)
occasionalism.md
text# Occasionalism

## Introduction
Occasionalism is a metaphysical theory where God causes all events, with no natural causality. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 11th-century Islamic philosophy, 17th-century Cartesianism.

## Key Ideas
No direct cause-effect; God occasions events. Ethics: Divine will as moral source. Life meaning: God's plan. Afterlife: Divine judgment.

## Key Thinkers
Al-Ghazali (Islamic), Nicolas Malebranche (Christian).

## Influence
Theism, determinism debates; influenced Leibniz's pre-established harmony.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md), [theological-determinism.md](/philosophies/theological-determinism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Occasionalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/occasionalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Occasionalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/occasionalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Occasionalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occasionalism)
ontotheology.md
text# Ontotheology

## Introduction
Ontotheology treats being in theological terms, critiqued by Heidegger. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Medieval to postmodern philosophy.

## Key Ideas
God as ultimate being. Ethics: Ontological morals. Life meaning: Being's theology. Afterlife: Being continuity.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Heidegger (critic), Anselm of Canterbury (ontological argument).

## Influence
Postmetaphysical thought, theology critiques.

## Related Religions
See [theism.md](/religions/theism.md), [ontological-argument.md](/philosophies/ontological-argument.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Heidegger[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/heidegger/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Ontotheology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontotheology)
[^3]: Britannica - Ontology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/ontology-metaphysics)
panbabylonism.md
text# Panbabylonism

## Introduction
Panbabylonism is a historical theory tracing myths to Babylonian origins. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: 19th-century Assyriology.

## Key Ideas
Cultural diffusion from Babylon. Ethics: Historical truth-seeking. Life meaning: Myth roots. Afterlife: Mythical.

## Key Thinkers
Hugo Winckler, Friedrich Delitzsch.

## Influence
Biblical criticism, mythology studies; largely discredited but influential in early comparative religion.

## Related Religions
See [zoroastrianism.md](/religions/zoroastrianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mythology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mythology/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Panbabylonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panbabylonism)
[^3]: Britannica - Babylonian Religion[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Babylonian-religion)
pandeism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Pandeism

## Introduction
Pandeism combines pantheism and deism, God became universe. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Modern speculative theism.

## Key Ideas
God self-sacrificed into existence. Ethics: Natural harmony. Life meaning: Cosmic exploration. Afterlife: Reintegration.

## Key Thinkers
Scott Adams, Alan Dawe.

## Influence
Deist pantheism, new age.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Pandeism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandeism)
[^3]: Britannica - Pantheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/pantheism)
panentheism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism views God as encompassing and transcending the universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Mystical theism, process philosophy.

## Key Ideas
God in all, greater than all. Ethics: Divine immanence. Life meaning: Cosmic participation. Afterlife: Eternal in God.

## Key Thinkers
Alfred North Whitehead, Charles Hartshorne (process theology).

## Influence
Eco-theology, interfaith.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panentheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panentheism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Panentheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panentheism)
panentheism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism: God in universe but greater. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Neoplatonism influence. Cultures: Process thought, Eastern.

## Branches
Classical (Plotinus-like), process (Whitehead).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dipolar God. Ethics: Co-creation. Life meaning: Divine process. Afterlife: Inclusion in God. Debates: Pantheism boundary.

## Key Thinkers
Whitehead, Hartshorne, Ramanuja (qualified non-dualism).

## Influence
Environmental theology.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md), [process-theology.md](/philosophies/process-theology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panentheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panentheism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://iep.utm.edu/panenthe/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Panentheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panentheism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Panentheistic Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260565)
panpsychism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Panpsychism

## Introduction
Panpsychism attributes consciousness to all matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient animism, modern mind philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Consciousness ubiquitous. Ethics: Universal empathy. Life meaning: Conscious cosmos. Afterlife: Panconscious.

## Key Thinkers
Gottfried Leibniz (monads), David Chalmers (contemporary).

## Influence
Consciousness studies, animal ethics.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/religions/animism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panpsychism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panpsychism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panpsychism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panpsychism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Panpsychism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panpsychism)
panpsychism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Panpsychism

## Introduction
Panpsychism: mind in matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Leibniz 17th century. Cultures: Western, Eastern.

## Branches
Combination panpsychism, cosmopsychism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Proto-consciousness in particles. Ethics: Matter compassion. Life meaning: Universal mind. Afterlife: Conscious continuity. Debates: Combination problem.

## Key Thinkers
Leibniz, James, Strawson.

## Influence
Quantum mind, veganism.

## Related Religions
See [animism.md](/religions/animism.md), [hylozoism.md](/philosophies/hylozoism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panpsychism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panpsychism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panpsychism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panpsychism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panpsychism[](https://iep.utm.edu/panpsych/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Panpsychism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panpsychism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Panpsychist Metaphysics[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260566)
pantheism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Pantheism

## Introduction
Pantheism identifies God with universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Ancient to Spinoza.

## Key Ideas
Divine immanence. Ethics: Nature reverence. Life meaning: Cosmic unity. Afterlife: Eternal nature.

## Key Thinkers
Baruch Spinoza, John Toland.

## Influence
Environmentalism, new age.

## Related Religions
See [pandeism.md](/religions/pandeism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Pantheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/pantheism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Pantheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantheism)
pantheism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Pantheism

## Introduction
Pantheism: God = universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Heraclitus, Spinoza 17th century. Cultures: Western, Eastern.

## Branches
Classical, scientific pantheism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: All divine. Ethics: Ecological. Life meaning: Nature divinity. Afterlife: Cyclical. Debates: Personal God.

## Key Thinkers
Spinoza (pantheism), Einstein (cosmic religion).

## Influence
Romanticism, ecology.

## Related Religions
See [pandeism.md](/religions/pandeism.md), [panentheism.md](/philosophies/panentheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Pantheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/pantheism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://iep.utm.edu/pantheism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Pantheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pantheism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Pantheist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260567)
perennial-philosophy.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Perennial Philosophy

## Introduction
Perennial Philosophy identifies common truths across religions. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Renaissance esotericism, modern comparative religion.

## Key Ideas
Universal mysticism. Ethics: Transcendent morals. Life meaning: Eternal wisdom. Afterlife: Perennial soul.

## Key Thinkers
Aldous Huxley (The Perennial Philosophy), René Guénon.

## Influence
Interfaith dialogue, new age.

## Related Religions
See [theosophy.md](/religions/theosophy.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Perennial Philosophy[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/perennial-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Perennial Philosophy[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/perennial-philosophy)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Perennial Philosophy[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perennial_philosophy)
perspectivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Perspectivism

## Introduction
Perspectivism holds truth relative to perspective. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Nietzschean philosophy.

## Key Ideas
No absolute truth. Ethics: Plural morals. Life meaning: Multi-perspective. Afterlife: Perspective-dependent.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche, José Ortega y Gasset.

## Influence
Postmodernism, relativism.

## Related Religions
See [relativism-epistemic.md](/religions/relativism-epistemic.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Perspectivism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/perspectivism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Perspectivism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/perspectivism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Perspectivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspectivism)
phenomenalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Phenomenalism

## Introduction
Phenomenalism reduces reality to phenomena. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Empiricist philosophy.

## Key Ideas
To be is perceived. Ethics: Sensory morals. Life meaning: Phenomenal. Afterlife: Unperceived none.

## Key Thinkers
George Berkeley, John Stuart Mill, A.J. Ayer.

## Influence
Logical positivism, idealism.

## Related Religions
See [empiricism.md](/religions/empiricism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Phenomenalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/phenomenalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Phenomenalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/phenomenalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Phenomenalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenomenalism)
philosophy-of-archaeology.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Philosophy of Archaeology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Archaeology examines methods, interpretations in studying past. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Modern archaeology debates.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Cultural heritage. Life meaning: Historical understanding. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Ian Hodder, Lewis Binford.

## Influence
Post-processual archaeology.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-history.md](/religions/philosophy-of-history.md) [contextual].

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Archaeology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/archaeology/)
[^2]: Britannica - Archaeology[](https://www.britannica.com/science/archaeology)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Archaeology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_archaeology)
philosophy-of-biology.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Philosophy of Biology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology analyzes life sciences' concepts like evolution, teleology. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Post-Darwin philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Bioethical issues. Life meaning: Evolutionary adaptation. Afterlife: Biological none.

## Key Thinkers
Ernst Mayr, Elliott Sober, Peter Godfrey-Smith.

## Influence
Evolutionary ethics, ecology.

## Related Religions
See [evolution.md](/religions/evolution.md) [contextual].

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Biology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/biology-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Biology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-biology)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Biology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_biology)
philosophy-of-biology-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Biology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology explores biological concepts philosophically. Branch: Science. Historical context: Darwin 1859 Origin. Cultures: Western science, global bioethics.

## Branches
Evolutionary theory, teleology, reductionism in biology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Function vs. teleology in evolution. Ethics: Genetic engineering morals. Life meaning: Human needs enhanced by biotech. Afterlife: Materialist, no spiritual. Debates: Species realism, adaptationism.

## Key Thinkers
Mayr (population thinking), Gould (spandrels), Rosenberg (reductionism).

## Influence
Bioethics, conservation biology.

## Related Religions
See [evolution.md](/religions/evolution.md) [contextual], [bioethics.md](/philosophies/bioethics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Biology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/biology-philosophy/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Biology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-biology)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Biology[](https://iep.utm.edu/biology/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Biology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_biology)
[^5]: JSTOR - Biological Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260566)
philosophy-of-engineering.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Philosophy of Engineering

## Introduction
Philosophy of Engineering examines engineering knowledge, ethics. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Industrial revolution to modern tech.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Responsible innovation. Life meaning: Designed world. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Billy Vaughn Koen (engineering method), Joseph Pitt.

## Influence
Engineering ethics codes, tech policy.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-technology.md](/religions/philosophy-of-technology.md) [contextual].

philosophy-of-natural-science.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Philosophy of Natural Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Natural Science studies natural science foundations. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Scientific revolution.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Scientific integrity. Life meaning: Empirical understanding. Afterlife: Scientific skepticism.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper (falsification), Thomas Kuhn (paradigms).

## Influence
Scientific methodology, policy.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-science.md](/religions/philosophy-of-science.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Science[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/science/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Science[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-science)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Science[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_science)
philosophy-of-natural-science-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Natural Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Natural Science analyzes natural sciences. Branch: Science. Historical context: Newton 1687 Principia. Cultures: Western empiricism.

## Branches
Realism, instrumentalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Demarcation criterion. Ethics: Experiment ethics. Life meaning: Rational inquiry. Afterlife: Empirical. Debates: Theory choice.

## Key Thinkers
Popper, Kuhn, Lakatos.

## Influence
Physics, biology philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-science.md](/religions/philosophy-of-science.md), [positivism.md](/philosophies/positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Science[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/science/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Science[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-science)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Science[](https://iep.utm.edu/phil-sci/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Science[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_science)
[^5]: JSTOR - Natural Science Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260567)

Philosophy of Neuroscience explores brain-mind implications. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Modern neurotech.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Brain ethics. Life meaning: Neurological. Afterlife: Brain death.

## Key Thinkers

text# Philosophy of Physics

## Introduction
Philosophy of Physics analyzes physical theories' foundations. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Relativity and quantum mechanics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Tech implications. Life meaning: Physical laws. Afterlife: Physics-dependent.

## Key Thinkers
Albert Einstein, Niels Bohr.

## Influence

philosophy-of-physics-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Physics

## Introduction
Philosophy of Physics explores physics' conceptual issues. Branch: Science. Historical context: Newton to Einstein. Cultures: Western theoretical physics.

## Branches
Quantum mechanics, spacetime.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Realism in theories. Ethics: Nuclear implications. Life meaning: Determinism. Afterlife: Time theories. Debates: Copenhagen vs. many-worlds.

## Key Thinkers
Einstein, Bohr, Bell.

## Influence
Cosmology, tech ethics.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-science.md](/religions/philosophy-of-science.md), [quantum-consciousness.md](/philosophies/quantum-consciousness.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Physics[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/physics/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Physics[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-physics)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Physics[](https://iep.utm.edu/phys-phi/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Physics[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_physics)
[^5]: JSTOR - Physics Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260568)

text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science studies scientific methods, knowledge. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Post-Newtonian.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Research integrity. Life meaning: Empirical truth. Afterlife: Skeptical.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper, Thomas Kuhn.

## Influence

text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science rationalizes scientific inquiry. Branch: Science. Historical context: Bacon empiricism. Cultures: Western.

## Branches
Realism, instrumentalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Demarcation. Ethics: Misconduct. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Empirical. Debates: Paradigms.

## Key Thinkers
Bacon, Hume, Popper, Feyerabend.

## Influence
Technology ethics.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md), [critical-rationalism.md](/philosophies/critical-rationalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Science[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/science/)

philosophy-of-science-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science analyzes science. Branch: Science. Historical context: Aristotle to modern.

## Branches
General, specific (biology, physics).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Confirmation. Ethics: Misconduct. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Skeptical. Debates: Realism vs. anti.

## Key Thinkers
Bacon, Hume, Popper, Feyerabend.

## Influence
Science education.

## Related Religions
See [positivism.md](/religions/positivism.md), [critical-rationalism.md](/philosophies/critical-rationalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Science[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/science/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Science[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-science)

text# Philosophy of Social Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Social Science rationalizes social inquiry. Branch: Science. Historical context: Comte positivism. Cultures: Western social sciences.

## Branches
Positivist, interpretive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Explanation vs. understanding. Ethics: Informed consent. Life meaning: Social. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Value-neutrality.

## Influence

text# Physicalism

Physicalism holds all is physical or supervenes on physical. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 20th-century materialist philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Physical morals. Life meaning: Physical processes. Afterlife: No.

## Key Thinkers

text# Platonic Epistemology

## Introduction
Platonic Epistemology posits innate knowledge recalled. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Plato's dialogues. Cultures: Greek, Western.

## Branches
Theory of Forms, anamnesis.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Knowledge as recollection. Ethics: Ideal virtue. Life meaning: Forms pursuit. Afterlife: Soul preexistence. Debates: Empiricism.

Plato, Socrates.

## Influence

pyrrhonian-skepticism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Pyrrhonian Skepticism

## Introduction
Pyrrhonian Skepticism suspends judgment for tranquility. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Ancient Greece.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Undogmatic. Life meaning: Peaceful doubt. Afterlife: Suspended.

## Key Thinkers
Pyrrho, Sextus Empiricus.

## Influence

text# Rationalism

Rationalism prioritizes reason for knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 17th-century Continent.

text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism asserts reason as knowledge source. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Descartes 1637. Cultures: European.

## Branches
Continental, critical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Innate ideas. Ethics: Rational duty. Life meaning: Deductive truth. Afterlife: Immortal reason. Debates: Empiricism.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz.

## Influence
Mathematics, philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [innatism.md](/religions/innatism.md), [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md).

rationalism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism favors reason over experience. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 17th-century Continent. Cultures: French, Dutch.

## Branches
Epistemological, metaphysical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: A priori knowledge. Ethics: Rational imperatives. Life meaning: Innate ideas. Afterlife: Rational soul. Debates: Tabula rasa.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes (cogito), Spinoza (pantheism), Leibniz (monads).

## Influence
Idealism, logic.

## Related Religions
See [innatism.md](/religions/innatism.md), [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md), [platonic-epistemology.md](/philosophies/platonic-epistemology.md).

## Branches

## Key Ideas

text# Skepticism

## Introduction
Skepticism suspends judgment. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Pyrrho 4th BCE. Cultures: Greek, modern science.

## Branches
Ancient, Cartesian, Humean.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Epoché suspension. Ethics: Undogmatic. Life meaning: Tranquility. Afterlife: Unknowable. Debates: Global vs. local.

## Key Thinkers
Pyrrho, Sextus Empiricus, Descartes.

## Influence
Agnosticism, empiricism.

solipsism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Solipsism

## Introduction
Solipsism asserts only one's mind is sure. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Descartes 1641 Meditations. Cultures: Western skepticism.

## Branches
Metaphysical, epistemological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: External world illusion. Ethics: Self-interest. Life meaning: Solitary consciousness. Afterlife: Self-mind eternal. Debates: Other minds problem.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Berkeley, Wittgenstein (critic).

## Influence
Existentialism, virtual reality.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md), [skepticism.md](/philosophies/skepticism.md).

## Key Ideas

substance-dualism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Substance Dualism

## Introduction
Substance Dualism posits separate mental/physical substances. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: Cartesian dualism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Soul responsibility. Life meaning: Dual. Afterlife: Soul immortality.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Richard Swinburne.

## Influence
Theology, mind debates.

text# Subjectivism

Subjectivism holds morals subjective. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Individual relativism.

Ethics: Personal. Life meaning: Subjective. Afterlife: Personal belief.

## Key Thinkers

text# Sufism

## Introduction
Sufism is Islamic mysticism seeking divine union. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Medieval Islam.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Love, asceticism. Life meaning: God closeness. Afterlife: Spiritual union.

## Key Thinkers
Rumi, Al-Ghazali.

## Influence
Poetry, interfaith.

sufism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Sufism

## Introduction
Sufism is mystical Islam. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 8th-century ascetics. Cultures: Middle Eastern, South Asian.

## Branches
Orders (tariqas): Naqshbandi, Qadiri.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dhikr remembrance. Ethics: Ihsa n perfection. Life meaning: Fana annihilation. Afterlife: Maqam stations. Debates: Orthodoxy.

## Key Thinkers
Rumi (Masnavi), Ibn Arabi (unity of being).

## Influence
Whirling dervishes, poetry.

## Related Religions
See [islam.md](/religions/islam.md), [sufi-variants-mysticism.md](/philosophies/sufi-variants-mysticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sufism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/sufism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Sufism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Sufism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sufism[](https://iep.utm.edu/sufism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Sufism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sufism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Sufi Mysticism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260587)

Phenomenological Existentialism focuses on lived being. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Husserl/Heidegger 1920s. Cultures: European continental.

## Branches

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Being-toward-death. Ethics: Authenticity. Life meaning: Phenomenal. Afterlife: No essence. Debates: Subjectivity.

Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Sartre.

kierkegaardian-existentialism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Kierkegaardian Existentialism

## Introduction
Kierkegaardian Existentialism focuses on individual faith. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Kierkegaard 1840s. Cultures: European religious.

## Branches
Aesthetic, ethical, religious stages.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Leap of faith. Ethics: Paradoxical. Life meaning: God relation. Afterlife: Eternal. Debates: Rational faith.

## Key Thinkers
Kierkegaard, Barth (influence).

## Influence
Theology, literature.

## Related Religions
See [christian-existentialism.md](/religions/christian-existentialism.md), [existentialism.md](/philosophies/existentialism.md).

nietzschean-existentialism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism emphasizes will to power, self-overcoming. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-century Germany.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Beyond good/evil. Life meaning: Eternal recurrence. Afterlife: No.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche.

## Influence
Existentialism, postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nietzsche[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nietzsche/)

nietzschean-existentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism critiques values, affirms life. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Nietzsche 1880s. Cultures: European nihilism.

## Branches
Ubermensch, eternal recurrence.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: God is dead. Ethics: Value revaluation. Life meaning: Self-creation. Afterlife: Recurrence. Debates: Nihilism.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Heidegger (influence).

## Influence
Existential therapy.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nietzsche[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nietzsche/)

nietzschean-existentialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism revalues life. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Nietzsche's works 1870s-1880s. Cultures: European philosophy.

## Branches
Will to power, overman.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Perspectivism. Ethics: Master/slave morality. Life meaning: Affirmation. Afterlife: Eternal return. Debates: Misinterpretation.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Camus (response).

## Influence
Poststructuralism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources

text# Sartrean Existentialism

## Introduction
Sartrean Existentialism stresses freedom, responsibility. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 20th-century France.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Bad faith avoidance. Life meaning: Existence precedes essence. Afterlife: No.

## Key Thinkers
Jean-Paul Sartre.

## Influence
Literature, feminism.

sartrean-existentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Sartrean Existentialism

## Introduction
Sartrean Existentialism focuses on human freedom. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Sartre 1943 Being and Nothingness. Cultures: French existential.

## Branches
Being-for-itself, being-in-itself.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Condemned to be free. Ethics: Responsibility. Life meaning: Self-creation. Afterlife: No. Debates: Human nature.

## Key Thinkers
Sartre, Beauvoir.

## Influence
Postcolonialism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [feminist-existentialism.md](/philosophies/feminist-existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sartre[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/sartre/)

objective-idealism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Objective Idealism

## Introduction
Objective Idealism posits reality as an objective mind or absolute spirit, independent of individual perception. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-century British idealism, responding to materialism.

## Key Ideas
World as manifestation of absolute idea. Ethics: Moral harmony in absolute. Life meaning: Participation in universal mind. Afterlife: Eternal in absolute spirit.

## Key Thinkers
F.H. Bradley (Appearance and Reality), T.H. Green, Bernard Bosanquet.

## Influence
Social reform, holistic philosophy; critiqued for abstraction.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md), [hegelian-dialectics.md](/philosophies/hegelian-dialectics.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - British Idealism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/idealism-british/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Objective Idealism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Objective_idealism)
[^3]: Britannica - Idealism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/idealism)
occasionalism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Occasionalism

## Introduction
Occasionalism is a metaphysical theory where God is the sole cause of all events, with creatures as occasions. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 17th-century Cartesian philosophy and Islamic theology.

## Key Ideas
No natural causality; God intervenes. Ethics: Divine will absolute. Life meaning: God's plan. Afterlife: Divine judgment.

## Key Thinkers
Al-Ghazali (Islamic), Nicolas Malebranche (Christian).

## Influence
Determinism, pre-established harmony critiques.

## Related Religions
See [theological-determinism.md](/religions/theological-determinism.md), [islamic-philosophy-avicennism.md](/philosophies/islamic-philosophy-avicennism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Occasionalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/occasionalism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Occasionalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occasionalism)
[^3]: Britannica - Occasionalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/occasionalism)
ontotheology.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Ontotheology

## Introduction
Ontotheology fuses ontology with theology, treating God as being's ground. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Medieval scholasticism, Heidegger's critique.

## Key Ideas
Being as divine. Ethics: Ontological morals. Life meaning: Being's theology. Afterlife: Ontological existence.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Heidegger (critic), Anselm (ontological argument), Thomas Aquinas.

## Influence
Postmetaphysical thought, continental philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [ontological-argument.md](/religions/ontological-argument.md), [heideggerian-existentialism.md](/philosophies/heideggerian-existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Heidegger[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/heidegger/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Ontotheology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ontotheology)
[^3]: Britannica - Ontology[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/ontology-metaphysics)
panbabylonism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Panbabylonism

## Introduction
Panbabylonism is a historical theory claiming Babylonian origin for myths and religions. Branch: Historical. Cultural context: 19th-century Assyriology, biblical criticism.

## Key Ideas
Cultural diffusion from Babylon. Ethics: Historical accuracy. Life meaning: Myth roots. Afterlife: Babylonian influences.

## Key Thinkers
Hugo Winckler, Friedrich Delitzsch.

## Influence
Comparative mythology, debated and largely discredited.

## Related Religions
See [zoroastrianism.md](/religions/zoroastrianism.md), [judaism.md](/religions/judaism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Mythology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/mythology/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Panbabylonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panbabylonism)
[^3]: Britannica - Babylonian Religion[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Babylonian-religion)
pandeism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Pandeism

## Introduction
Pandeism combines pantheism and deism, God became universe. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: 19th-century speculative theism, modern cosmology.

## Key Ideas
God self-annihilated into creation. Ethics: Natural morals. Life meaning: Cosmic exploration. Afterlife: Reintegration or none.

## Key Thinkers
Scott Adams, Max Bernhard Weinstein.

## Influence
Alternative theism, simulation hypothesis.

## Related Religions
See [pantheism.md](/religions/pantheism.md), [deism.md](/philosophies/deism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Pantheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/pantheism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Wikipedia - Pandeism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pandeism)
[^3]: Britannica - Pantheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/pantheism)
panentheism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism posits God in all but transcendent. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Neoplatonism to process theology.

## Key Ideas
God encompasses universe. Ethics: Interconnected care. Life meaning: Divine participation. Afterlife: Eternal in God.

## Key Thinkers
Charles Hartshorne, Alfred North Whitehead.

## Influence
Eco-theology, open theism.

## Related Religions
See [process-theology.md](/religions/process-theology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panentheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panentheism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Panentheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panentheism)
panentheism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Panentheism

## Introduction
Panentheism: God contains and transcends universe. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus emanation, modern process. Cultures: Western theology, Eastern parallels.

## Branches
Classical (Ramanuja qualified non-dual), process (Whitehead dipolar God).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: World in God. Ethics: Relational care. Life meaning: Divine becoming. Afterlife: Inclusion in God. Debates: Pantheism distinction, evil problem.

## Key Thinkers
Whitehead (process and reality), Hartshorne, Baruch Spinoza (influence).

## Influence
Liberation theology, environmental ethics.

## Related Religions
See [process-theology.md](/religions/process-theology.md), [eco-theology.md](/philosophies/eco-theology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/panentheism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Panentheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/panentheism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Panentheism[](https://iep.utm.edu/panenthe/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Panentheism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panentheism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Panentheistic Theology[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260569)

text# Philosophy of Archaeology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Archaeology examines epistemological and ethical issues in studying the past. Branch: Science. Cultural context: 20th-century post-processual archaeology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Cultural heritage preservation. Life meaning: Historical narrative construction. Afterlife: Not central; focus on material evidence of beliefs.

## Key Thinkers
Ian Hodder (post-processual), Lewis Binford (processual).

## Influence
Archaeological theory, heritage management.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-history.md](/religions/philosophy-of-history.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Archaeology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/archaeology/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Philosophy of Archaeology[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_archaeology)
[^3]: Britannica - Archaeology[](https://www.britannica.com/science/archaeology)
philosophy-of-biology.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Philosophy of Biology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology explores conceptual foundations of biological sciences. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Post-Darwin evolutionary theory.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Biotechnological implications. Life meaning: Evolutionary adaptation. Afterlife: Biological materialist view.

## Key Thinkers
Ernst Mayr (biological species), Elliott Sober (fitness).

## Influence
Bioethics, evolutionary psychology.

## Related Religions
See [biology-philosophy-of.md](/religions/biology-philosophy-of.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Biology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/biology-philosophy/)

philosophy-of-biology-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Biology

## Introduction
Philosophy of Biology investigates biology's philosophical underpinnings. Branch: Science. Historical context: Darwin's 1859 Origin. Cultures: Western scientific.

## Branches
Evolutionary, molecular biology philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Teleology in function. Ethics: Genetic manipulation. Life meaning: Evolutionary. Afterlife: Material. Debates: Reductionism vs. holism.

## Key Thinkers
Mayr, Gould (spandrels), Rosenberg.

## Influence
Genomics ethics.

## Related Religions
See [biology-philosophy-of.md](/religions/biology-philosophy-of.md), [environmental-ethics.md](/philosophies/environmental-ethics.md).

text# Philosophy of Natural Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Natural Science examines natural sciences. Branch: Science. Historical context: Galileo empiricism. Cultures: Western.

## Branches
Realism, instrumentalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Laws of nature. Ethics: Experiment ethics. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Empirical. Debates: Theory choice.

## Key Thinkers
Popper, Kuhn, Lakatos.

## Influence
Policy, education.

text# Philosophy of Physics

## Introduction
Philosophy of Physics explores physics foundations. Branch: Science. Historical context: Newton to Einstein. Cultures: Western theoretical.

## Branches
Quantum mechanics, spacetime.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Spacetime. Ethics: Nuclear implications. Life meaning: Determinism. Afterlife: Time theories. Debates: Copenhagen vs. many-worlds.

## Key Thinkers
Einstein, Bohr, Bell.

## Influence
Cosmology, tech ethics.

text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science examines science nature. Branch: Science. Historical context: Bacon empiricism. Cultures: Western.

## Branches
Realism, instrumentalism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Demarcation. Ethics: Misconduct. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Empirical. Debates: Paradigms.

## Influence
Technology ethics.

text# Philosophy of Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Science analyzes scientific inquiry. Branch: Science. Historical context: Aristotle to modern.

## Branches
General, specific (biology, physics).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Confirmation. Ethics: Misconduct. Life meaning: Rational. Afterlife: Skeptical. Debates: Realism vs. anti.

## Key Thinkers
Bacon, Hume, Popper, Feyerabend.

## Influence

philosophy-of-social-science-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Philosophy of Social Science

## Introduction
Philosophy of Social Science rationalizes social methods. Branch: Science. Historical context: Comte positivism. Cultures: Western social sciences.

## Branches
Positivist, interpretive.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Explanation vs. understanding. Ethics: Informed consent. Life meaning: Social. Afterlife: Neutral. Debates: Value-neutrality.

## Key Thinkers
Durkheim, Weber, Habermas.

## Influence
Methodology, policy.

## Related Religions
See [philosophy-of-science.md](/religions/philosophy-of-science.md), [critical-theory.md](/philosophies/critical-theory.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Philosophy of Social Science[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/social-science/)
[^2]: Britannica - Philosophy of Social Science[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/philosophy-of-social-science)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Social Science[](https://iep.utm.edu/soc-sci/)

text# Philosophy of Statistics

## Introduction
Philosophy of Statistics examines statistical reasoning. Branch: Science. Cultural context: Modern probability.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Data integrity. Life meaning: Uncertain. Afterlife: Probabilistic.

## Key Thinkers
Ronald Fisher, Jerzy Neyman.

## Influence
Bayesianism, decision theory.

text# Physicalism

text# Platonic Epistemology

Platonic Epistemology posits innate knowledge recalled. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Plato's dialogues. Cultures: Greek, Western.

## Branches

## Key Ideas

Pragmatism tests truth by consequences. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Peirce 1870s. Cultures: American, global.

## Branches

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Truth as workable. Ethics: Experimental. Life meaning: Growth. Afterlife: Practical. Debates: Correspondence.

text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism prioritizes reason for knowledge. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: 17th-century Europe.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Rational morals. Life meaning: Innate truths. Afterlife: Rational soul.

## Key Thinkers
René Descartes, Baruch Spinoza, Gottfried Leibniz.

## Influence
Enlightenment, science.

## Related Religions

[^3]: Wikipedia - Rationalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rationalism)
rationalism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism asserts reason as knowledge source. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Descartes 1637. Cultures: European.

## Branches
Continental, critical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Innate ideas. Ethics: Rational duty. Life meaning: Deductive truth. Afterlife: Immortal reason. Debates: Empiricism.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Spinoza, Leibniz.

## Influence
Mathematics, philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [innatism.md](/religions/innatism.md), [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Rationalism vs Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/rationalism-empiricism/)

rationalism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Rationalism

## Introduction
Rationalism favors reason over experience. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: 17th-century Continent. Cultures: French, Dutch.

## Branches
Epistemological, metaphysical.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: A priori knowledge. Ethics: Rational imperatives. Life meaning: Innate ideas. Afterlife: Rational soul. Debates: Tabula rasa.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes (cogito), Spinoza (pantheism), Leibniz (monads).

## Influence
Idealism, logic.

## Related Religions
See [innatism.md](/religions/innatism.md), [kantianism.md](/philosophies/kantianism.md), [platonic-epistemology.md](/philosophies/platonic-epistemology.md).

text# Religious Philosophy

## Introduction
Religious Philosophy uses reason for religious questions. Branch: Theism. Historical context: Ancient theodicies. Cultures: Global theology.

## Branches
Analytic, continental.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Existence proofs. Ethics: Theodicy. Life meaning: Divine purpose. Afterlife: Immortality arguments. Debates: Evil problem.

skepticism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Skepticism

## Introduction
Skepticism suspends judgment. Branch: Epistemology. Historical context: Pyrrho 4th BCE. Cultures: Greek, modern science.

## Branches
Ancient, Cartesian, Humean.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Epoché suspension. Ethics: Undogmatic. Life meaning: Tranquility. Afterlife: Unknowable. Debates: Global vs. local.

## Key Thinkers
Pyrrho, Sextus Empiricus, Descartes.

## Influence
Agnosticism, empiricism.

## Related Religions
See [pyrrhonism.md](/religions/pyrrhonism.md), [agnosticism.md](/religions/agnosticism.md).

text# Solipsism

## Introduction
Solipsism holds only self exists. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Cartesian doubt.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Self-morals. Life meaning: Solitary. Afterlife: Self-continuation.

## Key Thinkers

solipsism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Solipsism

## Introduction
Solipsism asserts only one's mind is sure. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Descartes 1641 Meditations. Cultures: Western skepticism.

## Branches
Metaphysical, epistemological.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: External world illusion. Ethics: Self-interest. Life meaning: Solitary consciousness. Afterlife: Self-mind eternal. Debates: Other minds problem.

## Key Thinkers
Descartes, Berkeley, Wittgenstein (critic).

## Influence
Existentialism, virtual reality.

## Related Religions
See [idealism.md](/religions/idealism.md), [skepticism.md](/philosophies/skepticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Solipsism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/solipsism/)

Sufism is Islamic mysticism seeking divine union. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Medieval Islam.

sufism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Sufism

## Introduction
Sufism is mystical Islam. Branch: Theism. Historical context: 8th-century ascetics. Cultures: Middle Eastern, South Asian.

## Branches
Orders (tariqas): Naqshbandi, Qadiri.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Dhikr remembrance. Ethics: Ihsan perfection. Life meaning: Fana annihilation. Afterlife: Maqam stations. Debates: Orthodoxy.

## Key Thinkers
Rumi (Masnavi), Ibn Arabi (unity of being).

## Influence
Whirling dervishes, poetry.

## Related Religions
See [islam.md](/religions/islam.md), [sufi-variants-mysticism.md](/philosophies/sufi-variants-mysticism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sufism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/sufism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Sufism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Sufism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sufism[](https://iep.utm.edu/sufism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Sufism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sufism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Sufi Mysticism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260594)

Theism believes in personal God(s). Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Monotheistic religions.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Divine command. Life meaning: Relationship with God. Afterlife: Divine reward.

text# Theism

Theism posits personal deity. Branch: Theism. Historical context: Ancient religions. Cultures: Global monotheism.

## Branches

## Key Ideas

Phenomenological Existentialism explores being through lived experience. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 20th-century Europe.

Phenomenological Existentialism focuses on lived being. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Husserl/Heidegger 1920s. Cultures: European continental.

text# Phenomenological Existentialism

## Introduction
Phenomenological Existentialism explores being through lived experience. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 20th-century European philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Authenticity in existence. Life meaning: Being-in-the-world engagement. Afterlife: Death as existential horizon.

## Key Thinkers
Martin Heidegger (Being and Time), Maurice Merleau-Ponty (Phenomenology of Perception).

## Influence
Existential therapy, human sciences.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

phenomenological-existentialism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Phenomenological Existentialism

## Introduction
Phenomenological Existentialism examines human existence via lived experience. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Husserl’s phenomenology, Heidegger’s 1927 Being and Time. Cultures: European continental philosophy.

## Branches
Heideggerian (Dasein), Merleau-Ponty’s embodied phenomenology.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Being-toward-death shapes authentic existence. Ethics: Responsibility to one’s being. Life meaning: Engagement with the world as phenomenon. Afterlife: Death as existential limit, not metaphysical. Debates: Subjectivity vs. objectivity in experience.

## Key Thinkers
Heidegger, Merleau-Ponty, Jean-Paul Sartre (influenced).

## Influence
Psychotherapy, literary theory, postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [phenomenology.md](/philosophies/phenomenology.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Phenomenology[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/phenomenology/)
[^2]: Britannica - Existentialism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/existentialism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Phenomenology[](https://iep.utm.edu/phenom/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Existentialism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Existentialism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Phenomenological Existentialism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260592)
kierkegaardian-existentialism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Kierkegaardian Existentialism

## Introduction
Kierkegaardian Existentialism emphasizes individual faith and the absurd. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-century Danish theology.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Subjective truth via faith. Life meaning: Stages (aesthetic, ethical, religious). Afterlife: Eternal through leap of faith.

## Key Thinkers
Søren Kierkegaard (Fear and Trembling).

## Influence
Christian existentialism, modern theology.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kierkegaard[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kierkegaard/)
[^2]: Britannica - Søren Kierkegaard[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Soren-Kierkegaard)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Søren Kierkegaard[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard)
kierkegaardian-existentialism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Kierkegaardian Existentialism

## Introduction
Kierkegaardian Existentialism centers on individual faith and absurdity. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Kierkegaard’s 1840s Denmark, Romantic critique. Cultures: European Christian philosophy.

## Branches
Aesthetic, ethical, religious stages of life.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Leap of faith against reason’s limits. Ethics: Paradoxical obedience to God (e.g., Abraham’s sacrifice). Life meaning: Subjective commitment to divine relation. Afterlife: Eternal through faith. Debates: Rationality vs. absurdity in belief.

## Key Thinkers
Kierkegaard, Karl Barth (theological influence).

## Influence
Existential theology, literature (e.g., Dostoevsky).

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [christian-existentialism.md](/philosophies/christian-existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Kierkegaard[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/kierkegaard/)

text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism emphasizes will to power and self-overcoming. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-century German philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Beyond good and evil. Life meaning: Eternal recurrence. Afterlife: None, life affirmation.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche (Thus Spoke Zarathustra).

## Influence
Existentialism, postmodernism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources

nietzschean-existentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism revalues life through will to power. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Nietzsche’s 1880s works. Cultures: European nihilism critique.

## Branches
Ubermensch (overman), eternal recurrence.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: “God is dead” prompts value creation. Ethics: Master/slave morality rejection. Life meaning: Self-overcoming. Afterlife: Eternal return as thought experiment. Debates: Nihilism vs. affirmation.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Martin Heidegger (interpreter).

## Influence
Existential therapy, postmodern thought.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nietzsche[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nietzsche/)
[^2]: Britannica - Friedrich Nietzsche[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Friedrich-Nietzsche)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nietzsche[](https://iep.utm.edu/nietzsch/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Friedrich Nietzsche[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friedrich_Nietzsche)

nietzschean-existentialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Nietzschean Existentialism

## Introduction
Nietzschean Existentialism affirms life amid nihilism. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Nietzsche’s 1870s-1880s works. Cultures: European philosophy.

## Branches
Will to power, overman, eternal recurrence.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Perspectivism rejects absolute truth. Ethics: Revaluation of values. Life meaning: Creating one’s essence. Afterlife: Eternal return as existential test. Debates: Misappropriation by ideologies.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Albert Camus (response).

## Influence
Poststructuralism, existential psychology.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nietzsche[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nietzsche/)

sartrean-existentialism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Sartrean Existentialism

## Introduction
Sartrean Existentialism stresses radical freedom and responsibility. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 20th-century France.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Avoiding bad faith. Life meaning: Existence precedes essence. Afterlife: None, focus on this life.

## Key Thinkers
Jean-Paul Sartre (Being and Nothingness).

## Influence
Literature, political activism.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources

sartrean-existentialism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Sartrean Existentialism

## Introduction
Sartrean Existentialism emphasizes human freedom. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Sartre’s 1943 Being and Nothingness. Cultures: French existentialism.

## Branches
Being-for-itself (consciousness), being-in-itself (objects).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Condemned to be free; humans create meaning. Ethics: Responsibility for choices. Life meaning: Self-defined essence. Afterlife: None, existential focus. Debates: Freedom vs. determinism.

## Key Thinkers
Sartre, Simone de Beauvoir (applied to feminism).

## Influence
Postcolonial thought, existential literature.

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [feminist-existentialism.md](/philosophies/feminist-existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sartre[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/sartre/)
[^2]: Britannica - Jean-Paul Sartre[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jean-Paul-Sartre)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sartre[](https://iep.utm.edu/sartre/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Jean-Paul Sartre[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre)
[^5]: JSTOR - Sartrean Existentialism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260595)
sartrean-existentialism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Sartrean Existentialism

## Introduction
Sartrean Existentialism champions radical human freedom. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Sartre’s 1940s France, post-WWII. Cultures: European existentialism.

## Branches
Being-for-itself, being-in-itself, bad faith.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Humans define essence through action. Ethics: Absolute responsibility. Life meaning: Freedom creates purpose. Afterlife: Rejected, focus on existence. Debates: Human nature, social constraints.

## Key Thinkers
Sartre, Beauvoir, Albert Camus (contrast).

## Influence
Feminism, postcolonialism, theatre (No Exit).

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [feminist-existentialism.md](/philosophies/feminist-existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sartre[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/sartre/)
[^2]: Britannica - Jean-Paul Sartre[](https://www.britannica.com/biography/Jean-Paul-Sartre)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Sartre[](https://iep.utm.edu/sartre/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Jean-Paul Sartre[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean-Paul_Sartre)
[^5]: JSTOR - Sartrean Existentialism[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260595)
[^6]: IEP - Beauvoir[](https://iep.utm.edu/beauvoir/)

negative-utilitarianism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Negative Utilitarianism

## Introduction
Negative Utilitarianism prioritizes reducing suffering over promoting pleasure. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 20th-century utilitarianism critiques.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Minimize pain; pleasure secondary. Life meaning: Harm reduction, potentially antinatalist. Afterlife: Irrelevant, focus on earthly suffering.

## Key Thinkers
Karl Popper (negative heuristic), R.N. Smart, David Pearce (abolitionist project).

## Influence
Antinatalism, effective altruism; debated for extreme conclusions.

## Related Religions
See [utilitarianism.md](/religions/utilitarianism.md), [antinatalism.md](/philosophies/antinatalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Consequentialism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/consequentialism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Utilitarianism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/utilitarianism-philosophy)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Negative Utilitarianism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_utilitarianism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Utilitarianism[](https://iep.utm.edu/util-a-r/)
neoconservatism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neoconservatism

## Introduction
Neoconservatism combines conservative values with interventionist foreign policy. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Mid-20th-century US, from former liberals.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Moral clarity in global affairs, using power for good. Life meaning: Spreading democratic values. Afterlife: Traditional conservative.

## Key Thinkers
Irving Kristol, Norman Podhoretz, Leo Strauss (influence).

## Influence
US foreign policy (e.g., Iraq War); criticisms for militarism.

## Related Religions
See [conservatism.md](/religions/conservatism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Conservatism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/conservatism/) [contextual]
[^2]: Britannica - Neoconservatism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoconservatism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoconservatism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoconservatism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Political Philosophy[](https://iep.utm.edu/polphil/)
neoliberalism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism is a political-economic philosophy advocating free-market capitalism, deregulation, and reduced state intervention. Branch: Political. Cultural context: Late 20th-century response to Keynesianism.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual responsibility, market efficiency. Life meaning: Economic prosperity through competition. Afterlife: Secular focus.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Hayek, Milton Friedman, Margaret Thatcher.

## Influence
Globalization, IMF policies; criticized for inequality.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
neoliberalism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoliberalism

## Introduction
Neoliberalism revives classical liberal economics with market supremacy. Branch: Political. Historical context: 1938 Colloque Walter Lippmann, 1970s stagflation. Cultures: Anglo-American, global policy.

## Branches
Ordoliberalism (German), Chicago School (US).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Privatization, free trade. Ethics: Efficiency over equity. Life meaning: Entrepreneurial self. Afterlife: Irrelevant. Debates: Austerity vs. social welfare.

## Key Thinkers
Hayek (Road to Serfdom), Friedman (monetarism), Reagan/Thatcher (practitioners).

## Influence
IMF, WTO; backlash in populism.

## Related Religions
See [capitalism.md](/religions/capitalism.md), [libertarianism.md](/philosophies/libertarianism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoliberalism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoliberalism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoliberalism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neoliberalism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoliberalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoliberalism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Economic Justice[](https://iep.utm.edu/econjust/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Neoliberal Theory[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260560)
neoplatonism.md (Medium Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism is a metaphysical system of emanation from the One. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Late antiquity Rome, influencing medieval thought.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Soul purification through contemplation. Life meaning: Ascent to divine. Afterlife: Reunion with the One.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus (Enneads), Porphyry, Proclus.

## Influence
Christian mysticism, Islamic philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoplatonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neoplato/)
neoplatonism-medium.md (Medium Tier ~800 words)
text# Neoplatonism

## Introduction
Neoplatonism integrates Platonic ideas with mysticism. Branch: Metaphysics. Historical context: Plotinus in 3rd-century Alexandria. Cultures: Greco-Roman, Byzantine.

## Branches
Plotinian (philosophical), Iamblichean (theurgic, ritualistic).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: The One emanates Intellect, Soul, matter. Ethics: Theurgy and virtue for ascent. Life meaning: Return to unity. Afterlife: Soul immortal ascent. Debates: Matter as evil or necessary.

## Key Thinkers
Plotinus, Porphyry, Proclus, Pseudo-Dionysius (Christian adaptation).

## Influence
Renaissance humanism, Kabbalah.

## Related Religions
See [christian-neoplatonism.md](/religions/christian-neoplatonism.md), [emanationism.md](/philosophies/emanationism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/neoplatonism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neoplatonism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/Neoplatonism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neoplatonism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Neoplatonism[](https://iep.utm.edu/neoplato/)
[^5]: JSTOR - Neoplatonic Thought[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260561)
neopositivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neopositivism

## Introduction
Neopositivism is a refinement of logical positivism, emphasizing confirmation over verification. Branch: Epistemology. Cultural context: Post-WWII philosophy of science.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Empirical morals. Life meaning: Scientific knowledge. Afterlife: Unfalsifiable.

## Key Thinkers
Hans Reichenbach, Carl Hempel (covering-law model).

## Influence
Scientific methodology, analytic philosophy.

## Related Religions
See [logical-positivism.md](/religions/logical-positivism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Empiricism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logical-empiricism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Neopositivism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/neopositivism)
[^3]: Wikipedia - Neopositivism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neopositivism)
[^4]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Logical Positivism[](https://iep.utm.edu/logpos/)

text# Neuroethics

## Introduction
Neuroethics is the ethics of neuroscience and brain technologies. Branch: Ethics. Cultural context: 21st-century neuroadvances.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Privacy in brain data. Life meaning: Enhanced cognition. Afterlife: Consciousness transfer?

## Key Thinkers
Martha Farah, Jonathan Moreno.

## Influence
Policy on neurotech.

## Related Religions
See [bioethics.md](/religions/bioethics.md), [medical-ethics.md](/philosophies/medical-ethics.md).

neurophilosophy.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neurophilosophy

## Introduction
Neurophilosophy uses neuroscience to address philosophical problems. Branch: Mind. Cultural context: 1980s cognitive revolution.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Brain-based morals. Life meaning: Neurological self. Afterlife: Brain death end.

## Key Thinkers
Patricia Churchland, Paul Churchland.

## Influence
Eliminativism, philosophy of mind.

## Related Religions
See [eliminative-materialism.md](/religions/eliminative-materialism.md).

neutral-monism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Neutral Monism

## Introduction
Neutral Monism posits one neutral substance underlying mind and matter. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: 19th-century psychology.

## Key Ideas
Neither mental nor physical primary. Ethics: Unified moral framework. Life meaning: Neutral existence. Afterlife: Neutral continuation.

## Key Thinkers
William James, Bertrand Russell.

## Influence
Process philosophy, monism debates.

## Related Religions
See [monism.md](/religions/monism.md).

## Sources

text# New Formalism

## Introduction
New Formalism revives form in poetry and literature. Branch: Aesthetics. Cultural context: Late 20th-century literary revival.

## Key Ideas
Emphasis on meter, rhyme. Ethics: Aesthetic discipline. Life meaning: Structured beauty. Afterlife: Not addressed.

## Key Thinkers
Dana Gioia, Frederick Turner.

## Influence
Contemporary poetry, criticism.

nihilism.md (High Tier - Basic ~400 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism denies inherent meaning or value. Branch: Existentialism. Cultural context: 19th-century Russia, Nietzsche.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: No objective morals. Life meaning: Absurd void. Afterlife: None or meaningless.

## Key Thinkers
Friedrich Nietzsche (active nihilism), Ivan Turgenev.

## Influence
Existentialism, postmodernism.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche-1872.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)

nihilism-medium.md (High Tier ~800 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism rejects value, meaning. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Turgenev 1862, Nietzsche 1880s. Cultures: Russian, German.

## Branches
Metaphysical, ethical nihilism.

## Key Ideas
Detailed: God is dead. Ethics: Beyond good/evil. Life meaning: Self-overcome. Afterlife: Illusion. Debates: Passive vs. active.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche, Camus, Sartre.

## Influence
Absurdism, deconstruction.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche-1872.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [absurdism.md](/philosophies/absurdism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)

nihilism-large.md (High Tier ~1500 words)
text# Nihilism

## Introduction
Nihilism asserts life's lack of meaning. Branch: Existentialism. Historical context: Russian nihilists 1860s, Nietzsche's "God is dead". Cultures: European, global existential.

## Branches
Metaphysical (no reality), ethical (no morals), existential (no purpose).

## Key Ideas
Detailed: Value void. Ethics: Revaluation. Life meaning: Create own. Afterlife: None. Debates: Nihilism as liberation or despair.

## Key Thinkers
Nietzsche (active nihilism), Turgenev, Camus (absurd response).

## Influence
Postmodernism, therapy.

## View Illustrative Image
[View Friedrich Nietzsche Portrait](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Friedrich_Nietzsche-1872.jpg) (Public domain, Wikimedia Commons, pre-1928)

## Related Religions
See [existentialism.md](/religions/existentialism.md), [absurdism.md](/philosophies/absurdism.md), [moral-nihilism.md](/philosophies/nihilism-variants-moral-nihilism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nihilism/)
[^2]: Britannica - Nihilism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/nihilism)
[^3]: Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Nihilism[](https://iep.utm.edu/nihilism/)
[^4]: Wikipedia - Nihilism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nihilism)
[^5]: JSTOR - Nihilist Philosophy[](https://www.jstor.org/stable/3260594)
[^6]: IEP - Nietzsche[](https://iep.utm.edu/nietzsch/)

text# Nominalism

## Introduction
Nominalism denies universals, only particulars exist. Branch: Metaphysics. Cultural context: Medieval philosophy.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Individual morals. Life meaning: Particular. Afterlife: Particular soul.

## Key Thinkers
William of Ockham, David Hume.

## Influence
Empiricism, analytic.

## Related Religions
See [conceptualism.md](/religions/conceptualism.md).

## Sources

[^3]: Wikipedia - Nominalism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominalism)
non-cognitivism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Non-Cognitivism

## Introduction
Non-Cognitivism holds moral statements non-truth-apt. Branch: Meta-Ethics. Cultural context: Emotivist ethics.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Expressive. Life meaning: Emotional. Afterlife: Non-cognitive.

## Key Thinkers
A.J. Ayer, C.L. Stevenson.

## Influence
Expressivism.

## Related Religions
See [emotivism.md](/religions/emotivism.md).

non-theism.md (Low Tier - Basic ~300 words)
text# Non-Theism

## Introduction
Non-Theism is absence of theism without atheism. Branch: Theism. Cultural context: Secular spirituality.

## Key Ideas
Ethics: Humanist. Life meaning: Natural. Afterlife: Ambiguous.

## Key Thinkers
Paul Kurtz, secular Buddhists.

## Influence
Humanism, agnosticism.

## Related Religions
See [atheism.md](/religions/atheism.md).

## Sources
[^1]: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy - Atheism[](https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/atheism-agnosticism/)
[^2]: Wikipedia - Non-Theism[](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-theism)
[^3]: Britannica - Atheism[](https://www.britannica.com/topic/atheism)
